text: There is certainly the "boots" theory of economics, which is to say that higher-dollar items are often better in the long run because they hold up better over time (originally from Terry Pratchett's novels discussing how a single pair of high-dollar boots can last a decade while cheap shoes will come apart in a year or so, so you end up spending a lot more on replacement if you can't afford a single up-front outlay), but a 15k fridge is outside the realm on that.  And these days, half the time the cheaper option is the longer-lasting one because it doesn't have a thousand electronic components that can burn out and just trash the whole darn thing.  I want a fridge with a good solid cooling system and a classic bimetallic thermostat and absolutely no smarts whatsoever.  Put the freezer up top, a solid door that doesn't punch holes through the insulation to add an icemaker or whatever, that'll last you decades.

text: Adam. I have been subscribed to you for a long time. Watched a lot of your videos. I think if you look back on the script of this video, you will see how tone deaf some of your comments are. Being self-aware about how rich you are doesn‚Äôt change the fact that saying things like ‚Äúit is what it is‚Äú about the price gouging on varied and nutritional foods is extremely dismissive of the real problems that people in poverty face. Let‚Äôs just be honest, six years ago when you were ‚Äúpoor‚Äù you were not ‚Äúpoor‚Äú enough to not have access to a nice kitchen to make food, or time enough to make and edit YouTube videos to get started. You are blessed, and that is wonderful, but the systems in the United States and many other countries around the world are in place to keep people poor, keep them sick, and keep them paying large industries for convenience or healthcare. In my opinion, many of your words throughout this video are filtered through unintentional, ignorance, or unintentional cowardice. With a position and a platform like yours, taking a firm stance on your opinions would go a long way. Instead of saying that fruits and vegetables should ‚Äúprobably‚Äú be distributed more equally, maybe you of all people could just say that they ‚Äúshould‚Äú be distributed more equally. Yes, many people who are economically disadvantaged have made poor decisions that have led them to that spot. That said, the system makes those decisions 1 million times more likely to be chosen. The best thing you said in the video, besides the recipe itself,was that you believe many people aren‚Äôt being paid what they‚Äôre worth. I wish you hadn‚Äôt had waited until the end of the video to say it. In my opinion, Adam, you can do better than this.

text:
Dominican Beans
(adapted from FrugalFitMom)
1 onion, chopped
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 green bell pepper
2 T tomato paste
4 t no-chicken base
1 T red wine vinegar
2 15 oz. cans pinto beans, rinsed and drained
1 t each dried oregano and basil
garlic powder
cilantro stems of half a bunch, chopped
1 bay leaf
3 c water, to cover
rice, for serving
optional on the side: chopped raw onion, sliced tomato, avocado

In a large skillet or wok, saute in some oil onion, when starts to brown add bell pepper and when soft, add cilantro stems and cook a bit then add garlic and cook a few min.
Add tomato paste and cook a bit.
Add remaining ingredients and stir to combine.
Cover, Btb (bring to boil), Rts (Reduce to Simmer), and simmer 2 hrs.
Serve over rice with chopped raw onion on top and diced tomato and avocado.
author: @MauraMarcus

text:
Black Beans and Peppers
1 clove garlic, minced
1 Tablespoon olive oil
1 cup chopped red, yellow, or green pepper (or a mixture)
1/2 cup chopped onion
3/4 teaspoon chili powder
1 15 oz. can black beans, drained and rinsed
1 8 oz. can stewed tomatoes, chopped 
1 bay leaf
1/8 to 1/4 teaspoon red pepper flakes
1¬Ω teaspoons red wine vinegar
2 cup cooked rice

In a large skillet, saut√© garlic in oil over moderately low heat for 1 minute.
Add peppers and onion; increase heat to moderate, and saute until onion
has wilted and pepper are slightly softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in chili powder, beans, tomatoes, bay leaf and pepper flakes.
Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook until slightly thickened, about 15 minutes.
Add vinegar.  Cook 2 minutes longer.
Remove bay leaf and serve over hot rice.
author: @MauraMarcus

text:
I made this for dinner tonight:
Spiced Potato Spinach Lentils (Aloo Palak Dal)
1 tsp oil
1 onion, chopped
1 inch ginger, grated on microplane
4 cloves of garlic, minced
1 t cinnamon
¬º t nutmeg
¬º t ground cloves
some freshly ground black pepper
1 t ground cardamom
1 t ground cumin
¬Ω t turmeric
1 15 oz. can of tomatoes with green chiles
3 fl. oz. uncooked brown or green lentils, rinsed
2 medium gold potatoes, cubed into ¬Ω‚Äù dice
1 13.5 oz. can coconut milk
water
3/4 tsp salt 
6 oz. baby spinach or a combination of greens, chopped

Saute onion in oil until brown.
Add ginger and garlic and saute until garlic golden, but careful not to burn.
Add spices and saute 1 min.
Add tomatoes and cook 15 min. or so.
Add brown lentils, potatoes, coconut milk, and some water.  If using green lentils, let them cook 15 min. before adding potatoes.
Bring to a boil and reduce to a simmer and cover and cook 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, adding water as needed.
When lentils are nearly done, add spinach and salt.  Smash some of the potatoes to thicken the dish.  When lentils are softened and spinach wilted, serve over rice with peas on the side.
author: @MauraMarcus

text:
You're supposed to let the beans soak for at least 6h before cooking them and throw the soaky water away. 
Beans have a lot of phytate which hinders our ability to absorb its nutrients, which is why you soak it (to drain the phytate) and throw the phytate full water away.

text: 11:35 plant‚Äôs proteins and even some micronutrients aren‚Äôt as bioavailable as meat‚Äôs, protein isn‚Äôt just 1 thing, there‚Äôs several different kinds of proteins and at their base level they‚Äôre called amino acids, most plants don‚Äôt have all amino acids which means when you eat them you can‚Äôt utilize all the proteins because you‚Äôre missing several amino acids, you can try to balance plants with other plants which do have the missing amino acids but that‚Äôs very hard because then you have to weigh out each portion of plants, find out their bioavailability, which amino acids they have and how much per serving, add them all up, then find out what foods have the missing ones and not to mention it‚Äôs bad for the environment because of monocrop agriculture OR you can eat animal products which ALL have the necessary amino acids, ‚Äúskipping the middle man‚Äù is a dumb argument because why not skip the plants too and just get energy from the sun and water, we‚Äôre omnivores for a reason.

When money is short I buy the best protein I can afford, like beef, chicken or pork, and also calf liver and chicken liver and eggs, canned tuna‚Ä¶and very little else. All the nutrients you need can be found in very small servings. I have plenty of calories attached to my hips and thighs for use in hard times. The occasional fruit and vegetable to keep the gut flowing. Beans have lectins which can cause an inflammatory response especially if you don‚Äôt throw away the soaking water. The last thing you need when you are poor is to be sick.

text:
I live alone and have no money. I always make big pots of soups and stews, using los of vegetables and beans or lentils (often using up whole packages or units of things) - I also freeze portions, etc. But I always add at least one different, fresh thing each time I reheat a portion of the "original". To the finished dish, I add cheese, yogurt, tofu, very occasionlly a little bit of chicken if I get it cheap. Works fine for me!
As far as energy costs go, I only have a very small oven and use it rarely - and when I do, I don't preheat it and make sure it's full each time. I cook on a double halogen hob with a timer, and leave my dishes to finish cooking in the retained heat, saving between 5 and 20 minutes of power-on cooking time.

text:
Something important to note:
Livestock digest more of the plant than you do. Grass fed meat is filling a gap in the food chain that would be left unfilled by the line of reasoning you mentioned around 11 minutes in. We're not herbivores, 90% of what we do with vegetation rather than the fruits/seeds/tubers of plants is effectively making tea, usually to soak said tea into our food (AKA what you do with your herbs and spices). 
See, there's land out there that you can't grow crops on due to soil quality, maybe lacking rainfall, etc. Irrigation is pretty standard and helps with the water aspect of these issues, but if the soil can't grow anything but grass, you need to turn grass into food.
I could go on forever about how it'd be better for the environment if we brought back nuclear power as a baseline power source, freeing up a lot of land for growing crops, restoring forests, or raising livestock.
Factory farms are definitely a problem, but it's precisely the californian urban "meat is murder" type folks who run or enable corporate farms.

text:
A thing I do a fair bit for a budget meal is pretty simple: Dice up a couple potatoes and an onion. Not a fancy, individually sold white onion like the one in the video, just a yellow onion, bought by the bag like your potatoes. Fry in a pan with a tablespoon of butter, maybe a splash or two of white or apple cider vinegar for bite. Add miscellaneous other things based on what you've got, after they're about halfway done. Maybe a bit of herbs and spices, maybe an egg scrambled in by stirring it in the pan with the spatula, maybe some shredded cheese if you don't mind it getting clumpy. Probably some salt. Pretty much whatever you feel like that seems like it would go well, and some things that don't.
Scoop it out onto a plate when you feel it's ready, add ketchup, mustard, and/or barbecue sauce. Eat.
I have no clue how well balanced it is for dietary needs, and I'm sure it's missing some important stuff. But it's not really an every meal, every day thing, just something that works when you need it.
author: @jadekaiser7840

text:
Sorry, but the thesis of this video is that you can't have a different and delicious meal every time you cook at home is either BS or American reality, Idk. The point is, I'm from Europe and I manage my products just fine spending ~2000 UAH per week, it's 47.6 USD. The secret is that you should buy in a wholesale lot of sauces, herbs & other interesting products that can lay on a shelf for a long time, and it makes you ~80% ready to cook something fancy at all times. Now you just go to any local store and buy the lacking 20% of ingredients when they are fresh and just cook it! If you want to save time, go do a base prep. Just cook 800g of rice, spray some oil, mix gently, throw it in the fridge, and u can have a different rice-based meal for up to 4 days! No, it's not gonna go bad, it's still really good. Anyways, I always cook for my family and I never repeat the dish more than 2 times a month. And guess what - the only reason I cook something for the second time is because it was bussin :)

(Let me know if you wanna know more tricks that I'm using)

text: I love this video.  Thank you!  I'm paid decently but live in a high cost of living area for now and need to budget a lot more than I used to.  I think the fridge and the food you just made are analogous.  By taking another few weeks and 3-5k, as well as the added frustration and coordination, you could have swapped in a "normal" fridge and had another cabinet to boot, under the budget of the fridge.  But to get it done and over with quickly, you paid a lot more to minimize your hassle.  Just like making food for yourself to save money takes time and frustration and coordination (and sometimes extra money to buy a bulk ingredient you don't have), but a lot of us choose to vastly overpay restaurants - or factories - to make us food and minimize the time and hassle.  But in that forgetting of time and hassle, we also lose customization and passion.  I know I'm happier making a cheap dish at home and serving it to my family, just like you may have been happier with a nice, tidy cabinet and a smaller fridge.

text:
if you're new to it all and trying to cook from recipes for the first time you're going to have to buy every single thing and say wow I had to spend $60 to make this meal so this isn't worth it at all. but as you develop the skills and routine of it all you might find yourself going to the store to get 1-2 ingredients when you want to make something specific because you already have everything else. there are a few fast food items that are actually okay price per nutrition but you can absolutely eat at home for less. if you're trying to recreate a chipotle burrito for the first time and you need to buy every ingredient then you're not going to beat their price but if you're in a routine of making those burritos every single week then you will save 80% of the price easily

i've worked in restaurants for about 12 years now and cooked growing up some too and i still struggle to make the habit of eating at home. when i find myself compelled to go out, i ask myself what i'm going out to get and how i can start making it at home. fried chicken wings, crispy loaded hash browns, delicious burgers with lots of toppings, massive burritos, pizzas, all the things i crave the most and trade my hard-earned money for are easy to make at home. but i understand it's a lot of effort, discipline, and time investment

text:
As far as a single pizza being less efficient. I simply adjusted my pizza recipe to suit home oven cooking. I don't need to preheat my over for an hour. 
First order of business, tthe pizza stone is not necessary to get good leoparding on the bottom of your pizza. (Leoparding is brown spots)
I use an aluminum pizza pan. I also don't need to transfer the pizza onto a hot pizza stone, which can be difficult. 
Second, oil your aluminum pan very well, I mean like soaking wet with oil. 
(I use avocado oil both in the pizza dough and on the pan because of health reasons. I have a rare incurable blood cancer (myeloproliferative neoplasm) so inflammatory oils like seed oils are out they play havoc with platelets, which I can't have those at all even as an ingredient in the food. Avocado oil has a high smoke point and taste good. Extra virgin olive oil works too, avocado oil just taste better to me.)
I usually make my dough the night before (covered in a bowl) and let it sit in the refrigerator overnight, take it out a couple of hours before you use it. You can make pizza dough several hours before using it and let it rise on the countertop covered. Occasionally I've made pizza dough and let it rise for as little as an hour before using it, though the overnight method gives a better result. 
Third, start preheating your oven to 425F, then stretch your dough on the liberally oiled aluminum pan, add your sauce and toppings. By the time my pizza is formed and topped the oven will be heated. 
So here's the thing about preheating your oven, not all ovens are equal, you have to play with the temperature setting through trial and error the first few times you make pizza. It took about three tries over time for me to discover that my oven gave the best result for leoparding on the bottom and a brown top at 425F. You might have a convection oven or something different, it may take a different temperature setting to get a good result on top and bottom. OR you may need to put your oven rack higher up in the oven or lower down because of the way your over heats, so play with oven rack positions too. A few degrees either way will make a big difference, you need to balance how brown the pizza gets on the bottom with topping browning. But once you find that sweet spot in your oven with the pan you like to use it's sweet sailing from there on in. 
No preheating or pizza stone needed. 

P.S. Since your cooking with lower temperatures you might want to change the moisture content of your dough too.I found cooking at 425F a couple extra tablesppons makes a difference.  But do it in very small increments. BUT MOST OF ALL! Don't change a lot of parameters all at once because then you don't know which tweak in your recipe was the one that got it closer to the result you want. From Carl Sagan's Contact "Small moves Ellie, small moves".

text:
Not trying to start an argument about the ethics or economics of eating meat, but I would like to point out a common fallacy which has been repeated here. Unless you can find a way for people to directly consume things like grass, straw, etc., it is not as simple as just eating the vegetables directly instead of feeding them to the animals. A significant portion of the land surface used for grazing livestock is not well suited to growing human-digestible food crops.

That's not to say that ALL animal feed is inedible to humans. There's this little thing called nuance. Animals can and do have a place in a balanced diet, and can help turn stuff we cannot eat into stuff that we can. It doesn't look like there are going to be significantly fewer mouths on the planet to feed any time soon, so we need to be as efficient as possible in finding ways to turn sunlight into people food.

text:
Like many have said here, saving $ through your food budget can help you a lot. However it can get tricky, taxing(on time, money, and on the body), intimidating maybe, but you have to use your head. Something that more and more people are not doing unfortunately as time goes by
Theres too many variables to list here since everybody's situation is different based on where they live.

Having said that the best skills you want/have to master if you want to keep your food budget reasonable is to be efficient and resourceful. Buy what you plan on fully using but take adavantage of the byproducts you can get from some the ingredients that you can use in other dishes. 

You eat bacon? Use the bacon grease to make mayonaise for your sandwiches, tuna/chicken salad. Use it in your baking. Fry your food with it. This is just a few examples out of hundreds you can do with secondary by products from your cooking.

Plus planning your meals is also a major help. This way your not scrambling on deciding what to eat. Doing these techniques (with your specific diet) can save you money. It takes trial and error.

text: Here in Brazil "feij√£o com arroz" (lit. bean with rice), is the traditional, "working-class" basic food of our meal, so much so that it's become a idiom, meaning the 'main sustenance' of something,. A typical Brazilian meal comprises beans and rice, salad and "the mixture", that is, the protein: beef, chicken, fish, eggs, the works. It's also quite common, specially in the North/Northeast, to add some sort of potato, squash, yam, manioc/cassava, plantain, etc.

text:
Cooking does not guarantee you spend less money but it 100% goes much further if you put in the time to learn some basic stables.  Being able to create a good rice dish, pasta dish, salad, soup, sandwich, etc. is a good thing because these are all pretty modular dishes that can take in whatever you have and put out something servicable.

If you are smart about it, you can stock on staples that last you a long time. I spend around 200$ at costco every month to 2 months. I also go to the grocery store each week for smaller items. That may seem like a lot but the way I see it is that food is important to me (beyond just living) and I don't eat out at all plus I'm a young tall guy who is working out and has a bottomless stomach. 

Cooking has definitely saved me money, on a budget. Pasta, chicken breast, cheese, a veggie, a negligable cost of seasonings. You can produce a dish that is not only as good as something you'd get at a restaurant but also make 4 servings of this for under 20$. That's better than a 5$ footlong. A 7.5$ chicken can feed a family of four for a night and maybe even have some left overs for the next day. That's better than a KFC bucket deal. A bag of potatoes is a bag of fries and mash potatoes (as well as: potatoes!) and a bag of onions is flavor for a month. 

It's incredibly strange to me seeing people saying "eating cheap is just eating the same four things over and over again." Eating cheap is just recognizing that you have to spend money to save money. i buy pasta at costco to cover the next 2-3 months of pasta eating. I buy big bags of rice to make rice. I eat eggs with rice. I eat eggs with bread if I find a good loaf for a few bucks at a grocery store. I make my own biscuits and if I find sausage discounted i make white gravy with it. I would say I never spend more than 5 days eating the same thing (becuase i typically meal prep 5 days out.) and each week on the weekends I am allowed to be creative and ask what I want to eat or try to make for the week ahead. 

I eat better and cheaper than nearly everyone I know. I understand that there are some housing/work situations that make this not possible, but for me I am making awesome stuff for myself each week at a fraction of the price of even other people who don't efficiently purchase things for themselves (and I enjoy cooking so it's fun for me too).

text:
I did grocery reviews for about a year. Every store in my city, every week.  I personally saved people millions in research time, and thousands at the register. There's no denying it: it is absolutely worth it to cook at home, versus take-out or sit-down diners (let alone any high class joint). 

The biggest take-aways were:
- Not every sale is created equally. Learn the price of things and stop overpaying. Dodge those faux-sales where items are priced high and reduced to an otherwise-regular price.
- Patience is a virtue. If it's not on sale, avoid buying it if you can. When the price is good, stock up, especially for pantry goods, anything you can freeze (get a chest freezer), toiletries - basically anything that doesn't spoil.
- Cook according to what's on sale. If it wasn't on sale, you're not eating it. Period. This translates into savings, sure, but also increased variety and creative cooking. Over time, the creative aspect gets easier and less time/energy intensive.
- Build up a good pantry of staples (rice, grains, beans, flour). Fill that chest freezer with sale meat, bread, and butter. Build a good selection of herbs, spices, and seasonings (buy in bulk when you can, don't buy the stupid 5x priced little jars).
- Get at least one good-ish knife and upgrade your knife skills. Not a Japanese folded steel $500 thing. Just a $100 chef's knife you can learn to sharpen yourself. Heck, even a shit knife sharpened with the base of a ceramic coffee cup will do wonders. The time-savings from knowing how to use a knife properly are worth the practice.
- Planning ahead pays off (thawing out ingredients, planning your grocery shopping around the days before and after new sales roll over into a new week)
- When possible, grow a small garden for ingredients that are high-margin/high-waste/high-convenience items, mainly fresh herbs, a few hot pepper varieties (mild to proper hot), a few tomato plants (I suggest smaller, high-producing heirloom varieties that pack more flavour than big watery tomatoes that take forever to ripen).
- When it comes to cooking, your time is worth exactly the difference between the cost of ingredients and the cost you'd pay to have someone make it for you.

That last point is SUPER important. If it costs $10-15 and 1 hour to make a pizza, versus 40 bucks to have one of equal quality delivered to you in the same hour, then you're effectively paying yourself $25-30 an hour to make that damned pizza. For many people and households, this is a non-trivial value opportunity. Many people have to work 2 extra hours at a min-wage/mediocre paying job to make up that extra $25-30 they might get AFTER tax. So, just do the work yourself. Sure, at first, it could take longer than an hour, but you get quick at it, and soon making your own pizza (in the comfort of your own home) becomes an hour spent at a stove to save two at a shitty job. And this applies across the board, for hundreds of meals a year, most of which require much less than an hour to prepare. So, unless you're making over $30/h (after tax), it's worth it to cook for yourself. Once you get the ball rolling, the savings compound rather quickly, and the savings roll through the year as you buy and replenish your pantry/freezer stocks based on sales. 

And goodness... dry beans. They cost 1/4 as much as canned, or, for the $3 you spend on a bag of beans, you get $12 worth of beans for just soaking them yourself.

text: The idea of eating plants that the animals eat is very simplistic. Yes, in our current conventional agricultural world, we can and do eat the things animals eat. Corn, soy, and cereals are edible and tasty. These things are fed to the animals in a manner that is very much fits the economy of scale model to a T. Models of economy should not be the most important indicator of success. What I mean to say is that there are more worthwhile measures of success and goodness than efficiency. My thoughts are all over the place and a Youtube comment a poor soap box from which to preach. As succinctly as I can, we are a part of the earth's ecosystem. We cannot look to extract what we want and never play an input role. Regenerative animal management is rejuvenating for the producer, consumer, and ecology of the planet. It is so important that consumers know how their food is produced. I well informed consumer will influence producers to move to regenerative practices.

text:
So rice and beans are the cheap stuff in the US? In France, it's clearly potatoes for me. It can cost around 1‚Ç¨/Kg sometime even less.It's also really cool because you can do so much different thing with potatoes (if you use the right kind), french fries, mashed potatoes, pomme dauphine, saut√©e potatoes,  etc... For vegetables, Yellow onions are a good contester, 1.5‚Ç¨/Kg depending of what time of year you buy it. Because yeah, that one of the main point of buying on a budget: you need to buy what is available in the season, it's generaly cheaper. Also i don't know how it work in the US but you can get food who are close to the limit date for cheaper  (you obviously have to it cook when you return home for safety reason). They are sometime 25 to 33% cheaper and it make a huge difference. Also i recommand to use seasoning and create a sauce with your food

And finaly, don't look at the price but the price per kg. Sometime food cost more but you save money because you have more quantity for less money. Also freezer can help to keep food longer if you buy too much but i sometime freeze them in little portion to be in use them when i defreeze them. For exemple 3 months ago, i buy 1kg of beef because it was in sale and i froze it after only using 100g asap but forgot to cut it in small part. So now i've to use the whole 900g if i defroze it, it kinda suck but teach me a lesson.

PS: the video is on point and he know what he is doing, i appreciate that.

text:
The amount of times I said "hell yeah, dude" as I watched this is an all-time record for any YT video I've ever watched. Cheers from a former food-stamps/gov't cheese kid with aggressive food allergies.

Also, crappily made "fried rice" (read: no wok, less oil, salt instead of soy sauce if yr strapped) is a great "anytime" low-cost meal. Make a giant pot of rice and store it in your fridge. Heat some oil in a pan, crumble in some rice, drop in a few frozen veggies/some onion and a couple eggs and you're in business. Always use 1-2 less eggs than you think you'll need. I've been making this for breakfast and it has really helped me stretch my supply of (compared to what they used to be) now astronomically expensive eggs.

text: Quality vs price is (very roughly) a logarithmic relationship. If you pay ten times as much for something, it might be twice as good; paying a hundred times more might make it four times as good. That makes quality conform to a similar value curve to buying multiples of the same thing (a second car may provide you value, but it doesn't provide the same value as your first car). Economists call this relationship between spending and value 'diminishing marginal utility', and I think it's underexplored how it effects the psychology of weath.

text:
So anyone that's into food enough to watch your videos is into food enough to know that ripening fruits produce a gas that causes other nearby fruit to ripen, which is why spoiling fruit causes other fruit to spoil rapidly.  One cool thing about the Sub-Zero refrigerators is that they have a catalyst in the fruit bins that converts that gas into other components, causing your fruit to ripen and eventually spoil at a mich slower rate.

Is it worth spending 13-15k on a fridge for?  I'm with you, no, it's not.  But it's pretty damn cool tech.  Plus, they're American made, so you're paying for US workers, not quasi-slave labor in Vietnam.  You've got the money, I say it was a good buy.  I could buy shit from Walmart, but when I buy, I buy quality domestic stuff.  It's better quality for me and better wages for the guy making it, because yes, people should get paid their worth.

text:
20 lbs of rice, 12 lbs of Costco chicken thighs, two bags of broccoli/spinach, 3 heads of garlic, 3 onions, vegetable oil, salt, pepper, bottle of soy sauce. Rice cooker and pan on stove. Dinner for two to three weeks for less than 100 bucks probably even including utilities for the three times I cook the stuff (but not including the fixed assets, i.e. house, fridge, stove, rice cooker, and pan). Boring as heck, but way cheaper than eating out. I lived like this for a while when I wasn't making as much (but I ate out on weekends). And I still eat like this with my kids except I mix up the meat types and veges.

*I'm also not eating all 20 lbs of rice in three weeks, nor using all the garlic cloves, vegetable oil, salt, pepper and soy sauce. So I'm usually only getting meat and veges every two weeks.

text:
On being poor in the US:  You do what you can with what you have, and as you noted, you can work your butt off/work smart and get richer.  If you choose not to do that, chances are you will stay where you're at.  If you get richer then screw it up, you can end up poor again.  My own life is a prime example of this.  Sometimes you can get in between.  You can also choose WHERE you live--Texas or Oklahoma is a lot cheaper than California or New York.

On eating out versus eating cheaper at home:  I can spend $50 to maybe $75 a week and eat homemade meals with meat of some sort in every meal.  But if I'm eating fast food all the time--buying $14 meals for every meal, that's almost $300/week.  But--I can't do fancy cuts of steak on that sorta budget.  If you wanna make it interesting, fill your pantry with a large variety of spices.  Spices are expensive other than salt (and buy the store brand salt--sodium chloride is sodium chloride and likewise for iodized), but two things on that:  first, once you buy a jar, you'll probably have that jar for awhile unless you use that particular spice a lot.  Second, I don't know if any other stores do this, but if you shop at WinCo, you can buy spices in their bulk section--no, I don't mean buying a 5lb bag of garlic powder or something.  You grab a bag, dispense said garlic powder into it to your desired amt, and buy it by weight.  It tends to be cheaper than prepackaged jars.  And then they sell you plastic jars you can put it in.  Oh--and a third thing on spices--REUSE your spice jars!  Wanna put something else in it?  Wash it, relabel, and refill!

text:
What people in Cooking YouTube that show "cookery on a budget" often overlook is 1) whether you start a recipe from scratch with all ingredients purchased; 2) whether each ingredient is a one-time use (full volume) or has multiple doles (many volumes); 3 whether a "staple" of a kitchen is included in a recipe (e.g., flour, sugar, eggs, milk). When a "meal" costs $3.00 per serving, for example, is that a dish that you make one time for one exact serving or for four servings at one meal or makes several servings over multiple meals, and is there "waste" that either you can't use in anything else or is it "thrift" because you can use parts of ingredients in something else over time?

Many, many, many videos gloss over this. The meal you made has both a) "staple" items, such as beans, spices, sugar, even the vinegar; b) fresh items that you may or may not keep, such as the capsicum/bell pepper or onion, which means you might have i) waste which can't be reused (and I see almost none); ii) thrift, such as the vinegar, spices, and if you use DRIED beans [which you did], extra beans; iii) excess, which can be stored in a 15K fridge (and simmered Cuban-style black beans -- CONGR√ç -- is a "freezes beautifully" food that lasts for weeks in the freezer).

I thoroughly enjoyed this video and hope people who watched had takeaways that got them to think/plan/imagine in how to be economical in buying and making cooked food at home.

If you want a better explanation of this go to the channel What I‚Äôve Learned. He makes great deep dives into health, nutrition, and things surrounding those topics like the meat industry. text: To be fair, even doing restaurant quality foods at home ends up being cheaper than actual restaurant food these days, because you still get 3-4 portions for the same price you get one portion in a restaurant... Hell, the more middlemen you skip, the cheaper you can go. For example buying whole chicken and processing it yourself is so much cheaper than buying just a package of pre-cut breasts or thighs... You get bones you can turn into a great soup (that's like 8-10 portitions easily for a bigger chicken and enough veggies), you can render the fat and store it so you need to buy less oil/fats since you can produce your own, and you obviously get 2 thighs, 2 breasts and 2 wings... what I do is I usually use the breasts for some actual recipes, like king pao, or chicken salad or whatever, that's another 4-6 portions of food there, and I freeze and collect the thighs for other recipes. There's plenty of similar tricks... Like don't peel your potatoes or if you do need to, keep the peels and prepare them in a different ways.... Don't throw vegetable cuttings away, keep them for stocks... Use deep frozen vegetables and fruits more, those are good quality and cheap, certain vegetables like spring onions can be stored in water on the window rather than in fridge, which means it will continue growing and yield more onion... There's plenty of zero-waste tricks you can use to make all your meals cheaper and healthier... The quality of the meal itself is mostly a skill thing... keep cooking for long enough and you'll find plenty of ways and techniques to turn the same amount of ingredients into higher quality and better tasting results... ofc there are exceptions, I'm not gonna make foie gras a lot, or fry my pommes in duck fat... I'm not going to eat a beef wellington often or anything like that... but to be fair when you go to a restaurant, how often do you really order a meal that you couldn't make at home? Restaurant orders should be reserved for foods you can't make or can't make cheap, there really are exceptions where the market-at-scale makes a big difference... but a chicken salad is not one of those...

text:
I think you're coming from a good place but exaggerating the challenge of eating healthy on a budget. The biggest hurdle is the upfront investment, not just in stocking the pantry with staples, but also in the time and energy spent learning to cook basic food. But once you get over that initial hump it becomes much easier to prepare healthy, enjoyable, and even diverse meals consistently for substantially less money than relying on prepared/packaged foods. There is a risk of understating this initial activation energy and thus being seen as an out of touch YouTube chef, which you are very clearly trying your best to avoid, but you also do a disservice to people by overstating it and arguing that any significant portion of your audience is so poor that they seriously need to consider retaining bean soak water for the sake of maximizing calories per dollar.

I feel a more productive message would be to emphasize how much cheaper and healthier it can be for an experienced home cook to consistently cook for themselves and then acknowledge the challenges that lay between the person who has an empty pantry and no cooking skills with clear steps to improve from there -- what pantry staples to start with, which skills and dishes to learn first, how to budget/plan meals and groceries, etc.

text:
About pizza: to be honest, even living in Italy (north, if you go to Naples is a different story) I can spend MUUUUCH less doing a restaurant level pizza than going to the actual restaurant. It cost me around 4-6 euro (depending from the toppings), all included to cook 2 pizzas in a Effeuno p134h oven. Including electricity. 

Just to say for 2 pizza STG: 0.30 of flour; 0.07 yeast; 1.80 mozzarella; 1.29 san marzano tomatoes; 0.32 electricity. 0.01 salt; 0.12 EVO oil; 0.20 pecorino romano. Basil is free from the garden. If i go out eating STG for 2 people in my hometown it will be around 16 euro just for a couple of STG pizzas, you need to add service fee and drinks (with their upcosts). In total it means i saved 10-12 euro each pizza: counting that in 12 months i got the oven i am over 200 pizzas baked (ok i didn't eat them all myself, i many family and friends had pizzas too)... the total savings are over 1000 euro already.

text:
I feel like the premise of this video was kinda given up on after like 2 minutes and then we had a lot of random rambling.

A few points:
-Even one hour of putting your oven on full blast is price wise pretty negligible. (In Germany it would be like half a Euro at worst)
-To remake that takeout would maybe cost quite a bit but after you have made it you probably have a lot of random shit you can use for many more dishes.
-You can make a lot of different dishes even with the same ingredients, you don't have to eat the same thing every day.

Buying raw ingredients and making meals out of them is almost always significantly cheaper no matter if its cheap or expensive dishes.
One can have a discussion about opportunity cost, labor or if it makes a lot of sense to make your own lets say Mustard because it's technically cheaper.
There is an skill to cooking in a way that you cook diverse range of food, with little food waste and economically and there are a lot of dishes that are simply great for everyday cooking like beans with rice but it's not flashy enough for a lot of food tubers.

speaking of fridges: some meals will keep for much longer in the fridge than two days. sometimes i will just make a batch of lentil curry, eat it on the day i cook it and the following day, then squeeze something other in (maybe something i buy running errands) and then make the rest of the curry into a soup.
also a reminder that "best by" dates are really just vague points of orientation. stuff like yoghurt, if still sealed, lasts days if not weeks longer than those dates, and things like soy sauce essentially keep indefinitely.

question about your recipe though: doesn't the vitamin C break down when stuff is simmered for hours? i would probably reserve half of the peppers and onions (after sauteing, i'd reckon) and add them back as a finish, also to give it a fresher taste.

text:
On the $15k fridge--I feel this because I bought a house that had a kitchen with a weird peninsula in it with a vaulted ceiling over top which would have made a hood really awkward and ridiculous looking.  So the previous owners had bought a Jenn-Air oven/range with a down draft system way back in 1982.  They kept all the paperwork for it and had paid over $3,000 for it back then.  It had all these weird modular attachments (rotisserie, electric grill, etc) and I just hated it.  Took forever to heat up, the oven space was tiny and eventually I just said "This stove is over 40 years old, it's time to replace it."

Except down-draft systems aren't really that common anymore.  And the only company that still makes them is . . . Jenn-Air.  So, I had a choice between completely retooling my kitchen to accommodate a different oven/range, install a weirdly-awkward hood in the middle of a vaulted ceiling or . . . pay $3,500 for a Jenn-Air stove.

Guess what I ended up doing?

text:
This video was great to hear. Whenever someone makes those food videos advertising "how cheap this meal is!! It costs pennies on the dollar!!" I get triggered. That entire plate of Thai Curry or whatever did not cost $2 because chances are you didnt have all the ingredients necessary in your fridge or pantry. And when you've made it? Have fun eating Thai Curry for the next, like, 3 days to use all those ingredients before they go bad.

This is the reality of cheap eating. The food might not even be this bean soup, it could actually be delicious and high quality, but you end up having to either eat it for multiple days, or strategically plan meals out to clear your cabinet.
author: @Morhamms357

text:
Personally to benefit from economies of scale and to save as much as I can, while eating fairly lavishly for someone who's """middle-class""" but functionally poor, I get bulk quantities of meat and spend a day just breaking it down into meals. Sure a 2kg bird might only last me a week, but if I'm buying them at ten bucks a pop and breaking them down myself, I can make many different things and save the carcasses and bones for making my own stock. For me eating only one kind of meal per week comes down to a time-save; I can bulk prep and then make what I need each night. I might render down a kilo of thighs down into shredded chicken and mix that with a sauce and rice and pair with bread. Each meal is only a few bucks, and it's more than enough Calories to get me through the day.

Now if I was cooking for a family that'd be different, being a single man makes things a bit easier, but it comes with its own set of challenges too since there's no second income to make weathering bad times easier.

text:
ONE ONION WAS $1.50??? I get 3 for 79 cents!! and onions last for weeks so there's no reason not to buy the 3-pack or even a bag.
I slightly disagree with your thesis that meal prep-style cooking is the only way to save money while cooking at home. What you need to be able to do is make a large variety of dishes from a few simple ingredients. For example, rice can be made with black beans OR a spoon of curry paste and some coconut milk (which freezes excellently), throw in a can of chickpeas and you've got an excellent curry. Maybe make roast chicken tomorrow (another excellent freezer staple) and throw that into tomorrow's leftovers. Then make burritos on day 3. There's all sorts of ways to mix and match ingredients, prepared foods and leftovers to get a varied diet on a budget at home.

text:
Most of the food eaten by cows is inedible to humans. About 30-50% of the feed that cows get, is upcycled from byproducts that was used to feed humans, and around 80-90% of feed is completely inedible to us. Things like corn husks, byproducts from soybeans, or almond production. This is also more environmentally friendly, because it is better for the environment to have it upcycled to cows, than composting or taking space in a landfill.

Ideally, cattle should be used as apart of a crop rotation, so we can lessen the use of chemical Fertilizer, and allow soil to reabsorb the precious nutrients that we take from the soil to produce our own food. Cattle farming isnt a waste, it is necessary and critical part of creating a closed loop system for food production. The worst thing you could ever do is get rid of cattle farming, and try to create an entirely vegan system.

Edit: eating rice with beans creates a complete protein. By themselves they are not.

text:
You don't have to eat the same thing every night on a low budget. Your variety is restricted by how much you can acquire within the scope of your budget before things go bad, but within that you can mix and match. The colored bell peppers are $3 for a three pack at my local Aldi. Learn how to store vegetables correctly (for most things this involves supplying moisture, e.g. a damp paper towel wrapped around the stem). For my money, a minimalistic side salad or a bit of fruit goes much further in making me feel I've had fresh food than aromatics that melt into the dish and are easily substituted from the spice cupboard.

Kroger is not as bad as some other regional brands, but generally speaking, the mainstream full-service grocery store is usually one of the most expensive options.  In addition to Aldi and Walmart, some regions have programs where SNAP recipients can increase their buying power at farmers' markets (you can buy a token worth $5 for $3 in SNAP or something like that), as well as food bank mass produce distributions which may have more generous income limits than the food pantries do. Speaking of SNAP I imagine many of your audience are singles with what not too long ago would have been considered perfectly decent early-career incomes, now straining under inflated rents, so their total incomes may be too high to qualify - but everyone should double-check this regardless, because you might be surprised. The formula they use to determine eligibility is complex, and ends up encompassing more people than those of us who grew up middle-class and unfamiliar with assistance programs might assume.  

Stop using "poor" to mean middle class and "rich" to mean "upper middle class" like some clueless suburban teenager - refrigerator notwithstanding, I don't think you actually qualify as rich (resale value is a cruel mistress!) and I seriously doubt you were ever actually poor. That said, I totally appreciate you taking this on. There's a lot of frugal cooking channels on YT but they tend to be very "standard American diet" oriented, with offerings that look like a counsel of despair to us downwardly mobile types who were raised to care what we eat. The number of people who are culturally middle class, but economically poor or near-poor, is exploding. Why not look up USDA family food budgets and see if you can make them work with your style of cooking?

text:
I know there's an ongoing discussion about over-reliance on recipes, and this one is simple anyway, but just in case anyone is coming back here looking for one:

# Ingredients
- [ ] 1 lb dried black beans
- [ ] 1 white onion
- [ ] 1 bell pepper
- [ ] White distilled vinegar
- [ ] Sugar
- [ ] Spices (Garlic powder, cumin, oregano)


# Instructions
1) Soak beans in hot water
2) Dice onion and start frying in some oil (looked like a tablespoon or two) at the bottom of large pot (Adam used a Dutch oven, but a stockpot, or even a slow cooker will probably work)
3) While the onion is frying, Dice pepper and add to the pot
4) After a while (I guess once the onions have some color) dump the (now softened) beans in the pot. You can include the soak water or drain and add fresh water. Add water to cover everything and boil.
5) Cook until beans are soft. Err on the softer side, they'll firm up as they cool and with acid.
6) Add vinegar, sugar, spices, salt. This is all to taste. Whatever you like, put it in the pot.
7) Serve as-is, with rice, or any way you like.


# Personal Notes
- Beans freeze pretty good. If you make too much just freeze the extra, it'll keep.
- You can probably use small red or pinto beans instead of black, if you prefer. I can't promise the color of the final dish will be super appetizing.

text:
I cook dinners that are large enough to feed me and my 2 grown kids (18 and 20) for 2 nights.  We eat Saturday's leftovers on Monday, Sunday's on Tuesday, make something in the crockpot on Weds to be eaten on Weds and Thurs and then a "kid" cooks something simple for Friday.  It makes my weekday evenings so much easier and let me tell you - it's so nice to get home on Mondays (the hardest day at work) and know dinner is just a few minutes away.  

When I plate the 1st night of meals, I portion out the extra into 3 realistic servings.  Any leftovers after that are frozen in "lunch size servings" for my son or I to eat for our lunches, along with a side of fresh vegetables and other items.  He loves having a "hot main" for lunch and this ensures leftovers are eaten in a timely manner.  

Having an always-hungry and not-picky 18 year old in the house has really cut back on the food waste.  This morning, I cleaned out the produce drawer and oven roasted anything that looks "a little weird", thinking it would be a good "side" for my lunch.  My son served himself some, mixed a little shredded cheese into it, microwaved it for 30 seconds and called it "veggie nachos."  Okay!

text:
‚Äã@tfrtrouble "can only get a crappy low paying job" 

Why? What is stopping them from advancing from a crappy low paying job to a crappy job that pays reasonably well? Most people do. Only 1.1% of workers earn minimum wage. The median US hourly wage is $19.24/h. That's not much money, but it certainly is enough to escape real poverty.

"As long as they work really really hard, then thanks to the magic of hourly wages, they will earn as much per hour they put in as someone whose rich daddy pulled strings to get them a high-paying job."

Nope they definitely won't. Connections do matter and life isn't fair. Daddy won't live forever, though, and if nepo baby really does suck at their job they'll be fired. They can squander their position fairly easily if they're not at least somewhat competent. 

At the end of the day, working more hours does generally yield more money, no matter what sort of job you're working in. 


"there is no excuse for anyone to think they are trapped in poverty. "

There are plenty of reasons for people to think they're trapped in poverty. Thinking that working hard is pointless isn't going to help them escape poverty, though.

text:
Whilst I do agree about meat generally being fairly expensive, I wholeheartedly disagree about the fact that it is bad for the environment. Go and look at the video by What I've Learned titled "Eating less Meat won't save the Planet. Here's Why", it is a great breakdown by an actual expert in the field. The idea that meat is bad for the environment is propagated by people like Netflix and started way back in the 60s or 70s. The fact is that many of your proteins in legumes and the like cannot be absorbed by your body the same way as from meat. We are made to be omnivorous, our bodies are geared that way, that's why we don't have extra stomachs like a cow. Eating meat is an incredibly effective way to get both proteins and many vitamins. 
Additionally, most grazing that cattle and sheep use is not arable land, so you're not taking away land that could be farmed for something else. In my country, the best sheep and lamb meat comes from an area that is semi desert, where you couldn't grow other crops due to water scarcity, but the sheep have no issues eating the local scrub, with the bonus of making the meat taste amazing. Same goes for cattle, they can graze in rocky areas, or on slopes too steep to farm, making productive land out of otherwise un-farmable land.
Don't lose sleep over encouraging meat consumption.
Even better, encourage cooking of cheaper meat cuts to get the benefits of having meat in your diet.

Otherwise, thanks for the straightforward video and generally sparking my love for cooking with your channel over the past 5 years. You got me through COVID with good food!

text:
Yeah, restaurants do tend to make more food as they have a much larger number of people that they need to feed in a given day.  Making meals for one person can be a bit tricky to make economical, but keep in mind that you can cook a bit more and then reuse stuff for other meals.  If you use a quarter of an onion to add to a hamburger for lunch, you aren't going to throw out the rest of that onion.  But you will definitely want to try to meal plan or meal prep to try to make it easy to know what your next meal will be and to make sure that you go through the ingredients that you have.  In addition, you want to get a permanent marker which you can write and track the purchase dates of some of your ingredients to make sure that you are minimizing food waste.  Some bits of vegetable trimmings, toss into a bag in the freezer and when you have enough, you can toss them all into a crock pot with a bunch of water to make your own veggie stock.  My girlfriend would also buy a rotisserie chicken for one meal.  Leftover chicken meat would be then used for something like tacos.  I know that she had like 4 or so different ways to reuse the same chicken into the next meal.
I also know that you touched on this too, but yeah, eating a whole food plant based diet does tend to be cheaper.  We did do this for a while, but if you lead a pretty busy lifestyle, you might not have the time to make something using whole foods and might end up eating something more pre-packaged, as it tends to be quicker and more convenient than making all of your own stuff from whole foods.  By whole foods, I do mean using as many things you buy that do not come in a box with a list of ingredients.
Also keep in mind that the more something is processed, the more it tends to cost to buy.  If you go to the produce department of an American supermarket, look at how much they charge to buy a package of sliced watermelon versus how much it costs to buy the whole watermelon yourself.  It costs way more to buy the stuff pre-sliced and then packaged than if you buy a watermelon and slice it at home.

text:
1 lb chicken breast, 1 lb of asparagus (honestly half this is fine, but you ain‚Äôt getting that low in bundles), 10 oz cherry tomatoes, box of penne, pesto. 15 dollars in total to make 4 decent portions of chicken pesto. Cube the chicken, saute the asparagus after cutting them into 1/4 inch pieces, and cut your tomatoes in half and once you‚Äôve cooked the chicken, you‚Äôll saut√© the asparagus in oil (I have avacado oil cause my roomate bought a bunch) and then you mix it all together with the pesto and penne. Very easy, you can pack it for lunch, tastes great and is roughly 4$ per meal. And you can probably go even cheaper with store brand pesto (if that‚Äôs a thing), or penne. 

Just thought I‚Äôd share, I‚Äôve been enjoying finding new, cheap meals to make :)

text:
Sooo... and this might be out of hand and I apologize if it is... what you're saying is you spent a LOT on a new fridge and will be eating beans until your budget recovers? Mood. also, I should prep some beans while I'm thinking about it. Might not be THE most economical, but I like to pre boil a bag of beans, freeze it on a flat tray then break it up and put it frozen in a freezer bag. Then when I want to add beans to something (soup, ramen, rice, barley, other stable grain or soup concoctions) I can just pull out some pre boiled beans that have been frozen, and not have to do the whole cooking process for it. It helps with cutting down on food waste for one person meals, and when I'm exhausted.

 Spices are so essential for preventing food boredom, and even if they're a bit expensive (8 bucks for a six ounce jar of tandoori masala curry spice? which turned out to have no discernable taste difference from taco seasoning...  oh dear) a little goes a long way. also some basics can be pretty affordable and used in more ways than you expect. I got a little container of 'poultry seasoning' from the local DG for like, a buck... it's basically rosemary and thyme? not like super high quality but not bad either... and i do use it for considerably more than poultry.

text: So I‚Äôve been unemployed for nearly two years. I‚Äôve done hundreds of job applications and had dozens of interviews and I‚Äôm never quite the person they are looking for. It‚Äôs incredibly frustrating, and the rejection is horrible. It‚Äôs also drained my savings completely. One bright spot is that I found a mutual aid group in my neighbourhood that runs a food co-op. Every week I can pay ¬£1 for a week‚Äôs worth of groceries, which is mainly just expiring food from local restaurants and grocery stores. It‚Äôs so much better than the food bank, where I am limited to one trip every two weeks, which is hard when what they give you is very meagre. The co-op was set up during the pandemic and it‚Äôs a finely tuned machine these days. If you are concerned about food poverty in your area and have some time and resources to volunteer, please consider setting up a co-op in your area (and please don‚Äôt have a means test, it‚Äôs always so humiliating. If you are finding and distributing expired food, just let anybody have it because otherwise it will go to waste). Also the money collected at my co-op goes towards supplementary supplies such as hygiene items and spices.

text: 9:00 I know you try to be conscious of social equity but I have to disagree. I don't think food should be a reason for people to work harder and climb the capitalism ladder. For years now, we've produced so much food that the majority of it goes to waste. Something like 40% of our food in the U.S. just gets sent to landfills while still perfectly edible, where it produces methane gas which is terrible for climate change. Capitalism does not have incentives to give that food to people who need it, and it does not have incentives to send that food to compost where the energy in those foods can be recycled into new foods. People should not have to work harder for better food, we should be giving that food to people instead of thunderfucking our planet into climate catastrophes.

text:
Fun fact; when microwaving water, you can "super-heat" it.
The result is a cup full of water that's over its boiling point, but hasn't actually started boiling yet.
When disturbed, it all boils at once, creating an explosion of water and steam.

Startled the absolute shit out of me when I was making tea. Glad I wasn't standing in front of the microwave when it happened.
Electric kettles are the way for me now.

text:
There are so many (or at least SOME) comments made in this video that twists me as weird.

Like, commenting how our economic system incentivises people to "just work harder" or "smarter" in order to get more money as allegedly a good thing, when it's heavily evident that no such law or system in America even encourages or allows that. This feels glaringly inaccurate to be told such a thing. You work harder, and you end up losing more money than you earn, simply because you put in more effort at no extra benefit or income. Working smarter either involves a lot of time and/or money invested, and the only more "viable" way to work smarter in America is nepotism. That's the biggest problem behind America's economy and its job markets. And yes, I get it, it's a pessimistic take, but that's a lot about what America *is*.

And let's not pretend that America's notoriously car-centric infrastructure doesn't exist, which basically means you have to be earning more money to maintain your car, even if you are regular at keeping it in shape. And in some states, jobs aren't always within reach, even for driving.

I also get that buying in bulk is very expensive in the long run, because food waste is insanely detrimental, but a $14 salad bowl feels like it's a weird thing to have: the pricing of food, itself, is already inflated as it is, and so is eating out, like how eating out always has been.

text: I don't see a contradiction here. Think of it like a crappy broken ladder; some people can climb all the way from poor to rich, but it takes a huge amount of luck in addition to the work. Most people who try to climb it end up falling back down. In a better system, people at the bottom of the ladder would be treated better, and people who try to climb it would be rewarded more for their effort and less for their luck. Adam is saying he's grateful to have a ladder at all, and he wishes it was less broken.
author: @hypertexture5034

text:
@hypertexture5034¬† That's a pretty tortured metaphor, but let's go with it. 

We need to change some things, though. 

First off, the bottom of the ladder is in the water- you climb or you die. You climb or your children die.

Second, most people never ascend far enough to not feel the water- some stay in up to their necks, others are lucky enough to just have a toe in- mostly safe, but never so far up as to forget struggling to not drown. 

Third- and this one is important- those who escape are no longer standing on the ladder- they are standing on the backs of those still on it. Some are content to stand on just a few, others spend their lives moving further and further up while more and more pile up below them.

And finally, those standing on top? They've learned that their life is better the way things are than if they had to stand on that ladder ever again, so they are actively sabotaging the ladder- the ladder is crappy and broken not because it must be, but because they keep it so.

Some of us look at this and say why not stop putting people on ladders and instead use that wood to build a boat that lifts everyone up.
author: @loopgru

text:
‚Å†¬†@loopgru¬†‚Äã‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å† Thanks for extending the metaphor! I suspect we don't disagree on what a good world looks like, or which things most urgently need to change.

I think an ideal and just economic system can still have incentives for hard work, and I don't think that's incompatible with criticising the extreme and arbitrary unfairness of the current system. But we can disagree on that point; my claim is actually just that it doesn't require cognitive dissonance. It's a normal difference of opinion.

The part which threw me most was actually when he said "the fact that it sucks to be poor is by design" and goes on to imply it's positive. Like, this is clearly a very bad thing? You can reward effort without punishing (or as you point out, killing) people for being poor. People don't need to be manipulated into wanting better lives, they already want that.

text:
@  Because, and this is the fundamental misunderstanding all of you have, the ladder is not a particular system, it‚Äôs human nature, or rather, human greed. In a Capitalist system, those standing at the top sabotaging the ladder are the Oligarchs, the ones with, well Capital. That‚Äôs all well and good, we know that already, assuredly.

The problem is, switching from Capitalism to another system, let‚Äôs say Communism like the old Union, is not getting rid of the ladder, it‚Äôs painting the ladder a pretty shade of red and calling that progress. And instead of the Oligarchs with Capital at the top sabotaging the ladder, it‚Äôs now instead the Vanguard Party with Political Power whom are sabotaging the ladder. 

I mean, we have well documented proof of this, from the secret wars of the Presidium, to the bickering between the Soviets and Chinese, to the fact that the majority of people whom had to live under Communism in Eastern Europe really don‚Äôt want it back? 

Or, casting your eyes further East, you can see how Communism can be used as a disguise for a system somehow combining both the worst traits of Capitalism and Communism in the modern CCP, where the guys standing atop the ladder are both the Vanguard Party whom have Political Power and Oligarchs with Capital, the only difference is that the Vanguard are also the Oligarchs at the same time, and they have a lot more guns than the American Oligarchs. 

Hell, even my home country of Vietnam suffers from the same thing, we pay lip service to the ideals of Socialism, but frankly? Americans have more social security and support networks than us. And yes, I know how bad things are over there, so that should probably put into perspective just how terrible things are over here, or in China. Add onto that the fact that we inherited both the shadiness of old Imperial China as well as the Russian vranyo traditions and you have a ‚Äúboat‚Äù that looks a hell of a lot more like a boardwalk. 

Hell, I can even point you back to a time in Vietnam‚Äôs history, what we call Th·ªùi Bao C·∫•p, where true, completely equal socialism was tried... and it proved to be a time almost as disastrous as the famine of 1945-46. That‚Äôs what happens when you try to build the boat ‚Äî crafty, ambitious, unscrupulous people will start poking holes in it so other people sink down, pushing them up. 

To the ‚Äúsome of us‚Äù who are trying to solve the problem this way, I don‚Äôt blame you. It‚Äôs incredibly noble what you‚Äôre trying to do, but the problem is our species, and our reality as a whole, is an ugly one. Equity, egalitarianism, equality are beautiful things, and so they are nearly impossible to have, and certainly impossible to maintain. 

A far more feasible solution, at least from what I know, would be a system similar to Western Europe or the Nordic countries. They have their fair share of problems, yes, but they seem to be closer to cracking the code than anyone else. They are certainly further along than the Soviets ever were, and probably closer to proper Socialism than we or the Chinese will ever get.

text:
Im 28 with a wife and a kid. Im the only member who gets paid. Id say relatively my salary is average. It usually lasts up until I get benefits and the next salary. What I learned about this world that its mostly luck. You have been dealt a situation you have no control over the only thing you can control is your response to the environment.

The best thing about all of this is that everyone has the option to better their conditions. I cook like Adam 2-3 times out of the week. The rest is survival meals. You really can spice something cheap up so much that it isn't considered cheap meal anymore. But you have to live with the fact that money is considered evil because if you have a lot of it you lose some of the life lessons that make you better yourself rather than buy it. Yes going out is fun but its the most expensive. Take out is fine sometimes. But doing everything by yourself baking bread making sauces for later use doing meal prep and so on can balance spending. If you do things in big batches that can be stored well its cheaper and when you have to you can use them as ingredient or as a whole meal.

We all need to experience good and bad and we have to make a decision on being in the middle as always because that will be the most successful road we can take.

text:
I didn't know it was a weird or undesirable thing to eat the same meals for most of the week. I generally pick out what I will have for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, then make it ahead as much as possible (e.g. make a gigantic quantity of soup or curry). Monday is a pretty busy cooking day for me, but the rest of the week it's just reheating stuff for the most part. It massively simplifies the grocery shopping too; I don't like to have a grocery list the size of "War and Peace". I generally keep it below 25 items.

On the weekends I'll make some different things. I didn't know that most people didn't do this until I had mentioned it and people made disgusted faces, as if I told them I ate earthworms for dinner.

text: I eat better than every single person I know.  I cook every meal.  I cannot FATHOM spending $14 on a single meal or even a days worth of food.  My fancy meals cost around $4 and my normal-but-still-better-than-everyone-else meals cost closer to $2 per meal.  Expensive cooking happens for those who cook for clout, not those who cook to eat well.  I cannot even eat out anymore because it is always disappointing.  Who pays top dollar for disappointment?  And I disagree with the premise of this video, that economics is a significant factor of eating well and interesting (for this audience, anyway).  In America, it is far more a matter of knowledge and culture that effects the effectiveness of one's diet.  This morning I ate freshly made egg noodles in a chicken and cream sauce with wild mushrooms and nettle sprouts.  It took me thirty minutes including creating the noodles, and I have 3 servings of noodles left to use.  Never had to get out of my pajamas.  The entire meal, including the gas to cook with and the feed that sustains my chickens for fresh eggs, was around $4 for that serving(and honestly it was probably 2 normal-people's servings).  It requires people to learn from teachers that aren't complacent in their opulence and using the plethora of resources that are at your fingertips that you might not even know are there.

text: Best way to get economies of scale while still enjoying variety is to explore foods that are conducive to transformation. Think of every night in the kitchen as your own personal episode of Chopped! Cook a whole chicken or just buy a rotisserie chicken for $7. Make some sides. Have dinner for two, make tacos with the little bits of meat that are left the next day. Boil the carcass, use the broth and the final bits of meat to make soup. Three dinners right there, none of them anything like each other.

text: I'd be interested to see an exact breakdown of "all-in" costs including energy used, amortized appliance cost, additional floor space cost for a kitchen, labor, etc. I have a sneaking suspicion that even the most basic home meals aren't much cheaper than the $10ish starting price of eating out when you actually account for everything. I think the world has flip-flopped and kitchens are actually now a luxury, whereas eating out is the cheap option for those who lack time/money. We're not fully there yet but I could see housing with community kitchens or no kitchens catching on and reasonably healthy/cheap options like Factor becoming the new standard "staple" for lower classes. There was a company called Maple in NYC a while back. It was basically a local meal prep kitchen set up wherever real estate was cheapest and then they had couriers that delivered the meals. They did it all in house. No DoorDash and no cloud kitchens. Guess it didn't work out but I love the idea of delivery-included low-cost healthy meals. I think a single company controlling everything from prep to delivery makes a big difference in quality and customer experience too. Something like that could probably work today.

text:
Advice, because of the goodwill and affection you've earned with me over the years:
1.  Stay out of economics, politics, morality as long as you are primarily a cooking channel; it's not a good look and takes you far, far out of your wheelhouse.  (Occasionally disagreeing with you in one context, that you're actually somewhat knowledgeable in, is all my wife and I can take and maintain a friendly regard that makes us watch your channel; adding many other vectors of disagreement, especially in areas that did not make you beloved or famous or successful, is a compounding disaster.)
2.  Eating frugally isn't some great sacrifice, don't tell people to feel bad about being motivated to learn what's healthy and develop skills that will make them and their loved ones perfectly healthy for +100x times less money.
3.  In your refrigerator example, the choice that makes you seem crazy isn't the expensive refrigerator (most poor people can imagine spending a lot of money if they have it to spare), it's the fact that you couldn't even imagine (in your discourse about your experience) having a refrigerator that didn't like up basically flush with the area provided for it, to the point where the choice was to replace it with a very expensive refrigerator or to remodel your cabinetry.
4.  You are out of touch, you're just dealing with it in the entirely wrong way.

That said, I understand that you're just a guy.  I hope you keep doing all right and keep forging your own successful path in your life, I'd just selfishly like to see your parasocial business continue to flourish in the context that I first encountered you.  Thanks for keepin' it real.

text: I understand where he's coming from, to a degree (referencing his quote around 9:00). I really work to cook efficiently / do meal prep / use what I have in my pantry & fridge to the fullest before I grocery shop again. A lot of rice n beans, a lot of pasta with veggies blended into the sauce, etc. Very little dairy and excess snacks besides popcorn and chips and salsa. I look to the recipes of cultures (including my own) that made a lot of good food with very little to work with. It can be done. The money I'm saving per month by doing this is pretty decent. I've learned to cook my whole life and come up with OR reference recipes that work in under 20 min and with little to no crazy expense. Meat can be a real budget killer unless it's ground, I've seen, so I usually just get that when I'm eating out. It's possible, but it takes a lot more work, and some people who need to work more hours (for less pay, probably) just do not have the energy and time, to no fault of their own.  For me, the incentive is just saving money each month, in whatever way I can. With that number shrinking though due to rising costs of everything, I can understand it's probably a moot incentive after some point

text: It can be, although it entirely depends on where you live and your schedule. It tends to proportionally be cheaper to eat out in dense urban areas because they service so many people that they operate at a scale of high efficiency and space for a kitchen tends to be very expensive. Cooking for a single person in a high CoL urban area is expensive and a terrible way to get variety in your diet. Conversely, eating out in most other places tends to be proportionally more expensive since they cater to a smaller number of tourists or special occasions and home kitchens are more standard.

text:
Instead of the fancy fridge or hiring a cabinetmaker(!!) - you could simply buy a reasonable refrigerator and leave a gap. It's a spot for your brooms and mops. Done.

This is precisely what we did in 2004. Inexpensive, rugged over/under fridge. Icemaker in the freezer because not only is in-door ice much more prone to jamming and breaking - it adds hundreds to the cost and generally means worse efficiency. The fridge was noticeably smaller than the slot. 20+ years later, nobody has died from the gap, and we still keep brooms/mops there. Around 2010 I did upgrade the situation by adding a wall rack which grips the handles.

text:
11:30 because it‚Äôs such a large and organised system I actually find that many of my staple meat picks are  a LOT less expensive per unit of weight than many to most veg, sauce and accompaniment options, let alone a lot of the pre-made convenience items or ‚Äúbuy now use yesterday‚Äù perishables. 

An example, I like me a pot roast. The meat will be 5-10 per kilo, the potato/onion/pulses/carrots 1-2 per kilo, the stock/spices 5-50 per kilo (but used in fractional amounts), so far so expected. Now let‚Äôs plate that basic meal, the greens, the reds, the occasional purple and the fancy mushrooms are often pushing 10-25 per kilo, the bread is probably 2-15 per kilo depending on choice, optional cheese 5-20 again per choice, anything salad is a exorbitant prices (to the point I basically buy pre-made or skip it entirely now for some windowsill cress and only buy salad leaf for specific recipes) 

All together those meat options at 4-10 can be pretty vital to the overall and especially so if you go from cheap boned cuts for one type of meal (roast/topping/side) and apply the bits not eaten/used there into a soup or impromptu stock/stew base (disposable bags for stewing are possibly my best kitchen investment beyond a decent heavy knife)

author: @KAZVorpal

text:
Hold on, you just said the adding acid will make the beans firmer. 
In the sense that you clearly meant it, this is not true. 
Acidity will make beans firmer in the sense that they will not continue to soften, 
but it will not make beans that are already soft more firm. 

So you should cook them to the firmness level you want, not past that point and then count on them becoming more firm again. 

The acidity will make only the very surface of the bean slightly more taught, but will not increase the firmness of the inside of the bean, at all.

text:
The idea that meat is a secondary product, is a fallacy. 
In reality, most of the plants that meet animals eat is not fit for human consumption, and can be produced in a fraction of the amount of space required to make plant products that are indeed fit for humans. 
In fact, animals are a more efficient system for turning undigestible material into the most nutritionally dense, healthy food for humans.
Even when it comes to carbon footprint, per calorie lettuce has a much larger carbon footprint and bacon, and tomatoes then steak.

author: @forrestwentworthii1321

text:
No, you can't just eat beans and rice all the time and have a healthy supply of protein. Part of the reason is digestability. 
You actually are only able to absorb, if you are lucky, about 50% of the protein in beans and rice. Not only is the human body not designed to absorb plant protein, so that it does it inefficiently, but both beans and rice are designed by natural selection to block the absorption of their proteins. They contain things like phytates, oxalates, fiber, and in the case of some plants tannins, that prevent protein absorption.
The rest is wasted, . 
The protein and nutritional density of beans and rice is also much lower than in animal products. Therefore you probably will not end up eating the double the amount of beans and rice that you need to get enough protein, so you end up being low on protein, overall, if you don't eat animal products with it.

text:
I think my best trick for making sure I'm not eating the same budget meal for 5 days straight (ok, it's really only 3 days worth with my husband around) is recycling the leftovers into something else. Beans with rice one day, mashed potatoes another, in breakfast burrito with some egg and the leftover rice on another, with chopped weenies the last day... just because the package has two pounds of food in it doesn't mean you need to prepare it all in one go.

Getting creative helps too, learn what substitutions you can make if you like using recipes. I have one very amazing cookbook and it's a great reference and starting point, but I believe all the times I've used it, only once have I ever made a recipe to the letter without any substitutions. It calls for cream, I have milk. It calls for shallots or red onions, I have cooking onions. It calls for fresh peppers, I used jared fire roasted red peppers, it calls for a specific cheese, I use what I've got in the fridge.
