text:
It's not just cooking itself, but the foods you choose to cook. The cheapest way to eat requires maximizing whole foods, limiting things pre-prepared, pre-packaged, and ultra-processed. The more physical work and prep you have to do the less money you'd have to spend on the meals you cook. What's also required is limiting the bigger expenses like meat, dairy, and eggs. 

You can keep eating those but they do cost a lot more per macro compared to a wide and varied fridge and pantry full of whole plant foods. Some of the least-well off places eat less meat, dairy, and eggs and a lot more plant heavy meals. The former costs a lot more than it does in more well off places, but plants are even cheaper. 

We put meat, eggs, and dairy in almost everything but if saving money is the goal then they must be limited, it won't limit nutrition just your comfort. That is to say, you can't have your cake and eat it too.

text:
I usually just do beans in the crockpot, no soaking beforehand.  About 4-5 hours on high, 7-8 on low.  I do use meat to flavor my beans, but usually just some salt pork, ham hocks, etc - what would otherwise be seen as waste products.

On the subject of the economics of meat, it's important to note that not all land is arable - not in terms of producing crops that humans can eat, anyway.  And many ruminants can consume food waste products that would otherwise just go into a landfill.  Chickens, goats, and pigs are the most notable examples of this and it's probably not a coincidence that their meat is generally much cheaper than beef (which does require a substantial investment of resources and often uses land that could be used to grow crops for humans.)

I would say we should treat beef, in particular, as an occasional treat.  But its price is trending up to the point that it's going to be seen that way for most folks, anyhow.

text:
Had to come back to this b/c I couldn't stop thinking about the comment about being glad to live in a country that "incentivizes hard work." Assuming you live in the US, that's not true, sadly. Some of the lowest-paying jobs involve perhaps the hardest work (as in labor, with one's body).

We want to convince ourselves we live in a just world, but we've wound up redefining some terms. "Hard work" really means well-connected, white-collar, intellectual work - and even that won't necessarily be rewarded monetarily. 

What we really have is a culture that rewards already having money (money earns a lot of money, maybe more than most people do) and criminalizes poverty. It's capitalism: It rewards owning capital. And it values everything by the market, so that the market gets to say who has a shot at living and who doesn't, and up Maslow's hierarchy of needs from there.

Other than that, this was a fantastic video. I love your videos, especially the way you're so anti-snobbery & encourage people to do the best they can with what they have or can acquire, realistically. So these videos are actually useful!

text:
one thing i like to do for budgeting is meal chaining, as i call it. which is actually just the process of:
1. buying a meat of choice, usually chicken
2. cooking 2 or 3 meals with that meat (for instance chicken parm, chicken curry)
3. cook with the created leftovers which i intentionally made too much of (for instance leftover tomato sauce, rice, chicken, whatever)
author: @isuccnewton2654

text:
Me and my girlfriend rarely go out to eat, usually once a month. So we end up cooking most of the time. We live in the nyc area, which will factor in all this, also I use to work as a linecook in a restaurant + am a fulltime freelancer while she is a 9-5. That said, we spend a gran total of 6-650 a month for all our groceries. This includes:
-Weekly CSA box with seasonal produce and two dozen eggs 54$ (reduces to 30$ when farmers market opens in spring)
-monthly pantry at trader joes 130$
-monthly trip to butcher 160-180$ (this month was whole chicken, 5lbs chicken breast, leg n thigh quarters, picanha, skirt steak, ground beef, beef liver and chorizo
-monthly fish monger 70-80$ (this month 5lbs salmon, 2lbs shrimp)

We eat pretty varied dinners (minus her lunchly meal prep, hence chicken breast). Also have a wine budget, etc. plus i bake bread.
We are also both immigrants fwiw, so grew up being crafty with simple modest ingredients like liver and stock bones for example
Idk maybe this is helpful to someone thinking about shop budget
author: @justinguitarcia

text:
Meal prepping is not only way more affordable but makes it way easier to eat healthier. Cook a large batch on a Sunday that gives you like 5 portions, eat 2, freeze 3. After a few weeks, you've got a variety of meals in your freezer to pick from so you aren't just eating the same stuff 5 nights in a row.

I couldn't imagine cooking from scratch every single night, not only for the cost but the time! Having something healthy to just put in the microwave for a few minutes is amazing. Then on a Friday or Saturday night I'll cook something nicer from scratch, maybe a Ragusea recipe!

text:
There are way too many people in these comments that don‚Äôt get the point behind the expensive refrigerator. He‚Äôs not flexing it, he‚Äôs not justifying it. He‚Äôs pointing out the irony of teaching the audience how to cook economically while spending a stupid amount of money on something that he could have got for 1/10 the price. 

Why did he buy the fridge? Because he could. He‚Äôs easily well into 7-figures of earnings on this YouTube thing and he‚Äôs retired in his 40‚Äôs. He can afford the stupid expensive fridge without facing financial consequences. 

This then spins him into this quasi self aware existential crisis wherein he examines the impact his videos have had on the viewers, the environment, and his own life situation while contrasting the level of effort he put into his success against what the level of effort the vast majority of society puts in  only to receive just a fraction of the rewards. 

You can all make fun of the wasted money on the fridge or try to see hypocrisy in the subject of the video (cheap cooking), but you‚Äôd be missing the point by a mile.

text:
We should talk about meat for a moment, because the off-hand comments about it needing to be a "treat" and "environmentally bad" might apply more to industrial systems of farming, but aren't totally grounded either. Meat prices in this country are affected by the fact that the animal is a secondary product, but we also have a massive amount of monopolization that has driven the prices up in the past couple of decades way beyond where they should be (and put many farmers out of business). It's also worth noting that there are vast tracts of land in the US that are non-arable, but perfectly fine for livestock. 

On the environmental front, we need to continue to promote rotational grazing (and high-density rotational grazing) as a better alternative to the factory farming. This has the added benefit of revitalizing the land the livestock are on. Even better if we can rotate through multiple groups of animals that are complementary. This is not a new notion in farming, but a lot of people tend to laugh it off or disregard it, basically saying that cow emissions are killing the planet or some such garbage. We had millions of bison on this continent and the world didn't end before, having a fractional population of cows isn't the threat people think it is (before we even get into the carbon cycle). Fertilizer runoff is just as bad as any animal product, so what we need are better farming methods that make sense for the land, not less animals.

It's about balance.

text:
It's funny that the implication of this video is that many people in the US don't know how to be poor. And I mean this genuinely. The notion of making as calorie dense of a meal as cheaply as possible to be eaten for days on end only to switch to a slightly different version of the same the next few days seeming so foreign is so far out of my experience it's almost laughable.

The knowledge that beans and rice (not just long grain enriched, though that's a fair one to use if it's all you can do) with a few veg (don't forget canned and frozen! Often more nutritious than folks give it credit for, though it certainly has it's deficits) and a modicum of meat with variety focused in the seasoning being able to get one through nearly indefinitely seems to be lost on many is a travesty. I lived on that for over 5 years and have lived on a more dynamic version of it (featuring more fresh veg content) for more than 10 years and have had doctors ask me if I would allow them to tell others of their patients about my diet plan. It's really not that hard.

text:
Hey Adam, if you still aren't able to sleep well at night, sleep well knowing that you helped me (and I'm sure many other people) to think more critically about what we cook and how we cook. 
I started off cooking not really understanding why I'm e.g. caramelising onions, garlic and ginger before adding my tomatoes and cubed meat etc. It was just something my Mom always did so I just did it not understanding the flavours I'm introducing to the meal and the possible ways I can manipulate the ingredients to enhance or mute certain flavours I like. 
What I do nowadays is basically cooking off of my own built up experience and knowledge acquired from YouTube videos (such as yours) about more scientific/ logical approaches to the basics of cooking. I now have the framework to progress into more advanced and custom dishes (half of the time it doesn't end up as I envisioned but my meals are a heck of a lot more palatable these days). 
I'm truly thankful from the bottom of my well fed belly üòã.

text:
It's amazing and sad how economical cooking seems to be a lost art.
My mother (I'm 61 now) came from a very low income family with lots of kids, and even when married to my father and raising our family - she often made what she called "peasant dishes."
Lentil soups, pea soups, chili's, various pastas - like pasta fagioli were all regular staples in our house.
I myself still cook foods like this all the time.

text:
I will disagree in the vinegar. You most definitely can taste the difference between something like balsamic, apple or distilled vinegar, even in a cooked dish. 

That's part of the reason why you add it near the end (depends on what you're doing).

Anyways, another good way to keep some variety in your cooking without ballooning your costs is meal prep and proper storage. A bunch of veggies and fruit will last for quite a while (weeks or even months) if you store them correctly. There's lots of information online about it, so look up your most commonly used stuff.

Meal prep would be getting your tupperware and jars out and turning some of your bulk ingredients into meal-ready components. Some can go in your fridge while others can go in your freezer and then for when you want to cook, you just mix and match what you feel like at the moment. 

That being said, it's best to do so with a shopping list/ingredient plan. Something like "for this week I have a bell pepper, two onions, a zucchini, some champignons, three carrots, a bit of ginger, a clove of garlic, a bag of mixed nuts" etc. And no matter what you make during the week, at the end of the week the goal is to have it all be gone and not have to throw anything away.

You can easily supplement that with your pantry stuff and spices.

That way you're flexible in your cooking and your choice of carb and protein, but you have a base set of veggies and fruit you can use for a variety of dishes instead of eating the same thing over and over.

text:
I do that as well, and it saves not only money but time. This is because if you're already making a pot of curry, it's not really more effort to make double that and freeze the rest. Sure, you're chopping more vegetables and stuff, but compared to the time/effort of making that whole meal twice, it saves you a lot of time. If I'm making anything that freezes well (e.g. almost any stew/curry type dish) I'll make a portion in the most massive pot I own, eat half throughout the week, and put the rest in a giant freezer bag. Then I can get that other portion out some other week and not have to cook at all.

PS: That potato and bean soup sounds great!

text:
¬†@eccomi21¬† Ragusea was a professor of practice--not a tenure-track professor (TT professors come with the official title of Assistant, Associate, or Professor). So he was much more in line with the salaries of Lecturers and Adjuncts. At my university, where I adjunct, you can expect to be paid about $7000 per semester-long class you teach (and that's actually on the higher end of what I've heard). Most adjuncts teach a maximum of 4 classes per semester, and that would work out to about a 70 hour work week to do so. 

All just to say that while some average TT professor salaries might be around 80k, the average or median salaries for non-tenure track instructional faculty at universities are much lower.

author: @MsZephyra

text:
That may depend on actual job and cost of living. My wife has looked into non-tenured positions and the pay for professors at some of those schools is pretty low. Not poor but but below median income. I just Googled the university she applied to. Median pay is 53k. But that is median. Adjunct professor is about 23k. Median income overall in the city is 56.5k. Median for master's degree is about 89k. This is an area that is on the high end of medium cost of living (some suburbs can be qualified as low end of high cost of living).

If he was stuck in an adjunct position with a fairly light schedule, he could have been struggling. Maybe not below poverty level. But definitely some financial insecurity.
author: @Fidasaind

text:
It may depend. I know in my area, starting salary at local district is 51k (the absolute cap is about 70k. And that is you have 11 years experience, hard to fill position, get full bonus, and have either a doctorate or master's +75 credit hours That is a huge cost and time commitment). Sounds like a decent amount but median home is about 560k and a typical bachelor's degree at the local state school is about 120-125k if you live on campus. But I am sure some states that invest more in education do pay better relative to pay. According to a page on USAFacts, my state is 5th worst for teacher pay relative to cost of living while New York is 50% better. My wife was a teacher when we first got married. She was making about 27k 20 years ago. Adjusted for 67% inflation since then that is just over 45k in today's dollars. For a job that requires a bachelor's degree (and heavy pressure to get a master's within the first 3-5 years).

I realize not all states are this bad. But far too many are. I think teachers are mostly used as an example for low pay based on how the worst states treat them. How low the pay is relative to cost of living, how little their pay goes up despite large investments in their education compared to other jobs, how much invisible work they do (beyond the 7 hours, 180 days per year people see), how much stress they get about testing scores or the difficulty of classroom management with kids that struggle to behave during the day. I doubt people are talking about New York or Connecticut teachers when using them an example of low pay. But Florida, Alabama, and Arizona? Definitely.

And I totally get there are plenty of jobs that are underpaid. Heck, I have an issue any job that is full time work that cannot pay a living wage in the local economy. Or jobs that require advanced degrees that don't pay appropriately to make those degrees (and the time invested to get them) worth it.

text:
Another good way to get vitamins without the cost of fresh produce is looking at frozen vegetables and fruit. They're most commonly flash frozen the same day as being picked, leaving them (when they thaw out) to be at the same quality as when they were frozen. I've found quite a fair few nice packs in my local stores that have a mix of carrot, onion, celery, and red bell pepper which has been huge on saving money due to them lasting half of forever but also because they're wildly cheaper than buying all the fresh produce. I won't pretend like it's a perfect option, as it does still limit you to what's available. However, taking the time to check what's there can (and in my case, has) stretch your dollar value out further!

Also canned peaches and mushrooms go dummy hard

text: I rarely eat out anymore.  What really helps me for eating economically, and keeping it interesting, is using the Chinese food pyramid: three fists of rice, two fists of veggies, and one fist of protein (which becomes more a condiment than a bulk food).  One package of meat will last me 5-6 meals.  And, just by varying the seasonings, and the veggies, and the proteins, I never get sick of eating the "same thing" even though most of it is prepared/cooked the same way (and a wok is MUCH more efficient than preheating an oven for an hour).  Good video.

text: I've grown pretty poor, and I tend to be very frugal because of this - but actually buying an expensive (not 15k expensive, cause that's absurd) refrigerator is a great way to save money in the long run - since the thing runs 24/7 the benefits of better efficiency are magnified. You will not only save a ton on electricity, but also on food - higher grade fridges can keep the temperatures and humidity inside at a very constant level, so your food won't spoil easily, and you can stretch one lettuce to a two week sandwich companion, keep meats fresh for long, and keep some condiments indefinitely. I've spent like 3x the base price for my fridge and I don't regret a single penny.

text:
As a Brazilian, I eat rice and beans almost everyday. 

Tip 1 for cooking black beans, soak it in cool water for 12 hours and THROW IT out. Why? It reduces the amount of phytates and lectins in the beans, which are substances that inhibits the absorption of vitamin C and minerals like calcium, iron, and zinc. If you're worried about nutrition per $, The small calories lost are negligible compared to the benefits. Also it decreases significantly the amount of flatulence caused. 

Tip 2, get a pressure cooker, specially if you're not gonna soak the beans (or throw the water out). Besides decreasing cooking time significantly, it gives a better texture and thicker broth.


Tip 3, salt before cooking, so the salt can penetrate.

text: I'm lucky enough to afford variety if I want, but I notice the cost add up if go out to eat at nice places too often. I always felt like the savings of cooking at home came from the fact that most recipes make multiple portions. A recipe might have, say, 20 dollars worth of ingredients (Accounting for costs on partially-used ingredients like spices is tough), but if you get 4-8 servings from a recipe (especially if you can stretch it with bulk carbs like rice or potatoes and don't mind eating leftovers the next day), then that is only a few dollars per meal. I'm lazy, so making a bunch of food and not having to cook for a day or two is a plus for me. Rice and beans and big pots of soup are my go-tos for inexpensive meals.

As best I can tell if you're dietary goal is to; lose fat OR build muscle you should be on a pretty high protein diet. I long for the days where I can just eat at maintainince and grossly drop my protein intake back to 'normal' levels.

text: I recently had to start being much more mindful about how much I'm spending on groceries, due to personal (and thankfully temporary) circumstances. Basically just wanting to create a bit of a safety net for myself in terms of savings. You start to realise just how indulgent we can be with food, without even realising it. I've actually enjoyed going back to basics and using cheap, staple ingredients, making them taste amazing for a small amount of money. It's surprising just how cheaply you can feed yourself, if you're willing to do the research and find good recipes. Buying and cooking in bulk, and freezing leftover portions, has also been a game-changer. Most weeks I can have a couple night's worth of meals for "free" because they're already in my freezer waiting. Also, having smaller portions for dinner, and stretching a 2-portion recipe to 3 nights, and making up the calories with a larger breakfast and lunch is also good, because it tends to be cheaper to have a larger breakfast or lunch. Buy reduced items that are about to go out of date and freeze them. We have an app here in the UK called Olio that allows people to give away free food (usually it's people who work at a supermarket and bring home the food that has just gone out of date.) I appreciate not everybody can put in this level of effort if they have a had job, or medical issues. But if you can, then eating economically doesn't have to be boring!

text:
One of the biggest things for making home cooking cheap is to really use everything you buy, and generally don't buy if you won't use it all before it goes bad.
The effective cost ratio of a $7 meal won't matter if the purchase cost of total ingredients was $24 and the rest spoils and gets thrown out (an extreme example, most won't be nearly that bad). Finding ways to effectively use less than perfect ingredients is important. Like soups/stews where very long cooking times makes a soft old carrot not matter. Or maybe put in a bit more of something than usual if it makes sure the last bit gets used in time.

Or how a single spice shaker isn't very expensive, but there's a huge amount of them, and if you buy new spices for every new venture, it'll add up, and eventually your kitchen might be crowded with spices you'll take years to use any more than a small selection of.

text:
A dish like Adam is making can feed an entire family.
Extras can be frozen.
Need or want to stretch it further? Serve it with rice - white or preferably brown - that you buy in the large bags and store.
Want to add some meat protein?
Buy chicken breasts - the large pack - separate them and store them in bags in your freezer.
Take one out, cut it up and brown it in a pan.
Add to the beans.
You can apply the same principal to pastas and stir fries.
It's how low income people around the world have eaten for centuries, and it's some of the best tasting of foods.

text: A great way of eating nutritious food at low cost is 1) don't waste anything - make soup with all the bits and pieces in your fridge from leftovers, to a heel of cabbage. Add them to boiling water with one or two bouillon cubes, herbs and spices you have on hand and some kind of fat. It is practically free, very quick and delicious. 2) Stretch your meat by combining it with mushrooms. I use less than half the meat/poultry/seafood that I used to. When I cook meat or poultry or buy a rotisserie chicken, most of it goes into the freezer all chopped up and ready to add to sauce, soup, pasta, stir-fry, curry, etc. When I make a meal I fry up a bunch of mushrooms before adding all the other ingredients. The mushrooms are so flavourful nobody notices that there is less meat.

text:
Adam is a capitalist who is bothered by the way capitalism has gone. What I took him to be saying (you have to factor in what he says directly afterward) is that he abstractly likes the idea of a system where harder or smarter work is rewarded with a wider array of novel experiences but thinks the way our system currently functions puts the threshold for that way too high and so traps way too many people in lives of frugal monotony that they don‚Äôt need to be in.

He‚Äôs wrong, the system he favors is just hopelessly broken if it ever was functional in the first place, but I do get where he‚Äôs coming from. You don‚Äôt want a system where nobody can ever hope for more and so skate by on the bare minimum.

author: @gtothereal

text: ¬†@gtothereal¬†  It really depends on what you mean by that, honestly. First of all, there absolutely are pockets of America that are about as bad as a lot of what we call third-world countries, so ‚ÄúAmericans‚Äù paints with too broad of a brush. Secondly, while the American poor have way higher access to a lot of cheap consumer goods and at least some interface with a modern healthcare system via Medicaid, that has also come at the expense of a lot of what people feel makes life worth living: strong communities, a sense of purpose, etc. Alienation is very bad pretty much across the board right now, and that can make an ‚Äúashes in the mouth‚Äù of a lot of what should be objective advancements in quality of life. My wife is from a much poorer and more unstable country, and while she appreciates the material abundance, she can‚Äôt help but notice how bloodless most Americans really are. Even upper middle-class families are vulnerable to the opioid epidemic, for example, and amongst the poor, it‚Äôs killing something like 100k a year. Basic costs of living are up across the board, such that basic milestones like having a stable place to live or having kids are increasingly unattainable. Something like 1/8 of blue collar men have no romantic attachments, few friends, no kids, etc. It‚Äôs bleak. I think if you listed what a poorer person in America can have to a poor person 80+ years ago, it would sound amazing, but only if you don‚Äôt tell them that it would come at the expense of much/most of what makes their lives feel like they‚Äôre worth living.

text:
‚Äã¬†@auricia201¬†Its the cost of labour: I can make a meal for an hour, or I can work for an hour. That means the "opportunity cost" is the ingredient cost + potential wage I could earn, versus for takeaway ingredient cost + business cost + wage for the guy making it.  

Hence, if you earn more than the guy working for you cooking food, plus business costs, it makes sense. The only exception, that allows for cheaper food, is scale: in basically the entire world, 90% of cooked food ready for you is efficient scale stuff, eg. I can make 300g of batter barely quicker than 20kg of batter frying is fast. 
Ergo, when people can afford regularly food that is not this super quick stuff... there is major inequality. And there is. Adams household is likely in the top 2% of the country, meanwhile for half the populace that 15k fridge is half their wage: Only thats for AMERICANS, for an chinese who made his camera or an indian who made his jeans, that could be 3x their annual wage. Its absurd.

text: ‚Äã‚Äã¬†@FranColeman0¬† I disagree that it's inherently a waste of money decision. In case you're not in the US, a good fridge costs easily $3,000. A basic fridge is $1,500, and a cheap fridge is $1,000. These fridges last anywhere from 3 years if you're unlucky to 10 years if you're lucky, 15 if you're very lucky. A sub zero fridge cost $15,000 but comes with a 20 year warranty from sub zero and if you do cooking for your likelihood having some of the features of the fridge might be worth it. So if you have to replace a fridge twice within 20 years if you're lucky, and each fridge is going to cost $3,000 then your already half the cost of the much better fridge. Yes it's a shitload of money, no I wouldn't spend that, but getting a better product that is going to last is not inherently bad.

text:
This video takes budget cooking to an extreme (which is needed sadly!), but it's not hard to make nice meals budget friendly as well, which I think sometimes people forget.  In general going out to eat these days (or door-dash or whatnot) is just exorbitant costing, and you will almost always save money if you just make food at home and (key here!) eat the leftovers and don't throw food away.  Plan ahead and eat multiple meals off one prep and you'll almost always save money in comparison to going out or ordering uber eats.

Example for a meal recently made at my house.  Made a pot roast a week ago with a nice ($$) chuck roast.  Paid almost $20 for meat alone!  But potatoes/carrots/onions cost was low enough (maybe an extra $5).  Add in a few more dollars for the onion powder/dried parsley/soup mix I used and we're talking say $27 total (probably less, but will use $27 for convenience).  My wife and I had a great first meal off that, including seconds.  We had another great leftovers meal 4 days later.  And I'm about to finish off the leftovers today for breakfast, making a nice hash out of the remaining beef/potatoes/carrots/onions.  So if we say that total cost was $27, 3 meals was $9/ea, divide by 2 for me and the wife and we come out to $4.50/meal.  Not saying that's super cheap, but for a really nice meal?  Delicious, nutritious, far better and cheaper than ordering out.  And I think that's what some people forget - you can save money and still eat delicious meals if you just are conscientious about what you buy and eat the leftovers and don't throw them out.

One more tip?  People always (even Adam here!) talk about eating the same meal for 3-4 meals in a row.  You don't need to do that.  I hate eating the same thing two days in a row.  Most meals will last as leftovers 5-7 days in the fridge.  Make a nice meal, eat it again 2 days later.  Then 2 days after that!  And lots of meals are freezer-worthy.  Toss leftovers in freezer, pull them out in 3 weeks for a delicious, no-work meal.  Learn how to save your food and eat all your leftovers.  Cook food that you know you'll want to eat the leftovers!  Use economies of scale to make a lot of food that you can then save and eat later.  We all have different foods we like to eat.  Figure out some of your favourite meals and then plan how you can make a big pot/pan/mess of it and how you can save it for future meals.

Doing all this?  In the long run, you'll save a ton on both groceries and going out.  Going out is what kills the budget, and if you can avoid going out or ordering in more than once a week?  You'll be doing far better than otherwise.

text:
"you're going to get your methionine elsewhere" this isn't true at all for a vegan, there are no methionine dominant food sources for vegans, it's simply a characteristic of plant material that they don't have much of it, you can look up methionine relative to calorie sources and there isn't a single good source in the entire plant kingdom from what I've been able to find(based on an online table, green laver is your best bet but you shouldn't rely on algae for macronutrients, it's best enjoyed in limited doeses ). you'll encounter a pretty severe bottleneck. I don't think I've ever seen anyone saying "don't worry about pdcaas" showing their work, of course you're gonna bottleneck based on which amino acid is scarce, even when you do classic combinations like beans and rice, it's not like rice has enough of the scarce AAs to make up for the much more protein-rich beans, you're only "completing" the amount of protein that's in the rice, at best. If you have bodybuilding goals I think you should supplement soy, silkworm, pea or mycoprotein powder. 
Yes, you can be fine relying on a vegan diet, and you mention india as an example, but places like india and china also have much higher rates of MONW

text: Not everything has to be fresh, it's fine to buy dried or canned or frozen, it may not provide the restaurant experience in bite and consistency but it's fine to eat. Bulk up your meals with reasonably healthy ingredients that are cheap by the pound. Dried or canned beans, pasta, rice, potatoes. Add small amounts of meat for flavor if you can, don't make it the main part of your entire meal by weight, meat is expensive. Think ahead before you buy ingredients. Do you have a soon upcoming use for the other half of the quantity you're about to buy, can you freeze it for a couple weeks or even months, or would you have to throw it away? I'd rather buy a half pound package of something for two bucks and use all of it, than to buy a one pound package for three bucks and throw half of it away in a week when I couldn't find a use for it. And last but not least, SEASONING IS EVERYTHING.

text: Liked your video, but 2 things.  Your comment that "you could skip the middleman" - eating the plants that a cow eats is NOT equivalent to eating the cow.  The cow has biochemical processes that change the nutritional profile of its body.  Example, grass has no Vit B12, but beef has lots of Vit B12.  Second thing - onion as a source of Vit C.  Sauteeing and boiling onions decreases its Vit C content.  If you boil broccoli for 5 minutes, its Vit C content decreases by 33%.  This is data from a research paper after a couple minutes of googling.  It's not far-fetched to think something similar happens for onions.

text: I really appreciate the take you have there about our financial system. Well, I suppose the incentive structure. As much as many folks rail against capitalism, looking around at some of the alternatives has been disheartening to say the least. At the same time, that does not excuse the past or present state of things in the United States, because things could definitely be better, and just pointing out that they could be worse is beside the point. Also, the whole luxury doesn't mean better/ more useful. That is so incredibly true! Honestly, the single biggest thing that I'm grateful for out of a fancy new fridge is having the ice and water dispenser, that way there's no separate thing that I need for filtering. And ice on demand is amazing, having grown up without it. I truly appreciate it. Now. I also love the trick you do here with showing how to make this one meal pretty darn fancy, while also advocating for the cheap like your shocking secret to vegetable soup. Also, while many folks do not have access to gardening, far too many of us are wasting huge tracts of land to lawn space rather than a decent garden, and it's that time of year! Thank you for all that you do, from the science videos that I use to teach my classes to the recipes that I used to pop a little variety into my home cooking.

text: You could toss some love to Larry Wolf of "The Wolf Pit"  who does a lot of "cooking on a budget" videos.     In the end,  unless you have VERY specific tastes (like Lauren would ONLY eat a salad EXACTLY like that for lunch.....or will eat ONE salad per week,  and she's the only one,  and she won't eat any more until the veggies all rot in the fridge)  EVERY meal is cheaper at home.     No a Porterhouse dinner with au poive sauce is going to be WAYYY more expensive than that lovely pot of beans.....but it will cost about $40 to make at home vs $100 at a nice restaurant.   Same with your pizzas,  even with the energy cost of heat soaking your steel,  a large pizza at home is lower than what you'd charge at the restaurant.      We need to encourage people to invest in themselves,   and eating is one thing we all NEED to do,  and doing it cheaper and being able to stick with it will save somebody HUGE money over time.

text:
About the economy of making pizza at home: don't just make one, make several. Pizza is a great portable leftover food you can eat on the go.

And forget about these steels and stones that need to heat up forever. Get thin pizza sheet pans instead. Prepare the pizza in them and toss them in the oven. The bottom of your pizza will get all the heat it needs transfered from the hot oven around it. And that's the final goal, also with those steels and stones. But it doesn't take as long, you just heat up the oven (the air inside it!), bake your pizza for ten minute, get the pan out and put the next in, done, simple.

text:
I grew up relatively poor. I say "relatively " as compared to other areas of the world we were doing ok. I didn't really notice it as a kid but when I made the jump to adulthood I realized just how hard it must have been for my parents. making money stretch and the amount of work put into food etc.

To this day I can eat baked potatoes with butter every day for an (as yet) unlimited number of days, if there is cheese available as well, probably even longer.  
Not because it was our "everyday" food, it was our treat food. 
Baked beans on toast was our "nothing else available" food (and will probably give away where I am from). I can still eat that and enjoy it but not not that often. 

Now I am not poor eating out is a break from eating at home and a time saver. After living through covid (I think we could all almost agree that the man who invented the dishwasher is up there with the guy who invented excel as a modern hero) I just feel out of ideas for cooking at home. I don't feel like eating at home should be an event every day.

text:
Meat is that expensive because of the demand for it. For instance, if no one ate deer, we'd still have to manage deer numbers, and the meat would have little to no value, and would sell cheaper than beans.
Because the demand is so high, we do all sorts of crazy things to create as much meat as possible. That meat then has to return on that in the form of higher prices.
It really frustrates me that intelligent people believe meat is expensive because we have to grow crops to feed them. We grow crops to feed them because the demand for meat is so high that it's value allows for that.
author: @jluke168

text:
Whether cooking at home will be cheaper will certainly depend on a country you're in. Grocery prices, energy costs and restaurant prices and their ratio to one another will vary A LOT around the world.

For example, that 1.50$ single onion is absolutely insane to me. I don't even know how much onions cost here in Poland because they're so cheap. I'd guess an onion like that would probably be 25 US cents or less.
In Poland, cooking at home was always cheaper than eating out. Some years ago there was a point in time where our wages have risen to a point where your average person could afford eating out just for the convenience of it, or to eat something more fancy. But over the last few years, especially after the pandemic, the prices in restaurants have absolutely skyrocketed, largely due to insane energy costs for businesses, to the point where I barely eat out anymore. It's simply too expensive now.

text:
11:30
This point is incorrect. It's so wrong it isn't even funny.

Good luck eating grass, Goats, Sheep, Cattle all eat grass. You can have livestock on very unproductive agricultural land where growing plants would not be easy.
Chickens and Pigs traditionally ate household garbage, and leftovers. Think wheat steams leftover from threshing, watermelon peels, roots and vegetable stems after harvesting (see how much of the broccoli plant actually gets eaten vs thrown away. Or how we eat the ear of the corn but not the stalk, that would be used as fodder)
So yeah, maybe you can cut the middle man out of the chicken and pork if you ate said byproducts, but we can't eat grass.

And sure, there's an argument to be made about overproducing and overconsuming meat. 
Meat is not just a secondary product that and not always the more inefficient option.

text:
@ 99% of economists never read Marx's work, because it's simply not taught in academia. In the context of Economics - which is avowedly Liberal - the name of Marx is akin to Voldemort's. You are not allowed to speak of him, period.
And you cannot critique something you haven't read. It's like me saying that you're wrong, without ever reading your opinion. That's science (and logic) denial. 

Marx was nothing more nothing less than a Classic Economist, like many other Classic Economists of his time, whom he studied.

i.e: Aristostle was incredibly wrong about a lot of stuff. And yet, Philosophy courses don't treat him like Voldemort. In fact, Aristotle is taught within philosophy, without any problems or regrets... because Philosophy, unlike Economics, actually asks their students to engage with the historical material critically, to dissect it, and to separate the wheat from the chaff. 
For the most part, Economics is literally just an ideological indoctrination program - one that does not have very good predictive capabilities, since "value is subjective lol, and it's impossible to calculate the entire economy lol, so I guess we'll just throw our hands in the air and give up lol". They're like ""scientists"" trying to discover the structure of the galaxy without having a telescope. It's impossible to do it.

Economics is about studying (highly flawed, incomplete, non-predictive) macroeconomic models. 
They have purposefully decoupled the study of Economics from Political Economy, which is why you will never hear a word about Marx, or any other alternative economic models to Capitalism. That's simply not part of their program. And that's by DESIGN. 
In Economics, you're not meant to engage with the economic model critically, but to simply follow some highly complicated mathematical formulas, so you can say you're the only expert in the room whose opinions are infallible.

text:
No, you don't need to eat the same thing for the next couple of days. 
I cook in big batches as well. A big pot of beans, a big pot of Bolognese sauce, big pot of cale or cheesy leek soup, polish cucumber soup, or whatnot.
I eat one plate, and from the rest I will each put 3 ladles into one zipper bag, flatten the bags out, write the date and the content on it and put it into my freezer.
This way, I can cook fresh once in a while or choose one of my older meals from the freezer. Just put the bag into some water to defrost, pour it into a pan, heat it up, ready. A Bolognese goes well over frozen cauliflower if you're not into carbs, some tomato sauce goes well on fresh zucchini stripes that you can create with a speed peeler, cook some rice, pour your defrosted lentil soup from the weeks ago over it, there you go.

Basically portioning big cooks into zip bags and using a freezer is your way to daily variety.

text:
I actually find the best strategy to minimise cost, encourage variety and reduce waste is to write a 7 day menu/ shopping list.

I have a rough idea of what most things will cost me, though I'll also look them up to see if there are specials or price increases. This way my family eats 7 different and interesting things every night under budget. Of course, we have that economy of scale on our side - feeding 3-4 is cheaper than 1 on the same ingredients if you want the same variety and freshness of food. But with this method, I am able to pick a recipe on a given day based on how motivated I am and if anyone has any cravings.

When I've had more money I've been more wasteful, but I've tried to keep this up and have been doing so for a few years now with pretty great success.

Anyway, good video. It's important to know how to cook on a budget and to know that you're unfortunately not alone in it.

text:
I always respect the humbleness and self awareness you're able to keep in most of your videos. There are a few things i'd like to add:

Frozen vegetables mixes are a good alternative to fresh produce at least where i live, it probably isn't all that cheaper compared to an onion and bell pepper, but it has much more variety and convenience. Vegetables with longer shelf life like potatoes(count those as carbohydrates), carrots, cabbage and canned tomatoes are also fairly cheap.

Vitamin C is degraded by heat, so you lose most of it in cooked vegetables. Rather squeeze some lemon juice in your water at every meal, or eat the vegetables raw (I can't do it with onions but bell peppers are delicious).

Most beans and legumes can contain different levels of toxins or anti-nutrients, which inhibit your absorption of vitamines and minerals you eat in the same meal. The reason we soak (and cook) them is to remove those substances, but if you don't discard the soaking water you're still going to ingest them. This is not a problem in a varied diet, and the extra calories and other un-inhibited nutrients might be beneficial to you, but it can lead to nutritional deficiencies if you eat beans every day. The best middle ground for me is to discard the soaking water but keep the cooking water.

I'm not aware of studies that have contradicted these last two points, but if there are any, I would like to know about them.

text:
The "incentivizes people to be more inventive or productive" argument has ironically the same flaw with that the "we need to have as many children as possible because it increases the chance that more Einsteins and Mozarts will be born" argument. If we we gave everyone at least equal opportunity, and if we had enough capacity to support the failures of this system, it would be great. Problem is, not every child born is an Einstein or a Mozart and not everyone has the right mindset (which comes from upbringing and situation as much as anything else) or capacity to be a creative or entrepreneur - or even wants to be. In fact, if we all were, the very system you propose would collapse because everyone would be cranking out bespoke works and the cost would be insane.
In reality, the people you describe tend to start with an advantage of some sort - wealthy or at least middle class parents, a patron of some sort (albeit more common in the past) - scholarships... but when a person is so poor that they have no choice but to work every waking moment, they don't have the bandwidth to worry about being inventive or creative - they're too busy worrying about - you know - making it to the next morning.
So really, if you want the maximum creative and inventive people - the most Einsteins and Mozarts - the best way isn't to run the population through a gauntlet and hope the ones who survive weren't just lucky, or overpopulate the world in the hopes that the ratios work out - it's to build a society with a good basic social infrastructure that allows people the freedom of trying to do risky things safely, and then educate them and incentivize that risk taking.
Which we actually do for the wealthy.
But in the US, the class system divides everyone into the small group of really successfuls and the rest of the people who, since they clearly aren't good enough or work hard enough, aren't worthy of good things and so should be worker-drones who eat the most basic of foods, mass produced and generally not good for them because - they don't deserve good food.
You guys get a lot of that from your founding economy, BTW, when some people were property of the wealthy class and used to do the work the wealthy people didn't want to do. Much of the US mindset with respect to labour still reflects that older mindset while in must of the rest of the western world, it's been eliminated.

text: a couple years ago i was in a deep depression and ate doordash exclusively. i could only "afford" it once every other day, and ended up with a food bill of about 1k/mo for one person. a year or two of that and i started carrying cc debt. last year I decided to go back to eating cheap and well. i make 3 dishes in rotation with an average cost of $0.83/meal. there is a LOT to think about when you tightly control your diet like that. I had to swap out a lot of foods that most people wouldnt think twice about because of the sheer volume and consistency with which I was eating them. anyways, it worked and i no longer have debt but it was an undeniable TON of work that I frankly wouldn't have had the energy for if I worked a more physical job. That's the real cost of being poor; being so exhausted from the excessive amount of work you do that you cannot do all of the /extra/ work required to "get on top of it" again. also pro-tip, don't worry about nutrients when you are first getting started. just take a multi vitamin and make sure you arent eating anything that is poisonous in high quantities. makes it easier to get started. your body will naturally crave foods with the nutrients you are missing over time and you can adjust your recipes to accommodate them. also, designing your menu around your limitations (like depression in my case) adds a lot of complexity, don't be afraid to throw conventional knowledge out the window and do what works for you, even if it isn't optimal. doing something that works for you means you wont abandon it for your old habits as easily when things get tougher. if you dont have time to babysit a pot of beans, just dont do beans. if you know you wont do dishes consistently, focus on one pot meals. etc etc

text:
As a university student in an absurdly expensive city and a new vegan, I'm extremely grateful that my grandma took the time to teach me everything that she knows about cooking - she used to work at a factory canteen, so the cheap, delicious and nutritious style of cooking is what she knows best. I can pretty much survive off of homemade stews, pilafs and casserols, with a simple salad on the side for the vitamins and the fibre. 

Also, something that I really like doing is to make wraps with some sort of vegan protein - beans, spiced tofu, soy chunks, whatever you want. You just prepare everything (the protein, the veg, the sauce) in advance, stick it in the fridge and assemble whenever you feel hungry. They're also excellent as a boxed lunch if you don't have the time to make it to the canteen.

I spend less than $10 a day to feed myself. That's 1.5 hours of the lowest minimum wage in the US.
Tomorrow, I am making breaded pork tenderloin cutlets. Why? IT WAS ON SALE. And it's easy. After I finish the 3lbs of tenderloin, I will buy brisket, which cost $10/lb last week. This week, it is $1.79lb. Why? St Patrick's Day! Corned beef is brisket + salt & spices.
I tried to explain to someone in r/frugal how saving money works, they complained that chicken sandwiches using deli sliced meat cost $8... Buy a CHICKEN for $.99/lb, roast it, stick a a fork in it, you're done.
Poverty in the US is caused by not making good choices. Some people will complain they do not have time to make beans - they will stay poor.
PS: Sort the beans, dude, there are often rocks in dried legumes. And Bugs.

text:
Of course cooking at home is way cheaper. A lot of Chinese, Indian, Mexican and even Italian cuisine is extremely cheap to make. 
Yesterday I made a amazing Pasta with spinach and with 1 pack of Molisana 2$, a pack of frozen spinach 1 $, 100ml olive oil 2$, besel, parcelin, salt and garlic let's say another $ so in total 6$ I made 6 plates of a dish that would probably cost me 8$/plate at a restaurant. And it was also easy to make most cheap food is extremely easy to make. It took maiby 30 min but most of that time was passive time. There are foods that are cheaper in restaurants like Pizza. Not only to heat the oven cost you a lot of energy but the ingredients alone are expensive. 200gr of mozzarella is 3$ so that almost half the prize of a restaurant pizza alone. Restaurants buy mozzarella,flower, prosciutto in bulc so they buy it way cheaper then you can find it in a supermarket but everytime I'm in a Italian restaurant and I see a carbonara, cacio e pepe or a Alllio e olio pasta for 8$ it makes me laugh because I can make that plate for a fraction of the price. Last month I had a party and I made the most lavish and rich curry with rice on earth that cost me maiby 20$ and it fed 32 people. And i also had 2 more portions next day

text: Pretty bad attitude. I've been poor and not poor. If you know how to cook you can eat well on a Very tight budget. If you have a yard or even a good patio you can level up a LOT. Learn how to cut up a whole chicken and turn that meat into several portions. What's left of that chicken goes in a pot with your veggie scraps (onion and celery at least) and you boil it for several hours to make your beans or be the base of a soup or to make a sauce. We compost all our veggie scraps to make rich dirt for growing herbs. I started doing that when I was in a little hovel of an apartment, but it had a patio. Fresh rosemary, thyme, sage, fennel chives, parsley, etc can all be grown in a little window box. some of the most flavorful restaurant dishes are made with cheap meat (pork belly, ribs, whatever goes in sausage...) Exquisite demi-glace is made from scrap bones you might get for free or almost. Indian & Thai is cheap and wonderful. Learn to cook well, waste nothing, live well. Worth the effort.

text: Yeah.  I learned how to cook as an adult and IMHO recipes are kind of counterproductive.  My cooking got much better, and also turned from being a point of stress to just a muscle memory thing i can do while doing other stuff, when i got a few key habits down - more than i should attempt to cram into a youtube comment, but in brief, keep a $30 list of staples (flour, veg oil, butter, paprika, ...) in your kitchen, buy clearance, and own a meat thermometer and a rice cooker.  I'd say to learn substitutions and spice pairings but everybody is carrying around Google in their pockets.  I'm not making any INTERESTING meals but it's surprisingly easy to advance to a level on par with mediocre restaurant meals.

text:
Cooking for myself is something like rice and beans, lentil or pea soup, noodles with some sort of soy-derived protein (tofu is cheap near me), etc., with whatever veggies are fresh and cheap all kinda herded into a complete meal. Fancy cooking is for visiting friends and family.

...but I make enough money to afford both that and rent, and live in an area where "whatever veggies are fresh and cheap" includes a non-zero number of options. (Supermarkets catering to immigrants around here tend to have a lot of produce that's affordable even if it's sometimes not pretty. In a city with enough immigrants, that can mean both pan-continental options like Latin American, Asian and African-cuisine-focused places and more nationally-specific ones. In other cities, or in parts of them, even that isn't really available. And in a household where every adult is working two jobs, even just time for cooking can be an issue.)

text:
I think ethan chlebowski (however you spell that guy's name) had a really great home cooking approach that allowed for decently varied meals by changing up preparation methods for the same sets of ingredients with different spices and approaches. 

But yeah, cooking at home gets more efficient the more food you actually go through. For families that eat a lot I would say it's much more important, as the piddly little meals made by restaurants are rarely sufficient or satisfying, especially at their price point. When cooking for 3 or 4 the meals end up being around 10 dollars a person for really nice high quality meals with no cheap ingredients, but when cooking for one the price feels like it balloons up to 15 or even 20 dollars per meal. That said, after you get going as a cook and understand your own taste buds, you can get so far with really basic cooking equipment. Cutting board, a knife, and something to cook on goes a long way.

text:
Something not taken into account here. People look at more expensive items and have sticker shock at the grocery list required to get the ingredients for the meals they want. You also need to consider the fact that you most likely bought components that you didn't use all of in a meal. Cheese for example is quite expensive. But think how many meals are made out of that one block of cheese and divide the high cost across them. Same with butter.
People often complain about fresh produce being expensive but aside from beans, rice and bread, vegetables are probably the cheapest thing you can buy at the store. You can buy a whole lot of them and make a ton of incredibly healthy meals.
Also, when you are first learning, shop around and figure out where produce is the cheapest. WINCO is our family go to. I've heard people talk about Aldi's and even Trader Joes (Trader Joe's is super expensive in my area). Peppers at our local WINCO run between .60c each to .80c each depending on season. Green usually are cheaper because, fun fact, green peppers are red peppers that were picked before they were allowed to ripen! As you learn your stores, you will learn which items to get where. For instance, I avoid getting tomatoes at WINCO. They tend to be mushy bland pink sob stories and I am willing to pay extra at Safeway to get nicer tomatoes. Avocados are another that I may or may not be willing to get there. Take control of your eating habits and track your spending. Enjoy watching the savings add up, because they will if you keep with it.
Eating out is unquestionably more expensive and usually less healthy.

text:
I would really like to see you recreate that takeout bowl and accurately track cost per portion, because I'm convinced (every time I see that type of dish on a menu, not just that one example) that there are only a couple dollars' worth of ingredients in there.  I can't tell if that one was, but they're usually >50% white rice (incredibly affordable), and I see 1/4 of a cucumber, a couple shreds of cabbage, a 1/4 cup of sweet corn, a tablespoon of hummus (make your own from dry beans, premade hummus is outrageously overpriced), a few sprigs of leafy greens, maybe 2oz. of meat, etc.  I could see buying all the necessary ingredients coming out to $14 but that would make quite a few portions - there's just so little of each ingredient in there.
Maybe I'm delusional and those rice bowls do cost significantly more that I'm giving them credit for, but if that's the case I want it proven so that I can stop getting so upset (at to me what seems to be a grave waste of money) every time I see someone order one.
I'm firmly in the "poor" camp in the context of this video and have to make every dollar go as far as I can.  I never eat out or get takeout because I can't afford it.  I consider myself to have gone over budget if I spend more than $80 a month on groceries, but it definitely does end up being a lot of rice, beans, veggies, and pasta, and never anything ready-made.  I really enjoy your videos and a lot of other cooking and food tourism channels because it gives me the opportunity to see and explore interesting cuisine that I don't have access to myself.
Also, Atomic Shrimp has done a lot of videos on budget cooking (though he's keen to point out that what he does is never a guide nor recommendation for practical daily cooking) and has make videos in which he meticulously tracks the utility cost for running appliances, both gas and electric, and has shown that that cost is quite negligible.  Kitchen appliances just don't use that much energy, even if they are inefficient.
Sorry if this comes across too rant-y, but I feel like I'm taking crazy pills when I see everyone around me (mostly peers and coworkers in the same income bracket) so accustomed to and accepting of the high cost of eating out.

text:
Back in the days when I was broke as shit, I learned the basic fundamentals of cooking by making huge batches of rice and beans.

And now that pure luck has allowed me to stumble upon a degree of wealth that allows me to eat/cook anything that I want whenever I want, I still go back to those rice and beans dishes from time to time. That shit's tasty. A big ladle of nicely-spiced black beans over a bowl of rice? That shit's good eatin'.

It doesn't make the stress of financial insecurity any easier, though. A hearty plate of rice and beans should be happy-time comfort food, not "this is all I can afford to eat" food. I wish nothing but happiness, community, and prosperity to everyone reading this right now.

text:
I have to call out bullshit on some of the meat claims in this video.

11:47 - it is wrong to suggest that we can "skip the middleman" in terms of not keeping animals for food, because many of the herbivore animals that have been with humans for thousands of years as livestock eat plants that we cannot eat, such as discarded hulls from cereals, grass, weeds and things that grow on soil that cannot reasonably support human-edible crops. Inhumane factory farming is a travesty, but so is vegan maximalism. Livestock is also an important part of agriculture because cows, aside from converting inedible plants into edible beef, also convert the plants into fertilizer. Topsoil erosion is a real thing (according to some, like Freeman Dyson, a bigger contributor to global warming than CO‚ÇÇ) and it doesn't help to grow more plants using more artificial fertilizer (made from fossil gas!!).

14:39 - it's not that beans are deficient in some amino acids, but rather that plant proteins don't break down into peptides as easily as animal proteins. Even highly processed plant protein (which theoretically should cut through the fiber and make the protein more readily available for the body to absorb) is much less soluble than animal protein, which means that you have to eat quite a bit more to fulfil the dietary requirement for protein.

text:
I'm watching this in my tent on a mountain near Orgiva, near a "hippie" communal house, where yesterday we cooked a big pot of curry for everyone (with rice and beans), from unsold food at the market. I helped the vendors to pack, and got onions, tomatoes, peppers, celeri, melons, oranges, etc., put it in crates in a big circle where everyone around put the unsold food they got, we held hands in a big circle, sang a song, and picked what we wanted, with an abundance for everyone, with enough leftovers for others. We then hiked up the mountain to this little paradise, and invited the friends we saw along the way. We cooked, played music, sang, and ate such a filling, good meal, very similar to the one showed in this video, but with more variety of ingredients. 

I understand that even though I am "homeless", I am extremely privileged to live this way, that it's dependent on this industrial megamachine, at least for the rice, the vegetables are from local market gardeners. It is not scalable. 

But FREE food COULD be a reality for EVERYONE. Urban and local permaculture and food forests delivering food to community and neighborhood kitchens where anyone is welcomed to have a meal. All ran by a mix of professionals and volunteers, the costs shared. 
In France, I was part of an initiative called the food social security, where you contribute 150‚Ç¨ (or not) per month and get back 150‚Ç¨ of food regardless, from local producers that fit the criterias democratically decided by the consumers (permaculture,  regenerative, bio, etc.). 

Food is a BASIC NEED, it should be guaranteed. And of course, healthy and efficient. That means less or no meat when possible. Let meat re-become a luxury product that only the rich enough to want to exclude themselves from this basic food guarantee can afford. Of course, no more subsidies for this destructive industry.

text:
Depending on your budget, you can eat what is pretty much restaurant quality food for way cheaper, but you still have to go for the economy of scale of cooking large batches and eating the same thing for a bit.

You can relatively cheaply replicate a Chinese, Thai or Indian curry or stir fry that tastes as good as most people‚Äôs local restaurant.
You can also make it healthier by adding extra vegetables, which also pads it out so you get more meals out of it.

Or slow cooked meat dishes that use cheap cuts of meat, in a Spanish or Italian or South American style, or whatever style you prefer.

I usually cook twice a week or so and eat delicious food that I don‚Äôt mind eating 3 or 4 days in a row.

It does take a bit of practice and your meals might not be as good as you want right away but over time if you‚Äôre interested in cooking you can learn to make very tasty food on a budget that is massively less than eating takeaway.

You don‚Äôt have to go all the way to beans and rice every day if you don‚Äôt have to be on that tight a budget, but you can keep them in your rotation since they‚Äôre also tasty.

text:
As to the theme, thanks for addressing economies of scale. Communal cooking is hugely more efficient than cooking for 1-few. Cooking for 1 is often way more expensive than cooking for 4 and if you price in the extra effort, one has to get creative to make it work. 

For me, I almost never cook meat at home. I buy pre-cooked meat and freeze it in sizes I can use later. Adding strips of steak to soup, meatballs to pasta. precooked bacon directly into my mouth‚Ä¶. It may cost more/pound but it‚Äôs actually cheaper per serving for me! Now with air fryers? I buy a bucket of chicken, air fry abderving for 5 min while I put the remainder in single serving sizes in ziplocks to freeze. Thaw it by microwaving it until the bag poofs +30sec and toss that mushy mess into the air fryer for 5-7 minutes and it‚Äôs like fresh cooked.

text: When I went shopping this week, I bought a whole 5 lb. chicken for $0.97/lb., because it was on sale.  I smoked that chicken today after spatchcocking it and rubbing it with salt, pepper, garlic powder and paprika.  For me and my wife, that chicken is 8 portions.  I admit that the salad I made to go with pushed my dinner cost above yours, but I could have made, for example, pasta in tomato sauce, and my cost would have come in less.  I don't try too hard to coupon shop, but I do use the apps for my local stores, and when I shop, I will visit up to 3 stores to get the best prices on what I want.  Last week I bought a whole top sirloin cap roast, which was on sale for $6/lb.  I cut a couple Picanha steaks off it, and sealed and froze the rest.  I do the same thing with Tri Tip: I buy the untrimmed mega packs that have 2 whole Tri Tips, trim them up myself, cut them in half and seal and freeze.  I've weighed the trimmings, this boosts the sale cost from $4/lb. to $5/lb. (which is way better than the usual $8-9/lb. for trimmed). I think you can buy higher quality protein for lower prices, but it requires a certain amount of time and dedication, and reports I've seen show that economically distressed people are already using their mental effort to keep their lives on the tracks.

text:
I do want to help you sleep at night, if just a bit. 

Meat production has ethical and systemic concerns, but meat is pretty objectively more anabolic than plant protein-sources.

In ancient Egypt the rich ate a lot more plant protein than in most other societies, and were relatively chubby. Meanwhile, every nomadic pastoralist group in history (literally without exception) has been taller and stronger than average. Even more sedentary cultures who prioritize meat (like those from the far north) have better dental and physical development outcomes than those who eat less meat. East Asian cultures who have started eating more meat have also seen considerable advances in average height since adopting this adjusted diet.

All of these outcomes (and the high average height of hunter gatherers.) seem to suggest that Meat's nutrient density and digestibility make it a source of nutrient humans benefit substantially from. I worry how we could ethically supply enough animal protein and generally digestible nutrient for humanity to reach peak development, but reducing intake has eventually diminishing returns.  


Dairy was a silver bullet solution between the neolithic and now, but industrialism makes villains of us all, I guess.

Orbital pastures, when?

text: It's not like i can't afford to eat out every day, i just feel like it's a huge waste of money that would be better spent elsewhere. And i kinda enjoy cooking and meal prepping. I've devised a "system" for budget cooking: buy shelf-stable foods like rice, pasta, dried and/or canned vegetables and spices in bulk. Then stop at the grocery store on my way home from work, and buy 3lbs of whatever meat is on sale that day. Also whatever fresh fruit/vegetable is on sale, and cook them in a stew, as a stir-fry or as a casserole with some random herbs and spices from the pantry. 3lbs of meat is enough to have lunch and dinner for 3 days in a row, so that's 6 meals for around $15. Then repeat with a different mix of meat/veggies/carbs/seasoning.

text:
Don't feel so bad about the oven thing. Using an oven at 500 for half an hour will only use like 5-6 KWh at most (not accounting for oven cycling, so probably lower). And yes, that's a lot of energy to use over such a short period of time, but you use about the same amount of energy if you cook something else at a lower temperature for a longer period of time (considering pizza is generally cooked quite quickly after preheating). So, the question boils down to "is it wasteful to cook food in your oven?". I would say no, it's not, so long as you or someone is eating the food.

For reference, at $0.16 per KWh it would only cost you about $0.96 to use the oven for 30 minutes. That totals to about $29.00 to make a pizza every day for 30 days.
Also, if we do attempt to account for oven cycling, with an assumed oscillation range of 100 degrees (standard) your oven will probably be cycled off for about 1/3 of the time that you are using it. 
so if we do the math again, that's a total of $0.64 per half hour, and $19.00 per month of daily high power oven usage.

You use more than twice that by accidentally leaving your porch light on all day. 
If you want to save energy, try turning off your water heater when you aren't using it. The oscillation range on water heaters is usually way lower and residential heaters can use up to 4KWh/hour. Even if it's only heating for 1/4th of the time that it is on, that is still using about $3.80 worth of energy per day. That about is $115.00 a month, and how often do you shower every day?

Sorry, that was a bit of a tangent. People talk about energy use a lot while not really understanding it, and while I know it's not entirely their fault, it does bother me when people beat themselves about using their oven to cook a damn pizza.

text:
I'm a cuban immigrant, and moved when I was about 7. When we first moved here my parents were very poor so this video really spoke to me. Were doing MUCH better now but we still do this exact bean recipe and i cook it myself now as well. I think cooking is one of those 'things" that does transcend economic status. There are so many good foods to make that are also cheap and varied. Im glad something so core to the human experience is translatable regardless of economic status.
And talking about poverty, in my opinion I dont think these people need to be treated like stray puppies nor victims. The statement "its not your fault" IMO doesnt always have a positive effect. If you ask me a video about how to make cheap food that is ALSO delicious (the former is easy, but doing both is what people look for) is infinitely more valuable than sentiments. I think somewhere down the line in our mission to treat poor people with respect we overcorrected and now they are victims by default. Especially in the west where upward mobility is at its highest, agency is more useful to encourage than sentiment. "heres how to make a cheap, delicious meal" > "its not your fault, youre a victim"

text:
8:59 "That's not very nice, it's just kind of a reality, right?"  The way around this is to get yourself a small community.  Check around your church if you attend one, or just your neighbors if you don't.  If you take turns cooking large cheap meals, you can chase some of the economies of scale that restaraunts get.  Instead of five different people each eating a different same thing for five days straight, you can have five people eat the same different thing each night.  (Or five families, though then you're looking at needing larger cookware, which is another expense.  But maybe a shared one.)

Admittedly, not everyone has a group they can trust like that, and that's a tragedy.

text: Am a single dad raising three female carnivores and its been easy for them to not eat meat at a lot of different meals. Breakfast (unless made for dinner) is meatless everyday, grains, cereals, yogurt & fresh fruits, only the fruit is expensive. Lunches by their own choice have become a lot of leftover meals that I reheat/prepare in the morning(did have to invest in good containers) Dinner we due twice a week veggie night and by buying seasonal get a good variety, also have a weekly "soup & salad supper". That leaves only four nights to feature meat and I do many recipes to scale at home. Those large batches with freezing & lunches can really bring down your $/M. thou with three kids still have to make treats. Use that as a bounding time too, we make cookies, pies, cakes, rice-crispy treats again in larger batches and store servings for school/snacks. Freezing/pickling/canning with buying seasonal and using sales/coupons can all help but have to admit we go out to eat once a month and everybody chooses on their birthday too ....lol Food is more then nutrition, its teaching/learning & sharing and that time together leads to many laughs/memories.

text:
Mostly true. Some people do bennefit from several factors that still allow them to eat fsr cheaper at the consumer level than they can eating out. 
 For instance, say you use a lot of tomato paste. You will not be able to go from seed to can making tomato paste at a lower cost yourself than can heinz, hunts or the store brand. Unless you are a Minnenonite, mormon or amish, you simply cant. And thats only because they arent allowed to buy those things in. UNLESS the primary driving force behind your value judgement is self gratification and hubris. 
 Thats the only and largest deciding factor in this. 
 But there are nearly ubiquitous busniess entitites within reasonable driving distance of most people that are in the top 50th socioeconomic percentile of americans that with a higher than average, but just slightly so, meal planning scheme, will allow you to with certain intellectual and psychological and mindful adjustment, will really allow you to save alot on food expenditures. Coupled with organizations like gleaners and local food pantires run by ngos and churches, food is plentiful as well as is nutrition at a very decent quality for nearly free. For instance ive lived off nori chips and 5 lb bags of hummus. Not for years. But you have to be adaptable.  And be willing to make excuses for why you have to make frequent retreats to isolated corners to bust ass privately. Hummus will turn you i to a wind tunnel capable of renting yourself to Lockheed martin or boeing. Ive lived off of wheathins and triscuits. Dont do that. It will give you a paper asshole. 
Also dont eat the aldi ground beef assistant stroganoff variety. I spent an hour on the throne contemplating how i was gonna get to the emergency room and explain to them that i needed help taking a dump. With the help of a rubber glove i pilfered from work, i was able to get things moving with a minimum of tearing. Full disclosure i added a lot of cheese to that so that might have had some effect on the ultimate 'outcome'
 Adam is a good guy and he can only know the things he has been exposed to. And he genuinely seems to be trying to be a nudge for good in the world. For that i give him all due credit. But i want to say that even if you are absolutely broke with nor regular income, you can get food if you look for it correctly. Its out there. It may not be awesome or even subpar. But it will keep you alive long enough to find something better. But as Joe Roagans sensei told him once, sometimes they die. 
 You might die at some point. The chances of it are high. So far as we know everyone who ever lived has or will die. 
 Dont let that stop you from living though. You have some limited degree of controll over when it happens. In aviation they have a saying that applies well to life. Always fly the plane, when you stop flying the plane, it stops being a plane.

text: I disagree, methionine is a genuine concern if you want to be lean and minimize meat in your diet at the same time, cultures with heavily plant based diets have much higher rates of MONW in large parts because there are NO good sources of methionine in the plant world, in fact legumes are already one of the best sources so you're not gonna "supplement" that with other elements in your diet. I've never understood this argument that "you don't need to worry about complete proteins because you'll get a variety of AAs in a varied diet" that only means your lowest protein source in that equation is completed, you can't complete all the protein in legumes with an equivalent amount of rice, you'll only complete the amount of protein that's in the rice AT BEST, it's excessively handwaved and misleading to people with any fitness goals.

text:
The biggest biological difference between being rich and being poor for me is the misfortune of being born disabled in a country that has no social security system for people with congenital disabilities. Can't work full time? Can't work at all? Enjoy being poor until you die from preventable causes that cost money to prevent.

I also have allergies and that used to be easy to manage but the way our modern food system is built, it's becoming increasingly harder to buy cheap staple ingredients (like rice and beans) that are free of cross contamination. Heck in my country, oats are not gluten free, because every company that sells oats uses shared equipment with wheat, so you have to pay extra for "coeliac certified oats" or simply go without oats because even though oats are naturally gluten free, in our modern food supply system, they aren't.

Ironically oats sold for horse feed are gluten free...and cheap...they legally can't market them to humans, and you have to sift through them for rocks and bugs, but I'm broke and I want oats dammit.

Secondly, I learned recently how to make a perfectly serviceable and not at all authentic lentil curry recently, and it's a life saver. It doesn't take long to cook, it's pretty simple, but it tastes very good, doesn't leave me feeling sick, and a normal batch lasts me at least three days. text:
Hi! I am actually one of the engineers who makes that specific refrigerator. We always love seeing them in the wild, and especially in the hands of somebody who is going to use them seriously.

If I can help assuage your sticker shock at all, you‚Äôre right it‚Äôs not a $15k fridge. It is, however, a $10k fridge that we upcharge because, well, rich people are suckers and also won‚Äôt buy things if they‚Äôre not visibly expensive enough. We put a lot of care into making them last the full twenty years we promise (and it sounds like the predecessor did), and in making them preserve food for as long as possible to cut down on food waste. Especially in a cabinet that size, filling it means having a LOT of material to use or discard if it spoils in a week or less, and leaving it empty means burning electricity cooling down dead air.

I hope you find it worthwhile over the rest of your time in that house!
