author: @obtusemooose

text:
‚Äã¬†@obtusemooose¬† It's far from a proper recipe but I'll write up a rough guide!

- I buy dried lentils; put maybe two cups in a strainer, rinse them well, then put it in a bowl to soak for a while. Any colour should work I believe, I use orange.
- Finely chop a big onion, put it in a pan with a decent bit of butter, cook it fairly low to soften. Throw in some cumin and turmeric. I'll do a bit of cayenne and paprika too, but they're less important in my opinion.
- Mince some garlic (maybe 3-4 cloves), a piece of ginger maybe the size of one garlic clove if you have it (you can also just do garlic/ginger powders instead probably), add those once the onions are soft and translucent. I also add a tablespoon or so of soy sauce here to get the umami flavour since there's no meat. Mix this and cook for up to a minute.
- Pour in a can of tomato sauce, stir together, add a bit of water if you need to (probably half a cup or so). Turn the heat up to maybe a low medium
- Drain the lentils, stir them in to the sauce. This is also roughly when I'll put rice on (I cook it on the stovetop). You can add bay leaves if you have them, not super important though.
- Stir the curry occasionally, and when you feel the rice is nearly done, stir in a few spoons of plain yogurt, or a similar amount of cream, though again this isn't crucial
- Fluff the rice and let it air a bit, and stir in some garam masala to the curry if you can get it. If not, add whatever parts of it you can source and taste for flavour

Personally, we keep most of these ingredients stockpiled because they're all pretty versatile; lentils I've had to go out of my way to get, but they last for ages and are very cheap in bulk. You can adapt this to use more vegetables, more seasonings, or whatever fits your own lifestyle better, this is just where the balance lies for me :)

text: I have so much issues with this. Mostly because the problem isn‚Äôt the cost of the food it‚Äôs the cost of time. Let‚Äôs take the pizza example, a 5lb bag of flour. Is about $6.50 where I live. It‚Äôs also a pantry item I often keep in my pantry. Let‚Äôs say your dough recipe is 500 g of flour and makes 4 pizzas that‚Äôs 35cents, salt if a few cents. Yeast for a pizza is going to be like 40cents. Let‚Äôs say 10 cents in oil. Let‚Äôs say $4 for the canned tomatoes. And that it makes 3 batches of 4 pizzas so about 66 cents per pizza. And the cheese is let‚Äôs say it costs $18 6lb for the cheese something you can freeze and store for up to a year easily. And let‚Äôs say you use 8 oz on a 13 inch pizza. Which brings it to about $1.50 per pizza That brings the cost for the raw ingredients to lets say $4 per pizza. Then ant 2.5KW for the oven running it for 1.25 hours at say $0.30KW/hr since i live in California that‚Äôs 3.13 for the electricity bringing you to $8 for the pizza. That is definitely as cheap if not cheaper than a restaurant. The problem is that to make the pizza you need to wait one hour for the oven to heat up. You need to have the foresight to have either premade pizza dough or time to make the pizza dough etc. But costs wise cooking at home has you beat. All with basically pantry or pantry style items. Not to mention you can have a lot of variety by mixing things up. If add some spices and change out the cheese with chicken breast add in a splash yogurt and some spices and you can make naan and something similar to chicken tikka masala. Change out the cheese for garbanzo beans lemon and garlic, and the tomato for canned red bell pepper with some other pantry items, you can make hummus, mahummara and pita. The problem is time not the cost and the idea that you need to make the same thing rather than understanding that you can use the same ingredients with minor substitutions to make a wide variety of dishes. It‚Äôs easy to do if you have the time. Unfortunately most poor people do not have that time.

text: 10:05 Not even a matter of money but just as a point of efficiency, I have basically no food waste goin' on. If it can be used, it's used. If flavor can be had, it's had. Onion and garlic skins go in a frozen Ziploc and eventually that's soup. Fruit and veg tops, same. Citrus peel? It cooks down chewable and is great in so many things (lime is overly tart for this, mind). It also has its own bag to just await its time if I'm not cookin' that sort of stuff at the moment. 20% of a banana's potassium is in the peel and people just chuck it. Cut that it into thin enough strips and it'll cook down. Could also brew it in hot water or blend into smoothie. That woody end of asparagus that people chop off and trash? Cut it in half or quarters and it cooks down chewable just the same. Got a Ziploc for bones and carcasses too. Bean water? I drink that stuff out of black beans. Bit of hot sauce, some seasoning. Kinda Bloody Mary vibes, honestly. Pasta water? Sauce ingredient. People waste a lot by sheer tradition and reflex that is utterly usable. Anything I really can't use or have used up goes to personal compost (also compostable paper and such) for gardening or gets chucked into the woods to compost there. Nothing even goes in the trash that would be better decaying natural to the earth. And that's not even a hippy thing. It just saves me trips to the dumpster 'cause A) The can doesn't fill as quick and B) No organic stuff rotting in my trash can and making a stink.

text:
That's exactly how I would have spiced that. Maybe not the sugar. Maybe with a bay leaf. 

I love the mention of the beans man. Often overlooked. I buy like 3lb bags of onions for $3-5. They last longer than it takes to use em. Maybe from my poor days but I've never once thought to buy like 1 onion or 1 potato haha. I do with peppers and such. Beans are a good slow carb compared to like rice or potatoes. And the different beans all have different flavors so you have tons of dish options centered or combining different beans.

I liked the topic today. It's one I'm really passionate about. After being so poor I fed my car instead of myself some days I have a really good understanding of just how easy it is to simply eat your money. At any scale of purchasing power you can just eat all your money. I find a lot of people are both stubborn and uneducated about how to shop and how to avoid those marketing traps. 10 years ago I had to survive on like $10-ish a week in food and when I look at prices today.. it would still work. Maybe more like $15 to guarantee it could be done today.

Cooking from scratch. Freezing things you can leverage later or in other ways. Learning how to leverage ingredients you have rather than buying random 1-off ingredients. Growing herbs is actually a huge saver if you like to have fresh ones. Cue my basil addiction.

I just made a spaghetti with a can of basil-garlic tomato paste. With a bunch of cardamon pods, cinnamon, oregano, cumin, garlic & onion powder, dark soy, onions, garlic, ground beef. 
Absolutely delicious and that's not a dish with any kind of recipe involved. I start with a base idea in my head based on what I have at home and then I taste and wing my way through it.
If I had an angry italian grandma I'd tell her I cook to eat tasty food, not to preserve honor or whatever lol.
Mexican chorizo is awesome on pizza btw. Mind the oil.

A lot of poor people really shop... poorly. Anything frozen that's not a meat or veggy or difficult pastry is probably a waste of money. Anything consisting of more than 1 ingredient in a sealed container is probably a waste of money. Canned beans are luxury priced bean. I'll stop, I've gone on enough lmao.

¬†@DeltaSkylar201¬† Well thank you.
Frozen veggies are usually cheaper and obviously can last longer than fresh. Beans, potatoes, eggs, milk, and chicken were like my staple foods. I'd buy giant packs of chicken and then portion that into bags to freeze once home. Spices can seem expensive but you don't have to replace them too often. So you can buy like 1 of those at a time.

Don't buy any of those meats that are pre-seasoned or come with a bunch of veggies. In general look at and understand the price-per-lb tier and kinda know what it should be. If you can buy big packs of meat and process it you'll pay less and have scraps you can use to make a stock.
For example I recently got a bone-in 10lb pork shoulder for like $9. It was a steal but I did spend a lot of time cutting it down, portioning and freezing. But that's 3 meals of adobo that will feed 3 people.

Curry, spaghetti, fried potatoes, chili, "soup", fried rice are all things you can just toss ingredients into a pan and then throw your own kind of seasoning profile at. I mean I like beans in my fried rice lol. Learn how to balance flavors. Salt, acid, fat, sweet, spicy all kind of interact. Other people can explain better.

My current favorite easy meal is 200 grams of flour, 2 eggs. Make that into noodles. 1lb of ground beef. Onion and garlic.Then just season it. I've had it taste like curry and like tacos. I have no recipe but it is always a winning unique dish lmao. Making noodles isn't so easy or fast but I just enjoy it.

Much of saving money on food can come at a cost of trading your time. Some things are not worth your time unless you do a GIANT batch. One example is tomato paste. But like making fresh noodles is kinda nice compared to those dry ones.
Canned beans vs soaking overnight + 1-2hrs simmering is a good tradeoff. Using the video as an example, adam cooked like 3-5 cans of beans there basically at a fraction of the cost. Even making your own refriend beans is better. Healthier, tastier, muscle building xD.

Figure out dishes you can make to use up your regular grocery runs. And freeze some portions so you can maybe skip that 3rd day of eating enchiladas or whatever. Then you just have a frozen meal ready for later.

I even freeze tomato sauce, cheese, pepperoni and dough for pizzas in portions. 

I really stand behind having a good stock of spices and knowing how to use them + how to cook different ingredients. After practice and disasters you'll really be able to raid whatever is left and make something reasonably filling and tasty even when the kitchen feels void of ingredients. watching lots of chefs helps learn new tricks too.

Freezing and repurposing are king when cooking on a limited budget. The most frequent ways are pan frying and soups, but I find that baking, adding different textures/changing up sides (bread, rice, pasta, potatoes) or even straight-up dumping the leftovers into a new meal in a perpetual stew kind of cycle works well with taste fatigue. 

Also, if you have friends/roomates/neighbors who have similar issues - just straight up meal swapping!

text:
I don't consider myself poor (definetely not rich either), but I eat the same thing for 4 days, since I cook for only myself, and there is no way I'll be cooking every single meal. 
Basically I cook a batch, I eat one at that moment, and store enough for 3 more meals in the fridge. I always have 2 different meals in the fridge from which I can choose from. If I cook an even bigger batch, I can freeze some for when I'm not feeling like cooking.
 I find it weird when he is talking about this "eating the same thing several days in a row" as being such a depressing thing to be subjected to. I find it kind of patronizing. It's not just poor people that do it, it's an efficiency thing, and it's not that bad.
(No, I'm not downplaying the struggles of eating exactly the same thing, morning to night, for weeks and weeks. The video was not talking about that, I am not talking about that)

text:
5:02 Another risk: Boredom and depression. I knew some poverty growing up (I'm not strictly clear of it even now) and TV dinners were CONSTANT. There were several points where the very idea of even eating became depressing. I skipped meals sometimes rather than eat the same thing for I don't know, the fifth night?
A big help is to just get away from recipe shopping. Buy staples and things that can be variable. Don't buy ingredients for [recipe], buy ingredients that can be portioned and stored and then prepared as needed for many different recipes. I got a big pork roast, 'bout six pounds, and it's about to be at least eight different dishes. Also soup: Make a soup. Big pot. When the solids run out or the broth gets low, throw more stuff in. Different stuff! Different seasonings! Change up the whole soup! Go from Spanish to Japanese flavor by way of Ireland. And I fall into the 'eating one thing a lot' category often. My fix for vitamins and such is literally just a bowl of Grape Nuts. They cram vitamins and minerals all up in that and it's not one of those dessert cereals either. Who's out here taking multivitamins? A bowl of Grape Nuts'll do ya for vitamins and calories. A lot of the non-dessert cereals will.  And for easy dessert, I keep a box or two of the sugary junk. Ratio tip: Two servings cereal, one serving milk. Weigh it out by grams. Perfect bowl. Buy a cheap scale if you don't have one. Brilliant things, scales.

text:
Something I've come to learn about dessert is it has to be psychologically satiating. Oreos are not. That's why a sleeve goes like nothing. Popped like pills, not much flavor beyond just pure sweet, texture's not much. A decent slice of cake with somethin' crumbly-crunchy on top could be half the sugar and I can walk away after the one slice. Denseness and richness (thick, chewy desserts are the ticket) and texture and pacing really help with overdoing dessert. Instead of seeking out more sugar (because our brains are actually evolved to trigger more appetite when we get sugar; the 'I got a second stomach for dessert' saying is not literal but figuratively near to truth), seek satisfying textures and such. And with something like KIND or granola bars, don't chomp right in. Pick at 'em, take little nibbles of sweetness. I break a granola down grain by grain sometimes. One bar can last me twenty minutes while I'm catching up on TV or some work or whatever. The dessert stretching over more time also creates a greater sense of satisfaction. Savoring food and whatnot.
...Mind, I suspect I also have sensory deficiencies so maybe it's just me who needs more texture and such to get the worth of dessert. Fun fact: Ben of Ben & Jerry's can't smell anything and because smell is actually a huge dimension of flavor, his means of differentiating food is largely down to texture and extremes of taste. It's why their whole schtick is piling hyper-sweetness over fifty different textures of thing no matter the flavor of the pint.

And if you have neither the time nor the energy to commit to cooking what is the alternative you purpose? Starving to death because somebody told you that you had to cook all your meals yourself? And that is a reality for some people.

Another aspect of being poor is living accommodations. Do you know how expensive a proper kitchen can be? You want an oven, cooking tops? Well that takes up a ton of space. You want a fringe with enough space for all your staple ingredients, well it doesn't have to cost you 15k, but it does cost money And take up space, which is at a premium if you're trying to keep down rent, which in many countries is out of control right now. You also likely want a sink, which cuts into countertop space, which might also be used for anything extra you want, like a microwave.

text:
If I may push back... very gently... on what you said about the economy... it's worth noting that much of what you said about the things you like about our economy are not actually true. They appear true, yes, especially to people who are successful (such as yourself... and that's not a condemnation; I mean it positively), but it's not as true as you may think. It may be worth looking up the work of economists and academics such as Richard Wolfe, Michael Hudson, David Harvey, Jason Hickel, Kohei Saito, Ann Pettifor, and others in a similar vein.

Our economy is built on a hegemony that is provably false... the idea of infinite growth in a system with finite resources. The assumption that our economy fairly rewards hard work or innovation breaks down when you factor in structural inequalities (such as disabilities and such), market failures, and the fact that those with capital tend to accumulate more at the expense of those without. I genuinely do not believe that the fruits of our economic system can be distributed equally in our system. The only path to truly equal distribution is through us laborers owning the means of our own production, which we do not and I'd argue cannot in our current economic system. We would need a completely different economic system for that to happen.

In fact, I would argue that what we're seeing happen to our government is the logical end path of our economic system. Elon Musk is what our economic system creates... not equality.

I could also go on about why I think "money as a need" is actually bad, why our basic needs should be actually free, why I don't think the idea of "laziness" actually exists, my critiques of the Capitalist/Protestant Work Ethic (not so great when you really break it down), and so on, but as this is a YouTube comment, I'll end it here.

I'd much rather cook a bunch of stuff, ONCE, and have leftovers for the rest of the week. Especially fancy foods. It's too much effort to cook multiple different things, multiple times a week, for every single meal. And yeah you can order out if you're well off, but 99% of the stuff you eat outside is not healthy, especially fancy food. They cook with 10x the oil, 3x the sugar. You'll be healthier if you cook your own meals and eat different colored veggies/fruits to supplement.
author: @Arunnn241

text:
You had me until you said that you're glad living in an economic system that incentivizes people to work hard to become less poor... That's not how the economic system is set up, lol. All the poor people I know in my life are not poor through any lack of work ethic or laziness. We all work our butts off and are underpaid, overworked, and exploited. I've had the privilege of working an office job in the tech sector, something that most people have been conditioned to see as something achieved through hard work, and it was so much easier than anything I've ever done at any retail job I've worked at, plus I was being paid a living wage. 

The incentive to work hard to become less poor is an intentional falsehood; we work harder so we produce more labor and thus value for our companies - those that perform well are kept in their low-wage, physically grueling positions because they're more valuable producing labor in that position. Again, in this economic system, profit maximization is all that's prioritized, not the human spirit or welfare, of course this will happen. 

I would also say that the work I've provided in retail jobs has produced more direct tangible value to society than something than maintaining an e-commerce application or selling overpriced health insurance to people could. This is especially considering that it would be much more efficient not only in terms of labor but also emotional labor to have a single-payer healthcare system that wouldn't deny people's claims randomly just to milk more money out of them and maybe not let providers and pharmaceutical companies over-inflate prices so laissez-faire. Indeed, a lot of jobs in our economic system like advertising, insurance sales, the dieting industry, and whatnot are mostly superfluous and provide little to no value, and we'd all have to work a lot less and enjoy life more under a more efficient, humane economic system, but that's another discussion entirely. 

Also, here in the United States, meat is high priced despite abundance largely in part due to illegal cartels being formed between agricultural companies. They share pricing information among other things to keep prices inflated. There are active lawsuits the government is involved in regarding these cases, but its yet to be seen if anything will actually happen. Meat didn't used to be so prohibitively expensive. There also used to be cheaper cuts of meat, but most all of them have been gentrified and glorified in some way through social media and the prices skyrocketed to be not much less than more appealing cuts of meat. I always wondered if any advertising money was used to make some of that happen.

text:
A lot i can agree with as a hospitality professional of 20 years.
But id say zippy bags and batch cooking is the win.

Always start in the grocery space in the meat area, a lot of store's stsrt you in the fresh food space.
But go past this. Go to the meat space. Look for discounted near out of date items or specials thst are beyond standard catalogue.

Then based off what you can get vs how much you need, vs how many portions which takes time to figure out but base your meals off this and then go back to the vegetables and fruits to collect ehats needed.

I make 4 litres of Bolognese with only a kilo of beef mince. Deep tomato and onion base.

4 litres of chilli

Or burger meat from chopped steak

Chicken thighs stored flat in zippy bags and freeze like sheets.

I pull my finished meal or meat to prep from the freeze and finish.

Most my meals are cooked half way allowing more time for other things. Spend 2 afternoons prepping meals but since you freeze them i always have a week or two of meals to rotate through never eating the same meal more than twice if there is leftovers.

Put vegetables in everything. If you can hide it, add it.
Example.
Add a shredded carrot into chilli.
Shredded zucchini into curry.
Broccoli florets into past spirals 

Last big tip.

Have two massive pots.

Fill one with potato carrot and Broccoli 

The other with zucchini, cauliflower or any other semi firm vegetable.
Pumpkins good but i roast mine in foil and add after.


Chop thick and basic.

Boil. Till soft.

Strain and mix together.

Add garlic paste, mustar, salt butter and rough mash.
Finish with parsley and frozen peas.

Scoop into bags based on portion requirements.
And freeze 

Congratulations you have a vegetable mash that is delicious for any protein, fried with bacon as a hash / bubble squeak,
On toast. With eggs.
And now you have all the veg taken care of without the need to boil and mash every day, prep vegetables every day. I can do 2 weeks of vegetables and not do more than microwave for 2 minutes and boom.

You can evenmake basic chunks and roast.
Also you can use all the vege scrap to make stock.

Being efficient isnt difficult just enjoy finding what you like, analyse how to attack the problem and be creative. Modern storage as basic as freezing has so much potential if you think outside the box.

text: After I got laid off and my unemployment ran out, I was subsisting on $25 per week from completing online surveys. Utilizing what I already had in my pantry, I got really creative making different congee to satisfy a craving. I made pho congee, Mexican congee, Italian, congee, etc and threw in beans and really cheap canned veggies. I ate oatmeal for every breakfast, instant ramen for every lunch, and then congee. It was rough but I was able to get by and creating different congees really helped break up the monotony. It sucked but was doable.

author: @IRMentat

text:
‚Äã¬†@dr.woozie7500¬†I like Asian cuisine but only stock a few of those. Soy sauce is a must for making anything taste spot on even if just a few drops on the rice. I'll also hoard any and all sauce packets I get lol. However for the ingredients you listed here's what I do as a basic white lady who doesn't specialize in Asian cooking but wants option in my general kitchen: 
Ginger- I keep powdered spice on hand (sometimes I can get a pack for like a buck) and it's good in bakery as part of pumpkin pie spice. Fresh ginger keeps a while but can be frozen. Also good as tea.
Garlic- kept for general basic, also like garlic powder on a pinch
Green onions- this is tricky but they can be frozen. Can also be grown in garden and also there's some varieties that are perennial so will last and last
Oyster sauce- rarely use so can't justify keeping on hand. I try to substitute a little soy sauce but any other ideas?
Star anise- I skip this but will keep eye out for sale. Can the same type be used for baking sweets?
Cumin- always on hand because it's a cheap spice and also great in Mexican food. I basically taught myself to use it a lot as it's so easily available. What do you put it in for Asian items? I've only seen it mainly as part of curry.
Fermented veggies- generally skip as I don't use them enough. A small jar of kimchi can be nice though 
White vinegar- household staple, everyone should have if only for cleaning, good general purpose substitute for rice vinegar in small dose
Cooking wine- I know this can really make home cooking taste like restaurant food but seems like extra expense. I barely buy cheap wine for drinking. Any suggestions?
Chili bean paste- occasionally I'll have Sriracha but I don't use it enough so when prices rose I stopped. 
Rice- this should be in EVERYONE'S cupboard. Basic white or brown long grain rice is under a dollar a pound and such a good staple for almost any cuisine. I'll freeze it for ease of use later. I try to get more interesting varieties like Jasmine and such if on sale..
author: @ELLEB3LLE

text: @ cumin is used for stir fry to add more flavor and also specifically I use it for cumin beef or Xinjiang style lamb kebabs. By chili bean paste I‚Äôm referring not to Sriracha but Lao Gan Ma or Lee Kum Kee (the stuff that comes in glass jars). I add that to stir fries or marinades or any rice or noodle dish for extra flavor and depth. As for cooking wine, Shaoxing Huadiao cooking wine is essential, it can be used stir fry, soup, marinades, adding a splash or two to any dish that‚Äôs being cooked in a pan or wok. It‚Äôs like $10 in most Asian markets.

text:
A major factor people leave out when comparing home cooking to eating out are the larger fixed costs. A kitchen with all the appliances and tools you need doesn't just appear for free, and of course you touched on the fact that cooking takes energy. The big one however is just the space occupied by the kitchen itself.
If you're in a small apartment, the kitchen is a large portion of your living space, and you're paying for that every month. If you're paying $1000 for a 600sq/ft apartment and the kitchen is 150sq/ft, just having that kitchen exist costs you $250/month. You can get a lot of pre-made food for that price.
Even if you own your home, you're paying property taxes on that kitchen forever, and the base cost of the house was higher for it existing.

text: I get by on less when I do beans because I tend to do a 13 or 21 bean soup that lasts 2 or three days as the only thing I eat in the volume I make it and with all the ingredients only costs me about $5 and because I do it in an instant pot I don't even need to presoak anything. It's a variety of dry beans I get in bulk, some frozen corn, a can of diced tomatoes and some bullion or soup base and takes me just a little over an hour to make. It's something I make at least twice a month. My other 'lasts for 2 or three days' meal I make in the instant pot is Beef Stew that runs me about $10 and I buy all the ingredients in bulk, prep multiple soup packs at once, throw 'em in vacuum packs and toss 'em in the freezer and when I'm ready to make them, just need do dice a few potatoes, toss in a can of diced tomatoes, add water and throw it in the Instant Pot for a little over an hour. On other days that I'm being cheap, I get by on less than a $1 worth of ramen or rice. I don't only eat cheap despite being poor. I also sometimes do things like Home Chef, because I've found that when I figure how much it will cost me to get the ingredients for the nice meals without buying in bulk (which usually results in some of it going to waste), getting it from a meal prep service comes out to about the same price and there's less prep and shopping involved. I also often do spaghetti, tortellini,  hot dogs, and burgers. Oh, and lots of steaks, which I buy affordable cuts and then vacuum pack then pre-salted to throw in the freezer as well, usually to eat over the next few months. I usually get by on around $200 a month in food, $300 if I do a lot of splurging on things like home chef or eating out in a month.

text:
Honestly, Adam's approach to these beans made way more fucking sense than any of the other food influencer videos talking about "X home cook recipes for week nights", in which they use one-off ingredients and make ONE portion/meal.

My biggest struggle as someone who lives on their own and is trying not to blow hundreds on ordering food online is figuring out "ok, what do I buy and prep to last me a week or so?". Meal planning/prepping - with the caveat of "hey, unless you're rich, you're probably eating the same thing multiple times a week" that Adam mentioned - is the actual challenge for those who didn't learn any of these skills growing up, IMO, and I'd love to see more people tackle reasonable foods, instead of "rich people food, but I pretend it is reasonable for everyone".

text:
You make one thing that becomes the base for multiple things. Sunday's Roast Ham extra potatoes, peas, carrots becomes, peas and rice with ham, ham and eggs, ham and potato gratin, ham and pea risotto or pilaf, pea soup, etc. Those dishes get tossed together quickly and after portioning and freezing, you end up with a variety of items in the freezer that can just be reheated. I always like dishes I can freeze. I don't have to eat the same dish for a week but, after a week I'll have a freezer half full of dishes. Do a similar thing the next week with chicken, pork, duck, lamp, etc, based on what's on special.

Overripe bananas get tossed in the freezer to thaw and make banana bread when I've got enough. Tonight leftover roast beef is becoming a chili (stretched with canned kidney beans and frozen corn) to serve on top of a rice and pea pilaf.

text:
I'm poor, but European, so I'm not sure how much this advice really applies to me. I wouldn't dream of eating the same thing for 6 meals in a row - that is absurd to me. I shop at Lidl for two and our weekly shop is about $60 (I converted the currency). We eat varied but quite simple meals - a lot of pasta, probably at least 4x a week. Chicken usually twice a week and maybe beef once.

What I will say, is that if you are wealthy enough to eat out every day and claim that is somehow "cheaper than cooking", please do not claim to be poor - you are either pretending to be poor, or are keeping yourself poor through your spending habits. If I could afford 2x$14 a day just for my dinner, I'd be in the top 5% of earners or so, I think. Just learn to cook, or at least learn to reheat pre-made stuff etc. I eat out probably once every 2-3 months or so, as a treat, because that is what I can afford, for now. Maybe I will treat myself more when I'm earning more!

I understand that second paragraph may not translate so well to other countries - I've heard groceries and especially fresh food is a lot more expensive in America. But I'm sure it can't be so bad that it's really cheaper - although I do take the point that eating stuff with lots of individual ingredients is difficult to make at home. Just learn to cook simple meals which require say, 3-5 base ingredients and herbs and spices that you can re-use again and again. That's the key.

text:
On the "Not everyone gets paid what they're worth" note, the company I started working at in the mid-2010s got bought out in late 2019.  We merged offices in early 2020, and the new management didn't even have time to see me before as many people as possible, myself included, went to work-from-home.

As a consequence, I wound up getting laid off to "save money".

Cut to a year later and they were real desperate to get me back.  I asked for five times my old hourly rate and they accepted it without even trying to negotiate downwards.

So, yes.  I'd argue that most people who work for a living are paid less than they're worth.  I certainly was.

text:
The self‚Äëawareness, and awareness in general, are appreciated. Being honest about things as far as they go, is how you let people make the right decisions for themselves, and judge things rationnaly. Even though you're far from perfect Adam (who isn't?), telling outright where you fail and how you fail enables us to appreciate what you do right more, and perhaps even helps us not fall into or fuel the same issues as you do.

As much as everyone on the social media "game" loves being appreciated, and recognized, and glazed, and whatever (I do, you do, anyone reading this who engages with others on the platform does), you know this validation must be balanced by recognizing your audience is just as smart, competent and legitimate as you are. Hell, we're a lot watching your stuff, so obviously there are people who are going to come up with valid criticism and that's normal.

Hence, you present yourself as what you are: flawed, like the rest of us, like the rest of the bunch. And like the beans, we indeed do not need that much sugar coating. What's good Adam is that you're not fooling yourself and trying to fool us as well, you know all of that and you act accordingly and with enough humility. Was that fridge really a good idea? Maybe not. But at least, not trying to gaslight yourself and everyone into believing "OF COURSE IT WAS RIGHT" is what matters most, cause that takes off of that pressure everyone's feeling when they see the foodtuber with all of his fancy schmancy stuff basically calmly calling us out to reform our whole lifestyle to make it revolve around his own, and that's of course surreal.

The way you handle that presentation, the ethics of it, that is great, Adam. So yeah, you keep doing you, and everything's mighty fine. Remember that a good portion of your audience is comprised of people who are also tired of being lectured by fancy foodtubers sending them signals that "if you're not doing it exactly the way I do, then you're doing it bad, even if you have no choice >:(", and so have found some comfort in the more relaxed, pragmatic and realistic ways you handle cooking lessons.

text:
I don't think it's a good idea to tell people it's not their fault they are poor. I also don't think it's a good idea telling people they aren't getting paid what they're worth. Your worth isn't something you decide for yourself, nor is it dictated on you, it's something you decide with someone else. These series of agreements across industries lead to the relative values of work which dictate the average bounds of contracts. There is also more to being successful than mere skill or hard work, or even "luck", but people should focus on building skill and working hard because it's the most likely to bring success even in an impoverished situation. 

I've always been in the bottom 20% of earners and yet recognizing that, building skill towards what I enjoy and can profit off of, and managing my money accordingly has me on the path to owning my own restaurant and home. Poverty in the US is pretty amazing as long as you can at least mimic being a good person, do your job right, and limit frivolous spending. Especially compared to nearly anywhere else in the world.

text:
wy should you be guilty about eating meat or encouraging others to eat meat? we literally cannot just eat the food we give to livestock. that video that you're clearly basing your take on, is total nonsense. it took things like "70+% of soy is fed to livestock" and didn't research exactly what soy is fed to livestock. we feed them the stalks, the pods, the husks, all things we humans can't digest and otherwise would either have to be burnt to fertilise, or be composted over a long time to fertilise. 
The far better option is to feed it to cows, pigs, sheep etc, they turn it into meat and fertiliser and so waste from harvested crops becomes a consumable source of food. We don't feed livestock foods that humans can eat in any significant amount. even "cornfed" means we feed them on the middle of the corn cob, and the stalks etc. again, all things we can't eat. 

"According to the United Nations FAO, only 13% of global animal feed is comprised of grain crops, and for cattle specifically, grain makes up only 10% of their diet globally.
 The majority of their feed, 57.4%, consists of grass and leaves.
 Additionally, a large portion of the feed is made up of agricultural byproducts that are inedible to humans, such as crop residues like corn stalks"

So please, stop pushing this meat shaming nonsense.

text: In the spirit of the video and for relevance to current events: you can freeze eggs. Just crack them and either separate the yolk and white (if you want) or whisk them and freeze. If you need individual eggs for baking you can freeze them in a muffin tin, otherwise just throw it all in a resealable bag. The shells can then be boiled to sanitize and crushed into a powder that is extremely high in calcium. Note that if you do this you have to crush the shells into POWDER, not "very small pieces"  otherwise you can damage your insides on the sharp edges. Also be careful how much and how regularly you use it because this stuff is so high in calcium you can easily give yourself calcium poisoning.

text:
I just want to comment that I loved the reality check this video gives everyone and especially to those """influencers""". However, what you said about needing to eat more legumes and meat is scientific misinformation/disinformation and is EXTREMELY harmful. 

While it's obvious that meat as a secondary product is very unfriendly economically, unfortunately it is still very very important to be in our diets. Look up the study that was recently done in India comparing provinces that eat mostly legumes for their protein vs ones that eat fish or other animals for their protein. The difference in average height and other demographics between those people are very pronounced and definitely calls into the need for people to consume higher quality protein vs just from legumes and lentils.

Thanks to grown food being so insanely cheap and plentiful, it is reasonable feed livestock a strict diet of that and not use large swaths of roaming land. Historically, animals kept for food ate things that people wouldn't. Things like grass, woody shrubs, spoiled fruits/vegetables.

text: When I was living at my poorest, I ate beans and rice all the time along with bananas because they were cheap.  I would also eat a cheap cereal with milk and take a multivitamin to cover anything that I might be lacking.  I would also on occasion eat spaghetti with tomato paste.  I remember hearing a story about a guy who always ate a cheese sandwich every day for 10 years, was getting sick all the time, and doctors seemed to have trouble diagnosing what was making him sick.  Then one day a doctor bothered to ask him what he typically ate and as soon as the doctor heard his answer, he was able to diagnose scurvy.  Apparently, it is so rare these days in western countries that doctors often don't readily recognize it.  The doctor then wrote a prescription for one piece of fruit to be eaten every day.

text: Two things: first, I have gotten by for much of my life making two large batches of food at a time, maybe one on Saturday and one on Sunday, and alternating throughout the week. This might not be worth it for some, but for me I get a lot more enjoyment out of at least not having the same thing every day for dinner. Second, the argument about "why not just eat the food that the meat animals eat" does leave out the fact that animals (currently and for much of recorded history) have eaten things that we cannot eat. In the current industrialized system, animals do eat a lot of things that come from resources that could have grown human food, but animals also eat grass, random seeds, bugs (which we could eat but usually don't want to), and waste products from other industrial farming systems like corn husks, other plant fibers, and even "food waste" (food that humans may have otherwise eaten but didn't).
author: @josephmcgowan9936

text:
I live in NYC and ever since the post-pandemic inflation, I've noticed that eating from the many halal carts in the city would be cheaper than doing grocery shopping to make food at home, lol. You can get a generous quantity of food for like $10 and often the portions are large enough for two meals. The only thing that keeps me from going this route is the health factor, so I grit my teeth and fork over more money for whole foods and fresh produce.

Re: pizza, I've resolved my love of the more expensive wood oven-fired pizza by making "pizza" at home on the stovetop in a large frying pan. Yes, you read that right! Takes very little time and it's NOT THAT BAD! I have perfected it down to an art and science. The slightly burnt bottom is even reminiscent of pizzeria pizza, lol

text:
Ground beef is relatively cheap in America, roughly $4 to $6 per pound and it can be stretched with all the usual cheap ingredients. 
I have a $23 spaghetti sauce recipe that will yield enough spaghetti sauce to feed one man for about a week. 
It keeps it interesting, can be used in other recipes, and freezes well when you get tired of it. 

Bulk cooking is what makes budget cooking work in both time and effort. I still do it even though I'm not a broke college student anymore.
author: @DangerB0ne

text:
Facts! My go-to is crockpot chicken thighs with onion and potatoes, bouillon "stock", seasoning, cook 4hrs. Lasts me at least 3-4 days (5days if i serve with side veggies and/or rice). 

Find ingredients within your budget and learn what you can do with them! You can still eat a wide variety of delicious food that way.

text:
¬†@AnnoyingNewsletters¬† it makes almost a gallon of sauce. You can cut it down to $19 if you make it without meat and it will still make a whole pot full of sauce.

Mind you that I'm adding the price of spices to the initial price, taking those out will bring the price down by a further $6. People making "budget" recipes always count spices' price by the amount added to recipes instead of the smallest available at the store. I went with the actual retail container price. Now that I have a pantry full of spices, this recipe typically costs me $17 or less in ingredients. Were I to make it without meat, it would cost something like $13 or less.
It's pretty competitive with jarred sauce and is much better for you than Ragu, no added sugar.

text:
@kandigloss6438¬† It depends on your local stores. I've found that ground chicken and pork are often more expensive than ground beef in my neck of the woods, though raw sausage is typically cheaper. Rarely I can find ground turkey for a cheaper price than ground beef but it's nothing to rely on. For whole cuts of meat, pork is king. Cheap, readily available, and often on discount or a buy one, get one free deal.
 
$4 is pretty cheap unless you're scrimping every last penny. I honestly don't know where one would find cheaper ground meat without it being the dubious stuff out of a Dollar Tree cooler.

text: As a frugal home cook, I'd argue that you overspent on the produce. An individual red pepper is costly and is the extra trap people are complaining about when they try to follow new recipes every day. You can usually get a pack of 6 for $4-6 depending on where you live. And then unless you're featuring the vegetable in a dish where you're feeding a group of people, you probably want to only use a quarter of it at a time to add a splash of color and vitamin C to a dish. Same with the onion, $2 individually, but like $3-5 for a bag of like 16+ smaller onions. And I live alone and cook for myself, so anyone who argues buying a bag will just have it go bad is either not cooking often enough or buying to many other things per trip expecting to have variety. As a solo cook, I know I have to monitor when something is starting to go off and cook a big batch on a Sunday and freeze it.

text: For whatever it's worth and whoever cares, I would add to the statement about meat, that both economical and environmentally it's beneficial to hunt and fish. Especially if you have spare time but not spare money, they are both great pass times that can result in cheap groceries. When I first got married my wife and I both worked part time and I was in college. We had very little money but luckily we live in family land that has a couple ponds and small game and whitetail deer. We out of necessity developed a habit of building a diet around wild game (way more so than fish, but fish on occasion) that still to this day (16 years later) we hold true to. With the exception of the occasional bacon, sausage and even rarer chicken, we don't really buy meat; I honestly have no idea when the last time we bought any beef was. But even without owning or having access to private land, most states have large sections of national forest and other public lands that require only a hunting permit. And because they aren't framed, they are really a secondary agricultural product; game will eat crops, but they get most of their food from browsing naturally occurring shrubbery and acorns and nuts. Public water ways are essentially the same, offering an opportunity to a plethora of fish species generally, assuming you live within driving distance to a body of water.

text:
The fruit vs vegetable debate is entirely because English has two meanings for "fruit" and people don't know the difference.
An apple is the fruit of the plant, and in a culinary context, it's also *a fruit*.
A pepper/tomato/etc is the fruit of the plant, but it's not "a fruit" in a culinary context; it's still a vegetable :)

text:
Back in the late 80s, when I was completely on my own, constantly broke, and most likely the healthiest I was as an adult, I cooked my own meals virtually 100% of the time. The cost of eating out just once was enough to feed me for at least a week out of my own kitchen. Not that I had a lot of variety, but I was a very good cook even then and wasn't bored with my food.

My food budget drove me to buy everything on sale, and about the only prepackaged food I'd buy was generic ramen, and only when I could get it for a nickle. Beans were a staple of my diet.

text:
I'm sorry, but a lot of this is just untrue.
I'm looking at Aldi in the US and you can buy 3lbs of apples for $3. Bananas are $0.17 per lbs. 3lbs of yellow onions is $2.85. 6 bagels is like $2.15. Flour (all purpose) is $2.59 for 5lbs. Meat? Chicken drumsticks are $5.50 per 3lbs. Pork loin (whole) is $1.79/lb, grab a knife and slice. Canola is $3.65 per 1.5L, which will last you ages if you're not deep frying anything.

What sucks up your food budget is not buying in bulk and not knowing how to cook, or not being able to cook (due to lack of stove, fridge, freezer, etc.). If you can, buy the basics, get some spices, get some cooking utensils, bowls, containers for the fridge, etc. and make a meal plan. Oh, and freeze. And stop buying loose vegetables, buy it in bags. Stop buying marinated fancy meats, buy bulk or primal cuts. Once you have that, solely eating rice & beans or packet ramen is just an excuse. No, it's not cheaper to go out to eat unless you're buying pizza, ethnic foods you would never want to make on your own, sushi, deep fried stuff, fried chicken sandwiches and the like.

Being poor sucks. A lot. I know, I lived it. No, it's not your fault and even if it is your country should be able to provide you with decent nutrition with good taste. I'm sorry the US messed up on that part, but you kinda keep voting for it.

text:
Well now I'm crying. I am indeed poor, have been for most of my life despite a lotta trying. I've mentioned before in comments on your videos about how much of a struggle it all is - made more challenging still by caring for a man with end stage kidney disease.
Beans really are an incredible food though. It's good to understand that bell pepper can give the nutrients that onions can, btw - I recently developed some level of allergy to onions and garlic so I've been forlornly gazing at my shallots and garlic powder and not using them often. I'll note that lentils are ALSO legumes and while they may not have quite the same "oomph" as black beans or kidney beans, they do have a bit less tendency to get the gut all upset. You can also add a teaspoon or so of Caraway seed to a pot of beans and it'll be less of an issue (and tastes okay too).
But most of all I appreciate what you're saying at the end of this. It's infuriating and disheartening how much our media and - I dunno, social attitude? - tend to hammer and hammer and hammer at the poor folks about how they're morally suspect, or stupid, or just plain not trying hard enough. It's so unfair to heap abuse on people already struggling. I get it - even the ones who want to help the most just run out of resources and energy after a while. The system isn't equitable, never was, and might never be, since pretty much all of what we live with (in the US at least) was put in place by powerful, wealthy folks who wanted to STAY wealthy and powerful, and had no intention of allowing their downtrodden to rise up and take any power or wealth for themselves. I don't have any answers for any of that. I'm just over here trying to survive. Hearing you say, even indirectly, that I'm worth more than what I'm suffering through? That felt like getting a really badly needed hug.
Thank you.

I will start off by making Adam feel a bit better about eating meat, there are regions where the soil can only support grass growth.

text:
I'm poor (like, $1300/mo poor, in the US, and mostly in more expensive states like HI and CA).

After watching YT cooking channels for years - and working in restaurants for ten - I decided it would be better, and cheaper, if I built my kitchen like a restaurant, or at least as close as possible.

I didn't buy any super expensive appliances, like a $15,000 refrigerator (but man, would a reach-in be so cool)...instead, I invested in high quality tools...Hestan Nanobond pots n' pans, Le Creuset stock pots and utensils, food processor, stand mixer, etc. Rubber Maid food storage bins for things like flour, rice and beans, salt and sugar (so I can buy 25/50 lb. bags and save money).

It took me four years to build this stuff up, scrounging every dollar each month, while living in a 1 bdrm, roach and bed bug infested apartment with two other men, who I cooked for in exchange for a steady food budget (made it easier for me to purchase more tools for myself).

So, it's definitely possible if you're broke, and have the time, but it's difficult.

I've since left that shithole in L.A., and everything I had is gone now, but I'm saving money to do it all over again.

Maybe I'll start a cooking channel when I do. üòÇ

text:
9:24

You're wrong - it's a myth that's been perpetuated way too much, but the truth is that a bell pepper (as well as tomatoes, eggplants, cucumbers) IS a vegetable AND ALSO a fruit. The problem is how you use the term and in what context. Since you are cooking and not leading a botany class, it's a vegetable, not a fruit. 

Vegetable is a culinary term and NOT botanical, in botany there is no term "vegetable". Fruit, on the other hand, is a term that is different when used botanically vs culinarily, and since most of us deal with food more often than the study of plants, colloquially the culinary term for "fruit" is the more common one, and by that definition a bell pepper is NOT a fruit because it's not something you would put in a fruit salad.

This is more apparent in other languages, such as Russian, that have a separate term for botanical fruit vs culinary fruit. In Russian, the botanical fruit of a plant is "plod" and has to do with the plant's reproduction. The culinary term for fruit is "frookt" and is referring to sweet fruits that are typically eaten for dessert or put in a fruit salad.

As an example of a similar situation, I could say that when you drive and apply brakes to your car, you are accelerating (even though you are braking). Why? Because acceleration in physics is change in velocity. Since by applying brakes you are changing your velocity (from fast to slow) that means from a physics perspective you are ACCELERATING, but try to give driving directions to someone by saying "accelerate" when you mean "brake" and you'll confuse a person and cause an accident. People sometimes say "decelerate" but once again, that is NOT a term in physics, it's meaningless, because accelerate is change in velocity, so there's no term for "negative change" in velocity, since negative change is just change, however colloquially we accept that accelerate means speed up and decelerate means slow down. Don't try to use physics terms while speaking to someone in every day driving scenarios - depending on context you need to adjust your speech.

So in conclusion, when you're cooking bell peppers are vegetables and not fruits. If you're teaching a botany class, a bell pepper (or rather Capsicum, as they are known in botany) is a fruit.

text: Saying that you could just eat animal feed instead of meat is incorrect and a gross oversimplification. Farm animals help utilize nutrients and sources of food that humans either don't want to or simply cannot eat. They also metabolise them into a more digestible form and sometimes even create compounds we ourselves cannot make. And the feed they process doesn't go to watse, as their feces are used as potent fertilizer and it all goes back into the cycle. Farm animals make farming efficient and more sustainable, which is the reason they caught on in the first place. If farming animals was inefficient, neolithic humans that domesticated animals would die out and only those just farming crops would remain. Instead, we can observe the opposite.

text:
I bought a brand new refrigerator in 2005 for $500.  In 2015, I had to get the auto defrost fixed, but that's all I've done to it.  It's still running today.  

And of course you can cook at home cheap, but you have be smart about it.  Smart shopping, smart cooking.  The staples, of course, beans, rice, potatoes, pasta, etc.  And if you can afford a little more, then yeah, you can supplement the staples and get some decent meals out of them.  I always try to keep bell peppers, onions, and tomatoes handy, and other fresh vegetables when I want something in particular, or can get them on sale.  Squash, zucchini, rutabagas, eggplant, sweet potatoes, whatever.  Canned veggies are always my backup for emergencies, especially peas, corn, and green beans.  I also do frozen veggies because they last a long time in the freezer and don't lose their nutritional value due to flash freezing processes.  My main frozen goto is broccoli, although I like to do Winter blend (broccoli and cauliflour) or California blend (broccoli, cauliflour, and carrots), and brussel sprouts.  Chopped spinach is also usually fairly cheap, but again, you just have to go to the stores and see what's cheaper.  

I like my cheese, dadgummit, but I found that cream cheese is a little bit cheaper than block cheese, and makes a good substitute for other cheeses, is fairly versatile, as it can be used in both savory and sweet dishes. 

Meats?  I used to do processed meats like hot dogs all the time, but they're so plain and processed.  Hot links and sausages are also somewhat processed, but not as much, and have more flavor.  As for other meats, obviously pork and chicken are almost invariably cheaper than beef.  If you can't stand the thought of doing without meat, and I can't, you can at least help by getting chicken and pork instead of beef.  Chickens and pigs use less resources than cows.

And don't get me started on politics.  Seriously.

text:
This is the second time this week I am told something that was beaten to the punch 120 years ago by Peter Kropotkin, anarchist philosopher and natural scientist. In his work the conquest of bread he touches on the fact that home cooking(and other domestic work) can be inefficient, and his home country of Russia was very poor. He advocated for the creation of communal kitchens where people can still feel the joy of cooking when they want to, but also have ready access to high quality and low cost hot food. He also thought these kitchens would produce products for home cooks that they might need and would be inefficient to produce on their own in bulk such as stock. When I read this a few years ago, I thought it was interesting, but didn't think too much of it. Turns out he had really good reasons for saying the things he said and was in touch with the poor peasants of Russia.

He also thought that this type of centralized domestic work(including child care, cleaning, and clothes washing) would liberate women.

text:
I have a hard time not using meat, I love meat, but I do try to 'cut' my meat with plant-based protein sources when possible. The completeness of protein arguably matters but probably not as much as people say, from the studies I've read you can usually see an effect in a highly controlled environment... but I don't live in a highly controlled environment, I can just as well consume say... 5g more protein and probably make up for the difference. 5g is not a significant percentage increase. Not to mention that other anomalies in my diet probably dwarf the protein quality a lot.

That being said, meat has a good nutritional profile (and when I say meat I really mean all animal flesh, fish and poultry included even though some people like pretending they're not meat) and tastes really good so it's very hard to avoid for me. Ultimately it's much easier for me to meet my nutritional needs with meat than with a vegetarian diet, and because I live in a climate unsuited for growing the majority of vegetables a lot of the environmental benefits are lost and so are most of the cost savings for that matter. At least my onions are cheap, a dollar fifty for a single onion is outrageous.

text:
I appreciate videos like this. I‚Äôm poor, and during Covid I followed a lot of your videos because I had to learn to cook. We got most of our food during that time from food pantries, and believe it or not the food pantry provides a lot of variety; at least where I‚Äôm from in Springfield Massachusetts. It was like a mystery box you‚Äôd receive of meats, canned goods, and fresh produce. I got a whole Porkloin from one of the boxes and had no idea had to cook it, and followed your video on it. Sometimes we‚Äôd randomly get lamb, or veal shanks. I used my food stamps to buy any ingredients I needed to properly follow your recipes and to build the spice cabinet I‚Äôm proud of today. I even thought of making a YouTube channel called ‚ÄúFrom the Pantry‚Äù where I‚Äôd cook food I‚Äôd get from the food pantry but my living environment wasn‚Äôt really conducive for producing content lol all‚Äôs to say i appreciate your videos and your political self-awareness most YouTubers lack that. And I want to somewhat kill the misconception that poor people can‚Äôt get a variety of foods, or eat well. Food pantries provide a lot of variety, it‚Äôs just that a lot of folks are too embarrassed to go to them, and they have so much food! üòï My grandmother volunteers for one and the amount of large bags of sweet potatoes, and onions they have left at the end of the week is crazy. They‚Äôre begging people to pick this stuff up, but some folks are too proud to take a hand out a lot of the time.

For anyone struggling please go to a food pantry near you if you can. It‚Äôs worth it.

text: I grew up upper middle class and now am just regular middle class, but in between there was a period when I was legit poor, a short time but I had to go on welfare and it sucked. I was eating mostly oatmeal, peanut butter, rice and beans, and cucumbers. Eggs sometimes. I used to collect Shopper's optimum points (back when that meant something, Canadians will know) and when I got enough of them I'd cash them in on the grocery section. That's how I afforded the eggs. Anyway, my main regret from that time is that I considered using food banks/food pantries and refused, because I thought they were for people who were more deserving than me (I thought the situation I was in was entirely my fault and I didn't deserve to use the pantry). If you are poor enough you know the dollar amount in your bank account down to the cent, if you are walking instead of taking transit, if you are eating plain oatmeal for dinner, then you are definitely allowed to use the food pantry. It's for you. Use it.

text:
17:29 I have a name for this phenomenon. I call it 'The Truffle Oil Effect'. I named it for a three day period where I went to a bougie country house in the Home Counties with my paternal grandparents then a bougie trendy restaurant in Central London with some of my extended family on my mum's side. At both places (by sheer coincidence) the only edible vegetarian option was 'Truffle Oil Risotto'... In both cases (even after the first time) I was like 'I like risotto! This won't be too bad!' Both times the risotto came, I brought the first forkful to my mouth and felt my entire body sag with disappointment. 
Truffle oil (to me at least) tastes disgustingly of feet!  It tastes the way bad foot odour smells! I have never wanted that taste in my mouth! I will not eat anything with truffle oil on it! 
I am convinced that the reason they put truffle oil on these dishes was in absolutely NO way related to any judgement about its effect on quality, it was because they realised they could charge three times as much for a truffle oil risotto as they could for your bog standard risotto! 
Waitrose (supermarket in the UK) is terrible for this! They're the posh people's supermarket so all their stuff is 50% more expensive than you'd find in Tesco, Sainsbury's or Asda and, to justify it (as counterintuitive as it seems) they make it all worse with fancy prestige ingredients that don't taste as nice!
Worst part is, I know there are snobs out there who'd hear that whole explanation and brush me off as having an unrefined palette!

text:
Lumen is a good example of technology solving the problems of a society ruled by technology.
The better alternative: Eat healthy, all fine. No app needed, no personal counselor for fat/carb balance analysis. All this complexity is the second level of making bank, with the first level being making bank with making people unhealthy.

And your approval of a work-hard society is very conventional, but the focus is on the means, not the ends, so it turns unhealthy. A healthy society does not fixate on making people work hard, but on balance. Someone who has no time to do absolutely nothing becomes sick, often without being aware of it because it is a societally approved sickness.
There is no need to push people towards ingenuity. It is the same con game: You only seem to need such to cope with the growing problems of a sick society.

Meat is a special treat? Kinda culturally narrow-minded. Different times and different regions may have meat as a staple ingredient.

text: I'm vegan and while I would not consider myself poor, I live at home with parents and have the privilege to only have to pay 10% of my wages in board so I have a lot more free income than others in my same position, I still only make less than ¬£1000 a month which really dosent go far after car insurance, board, car repairs and all the other life stuff so I really scrimp on food, furst of all batch cook, if you have the space  I make 2-3 portions everytime I cook and freeze them, it saves on cooking costs and time, one of the biggest thing stops people cooking for me personally. Secondly, vegan food is cheap, and where you can and have the storage space you can easily bulk buy your carbs, some proteins like lentils and dried beans, which saves on cost in the longtime. Finally, stick to your list and dont let food go to waste, always use stuff up, like use leftover slightly stalewraps to make tortilla chips or freeze onion, garlic and ginger before it goes bad to prolong its life

text: I don't remember what your fridge was from previous videos, but a 2000 era subzero fridge probably could have been repaired for under $1k and would have been more reliable in the long run. newer high end fridges all have circuit boards that do not last. my friend has a fridge and freezer that would be 30K to replace and when it was on the fritz and the GE tech said the part they needed to fix it was no longer available in their part system. text: one great benefit of batch cooking is that there is less cleanup. It is the same amount of cleanup as one meal cooked independently, but it lasts so many more days that you don't have to keep doing the dishes every day. Also, heating up batch cooking is a lot faster than ordering food, so you save time there too. I honestly think that one of the main reasons I have good financial habits is that I was taught to cook, like to cook, and continue to batch cook twice a week. It has saved me hundreds of thousands of dollars over the years.

text:
"I'm glad I live in an economic system that incetivises people to work hard [at the threat of poverty, homelessness, starvation] and make more money"
Is in complete contradiction with
"I think the fruits of our labour should be distributed more equally and not hoarded up by 1% of the population [whom have that wealth via owning things and not working]"

You don't seem to know the first thing about your economic system. Capitalism does not incetivise people to work hard, but to hoard wealth. Specifically, it incentivises capital accumulation at the expense of a working class. 
If you think billionaires are working billions of times harder than a fast food worker, you are delusional. And if you think they work a billion times smarter than them, then you are very stupid. I mean, have you seen elon musk? But hyperbole aside, even the smartest billionaire isn't a billion times smarter than your average person. It's not difficult to see that a lot of luck and circumstance were what allowed them to start a good business, and then capitalism rewards capital with more capital, which compounds. 
Even if a billionaire started working 100 times harder than the avergae person, they certainly don't need to keep working that hard once their investments make money for them (ie capital)

A system that rewarded hard work would not even have an owner class, making money from other people's work by abstractly "owning" a piece of the means of production. If any of you disagree, just remember to tip your landlord and lick their soles when they come to collect.

text:
That meritocratic line has always been BS- the more money you have, generally the less hard you work, if you look at the system as a whole. 

At a certain point, all you have to do is hold money and grow fat on the dividends from the investment, and not work at all- a far cry from a system that benefits people for working hard. 

While on the other hand, you have people working multiple jobs and destroying their bodies just to get by. It's not even like it's historically been true; coal miners never had more than the robber-barons, and they worked far harder than them.
author: @healdrop9313

text:
In my opinion, the thing that is mostly always correct is "the system rewards lack of morals", either by people doing shady business, scaming others, lying, taking credir for other people's work, or by puting aside family and health in order to get rich. That Doesn't mean that all rich people have done that. That also Doesn't mean that poor people never do it. But (mostly) all people that do it are able to get one step ahead.
That being said (even though not All the time) working harder and smarter does bring better results than being lazy and doing low quality work. However, since there are Many other things influencing the system, like the lack of morals mentioned before, the fact that price is not mainly related to quality of product/service, etc, you can't say that people lack those qualities just because they don't make much money.
Making one sided implications on text makes things a bit confusing...a Math expression  would make things simpler üòÖ
author: @auricia201

text:
¬†@healdrop9313¬† What you said is generally true, but rich people that do nothing at present most of the times have invested a lot of effort early in their lives and have started with regular jobs. Maybe they had luck, were smarter, had help, or something else that made they have better results than the average person, but that doesn't take away their effort. 
The problem is when people start assuming that poor people are lazy and unqualified.
author: @auricia201

text:
¬†@auricia201¬† That's also a myth? The richest in our society all started with generational wealth; Elon's father had an apartheid diamond mine, Bezos' parents provided money to keep Amazon open so he could undercut everyone, Trump's infamous "small loan of a million dollars", and on and on.

Rich people inherit their wealth. They might start a company to exponentially multiply it, but they weren't ever "poor and motivated by the desire to improve their conditions", they'd have already been able to just coast on the money they inherited.
author: @healdrop9313

text:
¬†@healdrop9313¬† of course there are people who inherited their wealth, I didn't say that didn't exist. But even generational wealth had to come from somewhere. It started with someone working hard and achieving that wealth.
 It's not a myth just because it doesn't apply to All rich people ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

I don't even think being rich is a worthy life goal, but Assuming all rich people are silver spoons is unjust, prejudiced, and it's even a disservice to poor people who could have the same chance (note: chance) if they considered that a worthy goal for their lives. 

Assuming all rich people were always rich and all poor people will always be poor is just self pity, doesn't help anyone, and widens the gap between socio-economic groups
author: @auricia201

text: ¬†@healdrop9313¬† They "all" started with generational wealth? As in 100%? Seems like a pretty extraordinary claim that would require some hard evidence.
author: @akirak1871

text:
@ ‚Äúassuming all rich people are silver spoons is prejudiced‚Äù lmao. Tell me you don‚Äôt know how power dynamics work without telling me. 

For the record, I am prejudiced against those in power- any society which is neither actively improving on it‚Äôs flaws and has flaws ought to be, because it means those in power aren‚Äôt using their power to make the lives of everyone better. 

Anyways, I‚Äôm not talking about the top 1% when I say wealthy. You can get wealthy by starting a company, and there are funds for startups. The point I‚Äôm making is- who funds those venture capitalists?

Those at the actual top of our society aren‚Äôt the 1%- they‚Äôre a tiny fraction of that. The richest of our society don‚Äôt make their money by owning a company or working hard, but by expanding existing wealth through speculation and markets- which is a lot easier to do if you start with enough money to bend the market to your will, which can be done easily enough by buying politicians. 

If you don‚Äôt start with a bunch of money, you can‚Äôt expand it in this way and reach those heights of power. And those are the people who are actually capable of influencing our world. Which, again, they mostly do to balloon their wealth even further.

If you can‚Äôt double your wealth through forcing an economic recession, you‚Äôre not in the wealthy class. And only a tiny fraction- the so called 1% of the 1%, are that rich, and you can‚Äôt get there if you started from nothing- these people started from a pretty hefty something and have spent their whole lives multiplying their hoard.

text: Except no, doing away with animal agriculture, especially cow farming, will NOT be better for the environment. The vast majority of the beef made in the US is made in West Texas, the Oklahoma panhandle, northeast New Mexico, and South East Colorado. We raise cattle there because thats where the dust bowl was... regenerative agriculture via cow farming reversed the dust bowl and has prevented another one from happening. Simply growing crops is HORRIBLE for the environment. WAY WAY worse than cow farming. Cows are not raised indoors for the majority of their lives, not even a quarter of it. The only legally defining characteristic of a factory farm is one where the animals stay indoors for just 45 days out of the year or more... you wanna know what happens for a month in the summer and a month in the winter? Deadly temps. They have to come indoors or they die. The rest of the year they are grazing on fields that have previously been left alone for long enough to regrow grasses, after having crops grow on them for a few years. Thats the cycle in cow farming that regenerates the land. Cow farming is literally better for the earth than simply cropping the shit out of land, draining it of all it's nutrients.

Onion, garlic, salt, white vinegar and hot sauce are the staples I always have, even when I'm doing OK monetarily. Right now, we are struggling to survive, and can't afford sofrito or adobo, but I have frozen onion and garlic, which I call good enough in my book.

Adam, it isn't our fault. It is luck, it is not just the "rig  system". I am in a very dangerous yet peculiar situation because I said no to a rich guy.

I'm a married woman. I love my husband. I'm not leaving him for anyone. 

This guy has been a nightmare. I keep changing my social media because he stalks me and sends bullies after me. Where I live they are relentless. I can't leave because I'm poor, but I want to leave. 

It is luck. Good or bad it doesn't matter. I had the misfortune of meeting that man and not acting appropriately  - I have ADHD/Autism Lv1, which doesn't help - like a fangirl of a man that got lucky that his dad in a fit of rage, gave him his fortune in life so that his other son got squat.

text: One thing to remember when talking about people in poorer countries surviving healthy on grains and rice and beans and whatnot was a US Army study done during WWII. The army was surprised to learn that Chinese troops survived OK on just rice, so did some experiments in the States. The US soldiers fed the same amount of rice adjusted for the weight of the soldiers, found they got sick fairly quickly. The difference, after getting samples of the Chinese rice was the number of bugs and larva in that rice, I've read. Makes sense. Sounds gross, but it's basically cooked animal protein, or as Adam has pointed out on this channel, more like rice and baby crabs or shrimps, :-) :-)

text: The frustrating thing about the point about meat is I don't know what you're expected to do if you're diabetic. I'm not personally but I have people in my household who are or who are pre-diabetic and so I've been exploring low carb diets and leaning harder into meat has been one of the best dietary changes that doesn't make you feel miserable about what you're eating. So many vegetarian and vegan recipes still rely on carbs, there's always rice or pasta or bread somewhere in there. To go low carb and more vegetarian I feel like you'd have to basically eat like a rabbit all the time eating nothing but leafy greens, which might be fine sometimes for a particularly healthy meal but idk when you're on your 50th salad or plate of broccoli or kale or whatever I feel like you're gonna be craving either a nice steak or some fried chicken or something or a nice big plate of pasta or a sandwich on some nice bread.

text:
¬†@gavinking-smith1656¬† This is a very first-world perspective on things, I think. Yes, the US is fucked up. Yes, people should not have to work two jobs to afford a room in someone else's house. Yes, necessary medications should not cost hundreds of dollars. Yes, nobody should have 450 billion dollars and be able to buy the government. However, there are SO many places in the world where people are terrorized by war, famine, or unjust social systems. Only 17% of the world's population lives in a developed country. So, yes, relative to most people on the planet, our lives are amazing and we have significant economic freedom. 

I almost feel it's disingenuous to say that the minority of people in this country can't move up the economic ladder by working hard. There are a variety of social systems in place (hopefully they stay in place) that can provide people with housing, jobs, healthcare, food, education, etc. Now of course there are extenuating circumstances where people can't access those systems, maybe because of geographic location or the social systems are overburdened or the individual themselves has some issue like drug abuse or disability, and those circumstances are where the shortcomings in the American system are most obvious, see: Appalachia, Kensington, Skid Row, etc. However, those extenuating circumstances are just that: extenuating. You CAN improve your lot in life by working hard. Is it unreasonably difficult in the US, a country that isn't terrorized by the aforementioned war and famine (note I exclude unjust social systems)? Absolutely. However, compared to most of the world we've got it pretty good, and weirdly the way poor people speak about themselves in this country is an example of the privilege they hold--most poor people in the world can't speak for themselves.

text: On my tightest budget I microwaved eggs, cheese and butter into a little Tupperware thing perfectly shaped for quick breakfast burritos with pico de gallo. For lunch (and a lot of the time also dinner) I prepped a heavily buttered and seasoned bean burritos. But my favourite budget prep would have to be whatever roast meat was on sale, slow cooked with homemade taco seasonings, and the same prepped grated cheese and pico, all while a few hardshell corn tortillas heated up. Timed myself and averaged 35 mins start to finish for the most delicious and affordable whatever meat tacos for three months straight.

text:
I spend $75CAD ($52USD) a week to feed 2 people. And I cook pretty nice meals. And yes, I live in a high cost of living area. Less meat, a good number of dirt cheap meals which "subsidize" the nicer meals. It works.

And yeah. I buy my onions and potatoes in 10 pound bags. I buy my tomatoes canned. I buy my beans dry. I make my own ginger paste. I debone my own chicken thighs and render fat from the skin, stock from the bones plus veggie scraps.

It's.. Very time consuming. And yeah i do often have to eat the same thing several days in a row I don't blame anyone who doesn't want to go this route.
