text:
ive been taking advice from your channel for a long time on how to cook cheaper, even in ways that sound just wrong or going against tradition to make cooking less wasteful in the ways that matter to me, whenever i sear meat in a pan, i use water to deglaze the stuff stuck to the pan, not to make a sauce immediately, but to boil water for the pasta i'll have alongside the meat i made (usually chicken or whatever cheaper cut of meat i can get). and then instead of dumping out excess water when the pasta is done, i only put in as much water as i need to cook the pasta until its done, adding any seasonings and vinegar and honey i usually put in, and by the time the pasta is done cooking, the water boiled off and reduced to a sauce for the pasta and meat i made.

its very obviously not the cheapest way to cook, but its the cheapest way to cook using what i normally have available to me, because i hate draining the pasta water, it always felt so wasteful to dump about a liter of water into the sink, even if you retain some of the cooking water for sauce. i save some extra water money by only having 1 pan to clean afterwards and like 2-3 utensils, and so on. thank you for teaching me to be less wasteful when cooking, and how to enjoy cooking more by cooking by feel rather than being fussy over measurements, youve changed my life quite considerably for the better because i used to eat a lot trashier before i found you.

text:
Adam I love you buddy but what even is this video? You don't need to go off on a tangent about how science doesn't actually consider poor people to be dumber than rich people. It's irrelevant to cooking, nobody would have ever suggested that here, so why bring it up?

You didn't even finish the recipe, instead of moving onto the rice or at least showing the final dish you veered off into a bit about your $15,000 refrigerator and then just ended the video. Did what you made here even get eaten? No "truth about cooking on a budget" was revealed here, no total costs outlined, nothing.

It's totally fine that you make cooking videos for the middle to upper class home cooks. You don't need to apologize for telling people to run their oven for an hour or showing them how to cook a steak. But you certainly aren't making life better for poor people by half-assing a cheap recipe and then patting them on the back and telling them that they aren't stupid, and you aren't making yourself look any more relatable by posting a video that comes across more as a satire of out-of-touch youtubers than an honest attempt at sincerity.

text:
I would say you spent too much on your refrigerator. I got a ridiculous mini fridge and a refrigerator like yours all for 1500 bucks. I bought display models that were of models that were discontinued and replaced with new models. So I have water and ice in the door and it's huge and side by side freezer and all that and I even got a mini fridge for between when I bought it and when it was delivered and installed and yes the 1500 included installation and delivery too because I am lazy. So the mini was to give me something and I still use the mini which I put stock pots of giant batches of food in. It's mini but not so mini it doesn't store a lot of food and it has its own freezer that can actually store icecream and stuff so yeah I got a lot more fridge and freezer than you for a tenth the cost.

So my tip. Buy the display model. Especially if it's one of a model that's going away. Because they want to get rid of it and selling it to you for a discount is better than paying to have it scrapped or something. So yeah, buy the floor display models. They are awesome and work great. Also you save a lot of money so if you're supposed to be giving tips for people on a budget, there's a practical tip.

text:
>odds are if you're within the sound of my voice right now, you live in a country where you've never met a person who has rickets or scurvy

While I 100% get the point of what you're saying, this line just made me giggle. Cause... while I live in the states, hell, I shopped at Publix just like you for the vast majority of my life. Yet I know SEVERAL people who have had scurvy, and one with rickets.

But, that's just the nature of statistics. While odds are, those odds suggest there are those on the other side. It makes me think of how my brother a couple years ago got ran over by a work truck giving him 'compartment syndrome' (it's where pressure in a muscular compartment has restricted blood flow and can lead to nerve damage and even loss of limb). I brought my brother to the hospital, they couldn't handle the case and I then had to take him to the next (and yes, I drove him to both, because the interhospital ambulance was out of our budget). The hospital he ended up in was a teaching hospital full of med students so groups of them were excitedly coming by to check out the compartment syndrome because it's not super common and missing this case might mean missing it all together during their time there as a student. The students were commenting on this fact to us and we're like:

"Huh... this is like the 3rd case we've been personally party to. Let alone the people we've met who have had it in the past."

Note... I get that could be interpreted as a little sad. But yeah, it make me giggle. I don't know why. Scurvy? Lol, we would throw lemons at our roommate cause he got scurvy.

edit - and I reached the end of your vid with your somber note about poverty. Just wanted to say my "ha ha, scurvy, lol" was prior to that somber note. But it is true what you say about it's not necessarily your skills that make you poor, just a screwed up chance. And the reason I know many people who have had things like scurvy is because poverty. I thankfully dodged it just cause my mom knew how to navigate healthy food on a budget... which is to the whole skill thing. My mother was very smart, but dirt poor... brains don't necessarily give you everything to be wealthy despite what some tech bro thinks. I am a tech bro... technically... I'm a programmer/software engineer. I've had juniors under me scoff at poor people and when I give them a weird look they get real defensive or even ponder why I'm defending poor people when clearly I'm not poor and I worked hard for my money. I laugh and point out... no... I'm not wealthy. I grew up dirt poor and the only reason I'm where I am is not because of programmer smart brain, but because my parents died when I was 20, and the insurance money surrounding the accident gave me that little oomph to climb out of that hole. "I earned my lot in life, I worked so hard at my 4 year degree." Honey... my father worked 100 hours a week for 30+ years. Working hard != good money.

text:
I looked into the refrigerator he bought from the brand Sub Zero and I believe the depth is 24".  When looking at Home Depot and Lowes, it seems that most counter-depth fridges are at minimum 28-30" deep, so that would stick out considerably and not just be an eye sore but an obstacle.  You can see that the fridge has the island in front, so it would potentially create a very tight spot.  On top of that, when they open the fridge that could even cause clearance issues with the door.  

Adam is a cook too.  The sub zero fridge has a capacity of about 24.7cuft, which isn't a lot.  By limiting the size they might have had to go with a <20 cuft fridge, which would make storing larger items potentially impossible and generally not be very pleasant to own, considering I know many people who need two refrigerators.

text: You could probably make that takeout meal for cheaper than 14 dollars, because you'd be buying larger amounts of each thing and making a larger dish.  Or using the leftover food that didn't go into the bowl for other things.  But yes either way, cooking cheaply requires intentionality, a determination to get the right kinds of foods at the right kinds of prices, and a decision to never let a single bit of food go to waste.  It requires a good understanding of cooking theory and also creativity, to use everything you already have.  In most cases you should NEVER just go the supermarket and buy every single thing you need for a special meal.  At most, get one or two ingredients or spices to supplement what you already have.
author: @PlaySA

text:
I know I have the privilege of a cooking background, but I think its important to comment on the middleground between the two sides of this argument. 

An approach I used which worked really well is to just look at what Meats are on sale, and try to plan out meals around that which use common, overlapping ingredients. 
If you buy something like pork chops, you can use a lot of the same veggies to make Burritos, a stirfry, curry, a flatbread or steambuns. The only real difference is the carb you're using and how you assemble everything together, and a lot of carbs are dried, or last a pretty long time. If you buy Tortillas for burritos, you can use them for for a lot of other things in the coming weeks. 

I'd agree with Adam if you're really, really struggling and just getting by, but I feel he's speaking from a really extreme example here, and most people probably have a bit more wiggle room if we're being realistic. 

Another thing is just, be creative. There's no reason you can't make Pizza at home, but yes, if you're making 1 pizza, it isn't cost effective. You can 100% Freeze home made Pizza's though. Just Par cook them with just sauce on them and focus on getting the crust pretty well along, then next time you go to cook it, you really just need to let it defrost, and use the oven to crisp it up and melt the cheese/heat the toppings. Will it be as good as fresh pizza? No, but if you really want Pizza, and can't justify cooking 1, doing 10 and freezing the other 9 would dramatically fix the energy cost issue while making the pizza way cheaper the next 9 times you want one.

text:
I'm cooking up food for weeks right now, and yeah, it sucks. People say, "Just work harder, just work smarter," but that idea just isn‚Äôt true anymore. We don‚Äôt just budget money‚Äîwe budget energy. And cooking at home after work costs energy. Sure, it saves money if you could be working more instead, but when you‚Äôre already maxed out, it‚Äôs still a win.

But‚Äîand it‚Äôs a big but‚Äîthere are only so many hours in a day, and energy isn‚Äôt infinite. The system we live in doesn‚Äôt just fail people; it actively grinds them down. You can‚Äôt just work harder or be smarter to keep up if you don‚Äôt even have the energy left to try. That‚Äôs something you should‚Äôve done before you were poor‚Äîbut of course, you couldn‚Äôt have known that then.

And yeah, if we could work more, we could earn more. Maybe then we‚Äôd eat better, maybe we‚Äôd buy back some of our time. But that depends on your job, your qualifications‚Äîand you couldn‚Äôt have known back then what qualifications would matter now. Some people just got unlucky. And in my case? Other things happened, so it wasn‚Äôt even an option.

Yes, the system should be different. And sure, this isn‚Äôt the reality we live in. But why not make it a reality where being poor doesn‚Äôt mean barely surviving?

And for those who say, "Just get better qualifications!"‚Äîhow? We don‚Äôt have the time because we need to work for what little money we make. We don‚Äôt have the energy because we‚Äôre already stretched to the limit. And we can‚Äôt just take a break or switch jobs, because that means earning even less. When you‚Äôre only barely surviving, you can‚Äôt afford to take a hit.

We‚Äôre stuck. Really stuck. What we need is luck and a break‚Äîwhich, again, depends on luck. And even then, just catching a break isn‚Äôt enough. We‚Äôre so drained from years of grinding just to stay in place that before we can even think about improving our situation, we have to recover first. And that takes time. Being poor wears you down‚Äîmentally, physically. You work for years, you try harder and harder, and somehow it still gets worse.

And funnily enough, the cheap foods that were supposed to be the safety net? They‚Äôve gotten more expensive faster than the expensive foods. The basics‚Äîthe stuff people rely on to stretch their budgets‚Äîare becoming just as unaffordable as everything else.

So if someone‚Äôs got a plan, please, do it. Because this? This isn‚Äôt sustainable.

text:
to the point of ones system adjusting as they eat more legumes regarding gas: I've been eating essentially this exact meal multiple days a week since November as I'm saving to buy a house and food is one of the easiest things to cut spending on if you're not already paying attention to your food budget, and I can confirm that, while maintaining a diet high in legumes for an extended period of time, the gas will lessen.

HOWEVER, one thing I didn't realize at first, is that the high fiber content of beans will draw moisture into your stool, so hydration becomes more important. 

First few weeks, good BMs. then I started having difficulty and realized it was because I hadn't been drinking enough water. Upped the water intake and the difficulty disappeared

text: I appreciate the message in this video. Last year, to combat rising food costs, I started cooking with dried beans for the first time, instead of canned beans. I was shocked at how massive the price difference was. I ate primarily beans and (brown) rice tacos, with homemade corn tortillas for my lunches. I calculated each meal was less than $1. At the end of the year we looked at the household budget and we'd spent less on food in 2024 than 2023 despite inflation, primary because I ate a ton of cheap beans and rice on cheap tortillas. It was both delicious and essential to our budget.
author: @GhaleonEB

text:
¬†@gtothereal¬† I've known A LOT of poor people who have opportunities in front of them but just won't take them. I get that people can end up poor due to circumstances that aren't their fault, and people are often rich through very immoral behavior. But some people seem to forget that there really are poor people who are keeping themselves there. 

One person I know is constantly rotating through entry-level service jobs, and those jobs usually end with her storming out over some disagreement with the boss, then it takes a while to find a new job because (surprise surprise) people are hesitant to hire a person who quit their last 15+ jobs in that manner. She has borrowed money from every friend and family member who would lend it, and has rarely paid it back. If anyone is too up-front about the need to get their money back, she starts the victimhood act and says things like "I might be living on the street because I'll miss rent, but don't worry, I'll get you your money" and then goes on social media and makes passive-aggressive posts about "all the greed in this world". Yet somehow she affords a one-week vacation every year.

text:
¬†@Brent-jj6qi¬† I feel like this false dichotomy comes up a lot because people don't realize we no longer live in a "true" capitalist society, sort of.

Capitalism has been proven to be the most successful and largely best for the people economic model. The issue is that it's TOO successful, and we have reached the point that we'd be better described as a "corporatist" society.

The ideal of a capitalist society is that everyone has a roughly equal opportunity to put in capital and get out profit. Unfortunately, the individuals who did so early on in America and succeeded then passed their wealth onto their kids, or conglomerated slowly over the years into the ludicrous megacorps we see today.

This leaves very little room for the average person to actually participate in a capitalist society except as a consumer; most people are a glorified commodity rather than people with the opportunity to take control of their own destiny.

Capitalism is a great concept, as is the American Dream, but the current reality is that it no longer really exists.

text:
as a person who is currently poor (relatively, I make ~$26k a year to be transparent), you are also being extremely generous to keep the video simple. youre sticking to the traditional "stew household" style of frugal home cooking where you make a dish that lasts several days. if you get a freezer and learn to cook from scratch you can have 3, 4, even 5 different meals a week cheaply by buying components that can be stored. you can even supplement those meals with rice and beans as sides. buying whole chicken raw is cheaper than buying 3 breasts multiple times and can be made into multiple meals to stretch that chicken. the remains make stock. and even if you dont have property you can grow herbs and tomatoes easily at home with grow lights. the cost of electricity even in the worst 1st world country areas is cheaper than buying fresh herbs and tomatoes. literally as we speak I am setting up a shelf unit that I got for $20 with some $5 chicken wire to support vine tomatoes and 4 staple herbs.
butter can be made easily. cheese can be made easily (im stretching it a bit there though unless you just like cream cheese and cottage cheese). butter milk, yogurt, greek yogurt, ketchup, bbq sauce, mayo can all be made easily.
it will always cost more i the moment to make a dish than it will to just buy the dish as a chain, but when you buy the proper amounts of ingredients and consider what else can be made with the same ingredients you start to realize you can cut down a lot on meal prepping without sacrificing variety and all it takes is some of your time here and there.

text:
Your point at 3:25 is the real key to it. Plan around what you have, not what you want.

I keep my pantry stocked with a few basics (rice, beans, dried pasta, canned vegetables/tomatoes, various vinegars and lots of spices). I basically always have a bag of onions in a basket because I eat onions in everything and they keep longer than they last before I use the bag up. And my freezer is stocked with "whatever I found on sale." (so some pork chops, chicken thighs, a few steaks I got on clearance, half a gallon of broth I simmered down from scraps, a 4-lb lamb roast I got on an AMAZING coupon and am saving for Easter dinner, etc). 

I go through a day or two before the weekly grocery trip and plan a menu for the week around "what can I do with this stuff." Then buy whatever produce or niche ingredients I need to pad out the recipe. Do that for 3 big entrees (I cook big batches of a thing for me and my roommate to eat on for 2-3 days) for dinner, one more to meal prep my own lunches with. Then a few fresh fruits and nuts as snacks, some yogurt or some english muffins for breakfast. Re-stock the pantry around whatever basic staples I might be running low on. And check for good coupons or clearance sales for stuff to freeze for later. 

Right now I'm feeding two grown adults for a hundred bucks a week, plus a quarterly Costco trip to bulk-buy a few things. Which is pretty great given I'm in a HCOL area. And if I'm being honest? that menu still has room to make cuts, since it occasionally involves me splurging on a fillet of salmon, and the only beef I buy is the ultra-lean 93 or 96% stuff (85 is probably fine, but I was in a weight-loss kick last year and stocked up on the low-fat cuts).

author: @meneldal

text: ¬†@jmanius1¬† What I think you're missing here is that inherent in his given world view is the need for a lower class. In order for there to be something to work towards, there needs to be class divide. It's a really common failing of people in capitalist systems when analyzing said system to forget that it doesn't end with them. If the system "works right" everyone should be incentivized to work harder or smarter to get access to more luxuries. But that inherently means there's always a constant class of poor people to work out from. There's always someone in last place, there's always people being born into the class that has to work harder to get luxury. The system working as intended is, by design, equal parts working your way up the ladder and pulling yourself up by the bootstraps, and maintaining a population of poor people through no fault of their own. The system can't work if poor people don't exist, and yet it exists on the promise that with enough hard work everyone won't be poor. It's a system that's mission statement includes the ending of itself, and yet here we are decades down the line still tumbling further away from that possibility of everyone working their way out of poverty. It's clearly sugar coated meritocracy, no matter how many "luxury" or "but poor people should be a bit less poor ideally" there is tacked on to the end of any sentence. No matter how much face saving you play by throwing some mild socialist key phrases on at the end of the sentiment, at the end of the day by advocating for a system that incentivizes hard work and inventiveness through the restriction of goods and services, you are advocating for a system that only functions through a majority population of people kept purposefully under poverty lines and constantly living in a state of relative discomfort and insecurity to fuel that pipe dream.

text: @DOODKOOK¬† I'm not arguing about the premises of class structure. It's not "sugar coated" meritocracy. He's never said it's right. He's never said it's the only way. He's never said it shouldn't be challenged or adjusted or improved. He just said it is that way currently. You can argue that's complacency at best. I still don't see how it's meritocracy just because he mentioned he liked the idea of incentives. Even his statement at the end of the video directly goes against that meritocratic argument. It's not sugar coating, it's his opinion to like the idea of capitalism, but he clearly doesn't like the current results. Which means he's not blindly approving of the system just because it leans into what he'd normally intuit as fair. It's alright to wish that he'd be more heavily socialist, but it's strange to claim that he's actually some capitalist purist when he's being so critical of it in his own self-curated video. Tldr: he's not "sugar coating" meritocracy, he's someone who'd like to have meritocracy but recognized that's not how the world works right now. Very different things

author: @Leon-xn3pt

text: @DOODKOOK¬† also I'd like to challenge you with this. The existence of a "lower" class itself is capitalist jargon. People who work menial or labor focused jobs are not "lower" they are the backbone/foundation of our economy. But it is also true that these jobs require much less specialization and skill. The working class (better name for it) is necessary. Absolutely necessary, but so is the skills-focused class (doctors, plumbers, technicians, physicians). The main failure of capitalism is the fact that the capitalist class (those who own the capital) have been given too much control, which happens easily in capitalism. But to be clear, the working class is necessary and always will exist even in a communist framework. Even under capitalism, if our government did more than the bare fucking minimum, or worse collude with the capitalist class, a system resembling capitalism but redistributed much of the profits by taxes and workers rights and protections would fix a lot of issues people have. Advocating for a system that incentives hard work and higher efficiency DOES work when you also prioritize the well-being of the basic person in the system. There's no need to do one or the other. That's also a capitalist fantasy, that you can't both incentive and subsidize. It's definitely possible to do both, but lobbyists won't let that happen any time soon.
author: @jmanius1

text: ¬†@Leon-xn3pt¬† oh no sorry, i wasn't meaning your specific talking points or actions. i mean in the sense that if we start criticising people who are already on our side with their heart in the right place, especially ones that are speaking up against current issues, we aren't heading towards unity. this isn't a case of no one is up for critique, it's that there is a time and a place to discuss it and those fingers should be pointed at the top, not horizontally right now. even just witnessing that kind of aversion to stand together does not stir much hope in me

text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã¬†@DOODKOOK¬†you sort of imply there's a natural abundance of goods and services currently being restricted artificially that could be somehow "granted" given sufficient political or popular will. Maybe that's not what you meant and I may have misunderstood.

But I agree there's an extremely unfair distribution of resources and the #1 factor is probably what citizenship you're born with, something most people have no control over.

Also I agree there's a lot of moral ad hoc post-rationalization among progressive-presenting capitalists but I'd extend it to most leftists in rich countries as to why it's okay for them to personally hoard resources (compared to the global median). One of those is refusing to acknowledge that they personally are (likely) wealthy from a global perspective and are personally part of the wealthy group who needs to give their money away to reduce global inequality. If someone is actually living in absolute poverty in a rich country this doesn't apply to them.

I'm not being facetious, what moral argument is there for having a $10,000 car when you could sell it and personally and directly save 2 or 3 lives by donating that money to distribute basic treatments for childhood diarrhea in the poorest countries? Maybe also mosquito nets, that might be a bit outdated.

I personally have never bought the argument that there's no personal responsibility to change until the entire system changes.

Do I live that way? No, I'm living in a way that is morally and intellectually indefensible. I don't claim it's morally acceptable/desirable to hoard wealth as the right-wing do or that it's solely the fault of someone else who is richer than me as the left-wing very often do (it's not really a core tenet of socialism or communism, more an emergent property among many adherents due cognitive dissonance).

Am I better than other people? No, probably worse, I don't even have even a fictive moral figleaf to hide behind. What's my point? I guess I'm just jealous of other people's ability to think of themselves as a good person.

Not an elite group controlling the state and dictating what everyone does. Modern democratic socialism is barely socialism at this point it's just tempering capitalism with a little bit of human decency and a little less greed.

text: @Ynno2¬† Despite the fact that this all reads very "you critique society and yet you participate in it", my point with withheld luxuries is mostly that they're utilized as a tool to reinforce the pipe dream of "working harder and you could have this kind of life". The specifics of those luxuries and their real or imagined scarcity isn't really important, they're usually products of capitalism manufactured to be goals to chase indefinitely while also bolstering the wealth of shareholders and directors. As for the rest of your comment; these are all infinitely complex concepts and systems, and bringing a global lens to it is only one facet of the argument. There's people who's entire lives are dedicated to research and writing on one small aspect of leftist critique and even then the discussion never feels finished in any meaningful way. It's easy to get yourself trapped in those thought patterns of global scale and systemic woes pitted against individual action and exploitation, but all that really does is result in you spinning your wheels. There are actions we as individuals can take to ease the wrong doings of a capitalist economy. There are also very large scale problems that cannot be fixed without huge systemic reform and the dismantling of entire systems of governance. Both things are true and don't make the other futile. At the end of the day, the reality is it's very hard to force change from underneath a global system. We're forced to play the game, so to speak, and there's a level of moral corruption forced upon us in that regard. If every person who wanted a better way to live had to carry the full weight of guilt the system has manufactured, I don't think anything meaningfully productive would come from that and I don't think it makes you a better or worse person to try and reduce harm while maintaining a healthy lifestyle within the confines of your own circumstances.

text:
¬†@jmanius1¬† meritocracy is, when you think about it, actually pretty farcical itself, it's akin to saying "yay good things, nay bad things" but theres no there there it's purely aesthetic in practice, just a talking point to get people to buy in. in this case it actually ties in as the corollary response to incredulity at the famous cliche "it works in theory but not in practice," 

"how, exactly?" 

"you see dear boy, capitalism incentivizes personal industry, while communism incentivizes LAZINESS!" 

who determines what merit gets rewarded? how do they know to reward this kind of merit over another less desirable kind, or how will they know to reward what actually IS valuable and not just what theyre invested in treating as valuable. look at the justifications for the capitalist, "hes a job CREATOR", "the landlord gives you a place to live", etc these things are clearly false, things are only that way because thats how the system is set up but if you ask lots and lots of people theyll tell you thats a meritocracy

the way things work and the way they have for ~100-200 years is that the things you can produce are evaluated based on the relationship between the value it represents and the value that was put into it in the form of labor, if you work harder on something than it's worth, you lose out regardless of whether it's a good product that solves some kind of problem even in a new and novel way. there are countless instances of people making massive achievements throughout their life and dying penniless and forgotten, thats actually relatively common 

personally i think that since we all know the game here, since we all know 1. work needs to happen for life to continue and 2. austerity and constant pressure dont solve the problems that keep people from working,, that if we had a system that did solve those problems and we remained conscious of point 1. we can actually have an "association of free people using communal means of production and who self-consciously expend their many individual instances of labor-power as one social labor-power....The total production of this association of free people is...a social product. Part of its product is used as new means of production. This part remains social. Members of the association consume another part as their means of subsistence, however, and so this latter part must be distributed among them. How it is distributed varies with the social organism of production itself, and also according to the producers‚Äô corresponding level of historical development." (capital volume 1 pp54-55 reitter translation)

at the end of the day it's always going to be up to you to live a fulfilling life, but the means of subsistence probably should be provided even if you dont do that, as an investment in the future on the part of a united society. idk all of how to get there but if you eliminate waste to the end of profit then there would be more labor power to go around being consumed as use values, and society should prioritize efficiencies in that domain imo starting on the federal level and im not talking about doge

text: @random3po¬† I agree with most of what you said here, except in the sense of the idea of meritocracy only being used as a way to "buy in" people. The reason I say that is because it can be applied to a lot more than economic success. Now there are also MANY problems there, but fundamentally the desire to reward people for doing good things is pretty natural, so I don't like the villainization of anyone who has that viewpoint when they aren't trying to shove it down everyone else's throats. You can point out your issues with incentives without assuming the other side would not hear you out (unless you've been given reason to believe the other party is unreasonable). That's literally all I've been saying in all of my comments, but some people are assuming I'm defending meritocracy on its own. I just think it's okay for someone to like the ideal as long as they aren't blinded by its very real issues.
author: @jmanius1

text: @random3po¬† I said my interpretation was luxury food items, not nutritional variety. I'm talking raw vanilla bean vs imitation. You aren't missing out on much, but the price tag difference is huge, and you can afford to splurge every once in a while. Currently that's not how it is, unfortunately but I'd prefer a system where most people can try most things at least a few times regularly, but luxury items are more available to key contributers in society. Also in my view key contributers would be anyone who was an essential worker during the pandemic, which also isn't how the system works in capitalism (sad), but a different form of a meritocratic system could function that way. Meritocracy in itself (when not used to justify unreasonable poverty and hoarding of resources) isn't inherently evil and it's pretty natural to feel. That's my whole argument man. I'm not arguing about what's going on rn, in fact I heavily agree, i'm just saying that someone saying they like incentives isn't a sign of some horrible moral compass.

text:
You say it keeps you up at night that you've encouraged meat eating, but you've also done a huge amount to evangelize meatless alternatives, and beans in particular. And I think you deserve particular credit for your brand of very practical and rational philosophy of meat reduction instead of just professing vegetarianism outright.

I'd absolutely credit you with having the greatest impact on my own personal reduction of meat eating. I'm not a vegetarian, but I am eating a far greater number of meatless meals than I used to, and using a much smaller amount of meat in recipes that used to be meat focused. And beans in particular have been the greatest drop-in replacement for meat most of the time. I discovered I really like beans. I started ordering them from the indian takeout and discovered how much I love almost all of the vegetarian options they have.

You did alright. You've done what you could and done so in a way that I think is going to age well.
author: @cebo494

text:
I'm really not a fan your statement, "the fact it sucks to be poor is bad by design" and the implications that not being poor is an acceptable motivator to do better.  I work 65 to 70 hours a week at a min and I can barely pay my bills I don't think it's a motivating issue.  While I appreciate your minor caveat and your follow-up statements it doesn't really make up for the viewpoint IMO.

No one looks back even after their life improved and thinks oh yeah me being hungry for significant periods of time sure was a good thing.   When the fact of the matter being if you had been well fed to begin with you would have had the energy to have done better.

There is no reason people in a developed 1st world country should have anyone living in poverty.  There is room to elevate the bottom economic tears to an acceptable living level and still have plenty of motivation for those people to further improve their lives of their own accord.  Suffering should not be a method of gatekeeping people from success, nor is suffering a component of success.  Opportunity is much more meaningful motivator for people who are poor, and poorer people do not have as many opportunities due to their economic state.  If the burden of being poor is lessened significantly, opportunity is much more readily available.

text: The reality is that most people are just too lazy or do not have the time to cook at home, so takeout or mostly prepped meals are just more convenient. I.E buying a frozen lasagna from costco. Put it in the oven, frozen, start oven at 350f and give it an hour and you're done. then eat it from that container and throw away the container.  I do this as well, but max 1 per week, when I am really running out of time.  But, me bigger issue is 3 things for me: 1. lots of recipe's need 15-20 ingredients (spices, etc), pre-making stuff, like marinades, and trimming, carving, other work than most people are not excited about, so these things are only done on special occasions.  Personally, I do something else - I make a big pot of something and vary sides with it - I.E i Make stewed beef chuck (a simpler version of any stew recipe u see on YT), like 10lbs. It has 5 ingredients total. It's good in fridge for a week at least. And, I vary sides for it, from rice, to pasta, to potatoes, to just putting in  a bun, to anything else. I.E Beans, or veggies. You can do same. Also, I Cook 10lbs at a time a mix of onions, peppers, 1-2 other veggie you like. Then when you need to have dinner, u put meat, veggies, and reheat over some kinda carb - complete meal in 15-20 min. You can vary spices and types of meat/veggies, so it'll never be boring. It won't look at good as a takeout, sure, but it'll taste likely better (it has everything you like). If you do things like that, yes, it'll take time and will take a bit of planning and adjusting to and how you shop and maybe buying a dedicated freezer, but it also = about $200-$400 a months savings in food, which is about $2.5-5k a year, invested  = alot of $ over the  next 30-40 years :)

text:
My weekly grocery budget is 30-50 $. Lived on cheaper too but i fins this is far more sustainable. Secret is to buy bulk in first week like 10lb rice or big bags of pasta, oats.  Bulk prorien and 10lb onions, i only use ghee as fat so a 5lb of that, some dried beans and milk. 10$ worth of fresh veggies/flash frozen peas,carrots and other stuff for 2$ a bag.  Abput 50-60 bucks first week.  
From next week I just buy meat, milk , veggies ,yogurt.  All in all I spend at max 250$ thats including whey protien for my bulk. I prep my meals and more times than not I have left over ingredients by the end of month like beans, rice etc. 
I hit all my macro goals and eat very healthy food for way cheaper than i would if i eat out. Easily 10-15 bucks for any decent meal if I eat out here in Toronto. 
 
But its not easy the amount of time and effort to plan,shop,prep,cook,clean is a giant task. But once you get into the groove of it, the upfront cost  maybe a little steep depending on your equipment, comdiments etc but its extremely worth it. 

Oh i also buy dry spices every 3_4 months , may be costs me like 30-50$ bucks but they last forever. 

Its very possible and beneficial. Just needs a little effort üòä

text:
You nailed it right on the head there. It's a surprisingly common take. Most people dislike wealth inequality and don't think poverty is anything anyone should ever have to experience. BUT if you ask them if someone who didn't work as hard as they did, should not get the same "rewards" (ie. the same level of human joy, comfort and pleasure) they will almost universally say NO.

Because built into this culture mindset of individualism, is the idea that you have to have some else to compare yourself against to feel validated.  If someone worked less and ended up better than you, then that makes you some how worth less. And it's through hard work and the desire to "better" ones experience, that we derive worth and value to ourselves and society.

It's so blatantly capitalist propaganda but you can't really point that out, because it's so deeply ingrained in western culture that people take it for granted and are mostly prevent from realizing it.

And in a cruel twist of irony, Adam has literally spoken about his experiences with this. He's already "won" the race, and become super successful and doesn't need to work again.  And he's struggled (struggling?) with the fact that this hasn't made him happy. He isn't able to sit back and enjoy the good life.   According to this mindset he should be able now to sit smugly in the comfort of his rewards.   Unfortunately I don't think he's quite realized yet, is his dissatisfaction is a result of the whole idea being a lie/illusion.  You are on a treadmill chasing a carrot, that you are never supposed to reach. Once you step off and realize that you haven't actually been going anywhere, can only lead to a feeling of emptiness.

On an unrelated note, it is also a contributing factor to the pathology of billionaires. They have "WON' at the game, and so should be happy. But they aren't, and that's why they keep making money, keep reaching in that never ending cycle of greed. Because all they've been taught is that this pursuit will lead to validation and meaning. But it never comes and so they keep trying ever higher.

text:
I really hate a lot of the cooking discourse. Influencers will be like "this is a cheap easy meal for only 2$ a portion! Just buy a chicken breast, an onion, and then add these 15 ingredients you should have in your store cupboard and prepare it using these 5 pieces of expensive equipment you definitely have in your kitchen. It should be easy to make in only 20 minutes as long as you have already mastered knife skills, have 7 ramekins of preportioned ingredients and can multitask like a professional chef"

Problem is, if you're a single person living in an apartment who was never taught cooking, you don't have a fully stocked store cupboard with 15 ingredients and you might not have any kitchen equipment besides a burner and microwave. The startup cost is enormous and if you're not already a good cook who can make use of all the random stuff you have leftover that you only needed a small amount of for the recipe, you're wasting so many ingredients you won't be able to use. If you're not already good at cooking, that 20 minute recipe becomes an hour and a half, and cost $30 with all the "store cupboard" ingredients they assumed you already have. Half the time you aren't even good enough at cooking to produce an edible result so it just tastes awful for all that time and money. And if you're cooking for 1 instead of a family you have zero economy of scale, and a lot of times the serving sizes of the stuff that's sold affordably just aren't feasible for one person to use before they expire even assuming you're good enough to utilize them well in the first place. There's even the assumptions of like, I have a car to go buy huge packages of bulk ingredients when I am actually walking to the grocery store alone and carrying my stuff back by hand in tote bags or using the bus.

If I'm really trying to save money, actual affordable eating looks like degenerate girl dinners, just eating the most calorically dense to cost ratio food with the least processing and extra ingredients required. When I backpack on a shoestring budget and stay at hostels I eat stuff like bananas or refried beans heated up between tortillas or even just with a spoon from the can. They come pre spiced and are cheap and compact. The reason ramen is popular struggle food is that it's cheap, yes, but for the price it comes with all the seasoning and flavor included so you don't need to add anything else.

Plus, cost of cooking vs just buying food varies a ton depending on where you live, how much you need to eat, and what you're getting. I used to get lunch at a local indian restaurant for the equivalent of like 6 dollars, and it was a super filling nutritious vegetarian meal. A banana for breakfast is like 20 cents. And for dinner I'd buy something premade from the grocery store for like another $6 ish. Whenever I'd try to cook I'd usually end up in the red due to general inexperience and lack of ingredients. Sure I could eat bean soup and rice every single day for $3 a meal instead of 6 but it's such a small savings compared to the struggle and effort. Hell as sad as it is, you can get like 1200 calories of mcdonalds for $5 if you don't care about your health and just want calories. Now on the other hand if I lived in a more expensive place where buying a meal cost $15 then cooking becomes a much bigger savings.

text:
Yep, it's really hard to tackle a topic like this without coming off as offensive at worst, and tone deaf at best.

Just acknowledging that you are aware of the absurdity of having someone that just spent $15k on a refrigerator, demonstrating the economy of a 7$ dish that can feed a "poor" person, doesn't erase the problematic aspects of that.

Don't get me wrong, I appreciate him making the effort, but you can't erase the privilege's from the video.  There is a reason that society's views have shifted to the fact that for example, the very existence of a Billionaire is immoral, no matter how much philanthropy they perform.  Obviously a food YT isn't a billionaire, but the same idea holds.

There are going to be plenty of people watching this video for whom $15K could be a life changing amount of money. That doesn't mean Adam didn't work hard for his money, the YT hussle is no joke, a large amount of effort, and luck/good timing are involved.  But it's also psychologically proven that we are really bad at over believing how much of our success is due to our own effort and individualism. 

But that makes it so easy to cut the other way and very subtley espouse the idea that people who haven't been that fortunate, didn't do what you did, and that is what makes you different.  It's not that they deserve their situation in life, it's just that you got yours because you deserve it.   So much of that is ingrained in western culture, that inherent desire to compare ourselves against others to make us feel validated.  You can't have the idea that everyone deserves to live in abundant joy and happiness, and eat "good food every night", because that would somehow make the fact that you do it worth less.

I still like the video, there are good aspects, but you just can't erase this one point of it.  You sadly don't get to spend $15k "unintentionally" on a fridge, and still talk about "poor people", just because you didn't want to spend that money in the first place and so you aren't one of the "bad ones".    You can tell he feels weird about it, and he should, those feeling are honest.   But just because you aren't responsible for the inequality in society, and you feel bad about it, doesn't mean it stops being problematic.
author: @aggies11

text:
I can understand that someone with little knowledge in the kitchen would not be able to cook with that kind of recipes.
But just for your info, you don't actually need these 15 ingredients... most of them are spices, you can cook chicken even without them.
I always skip the garlic because I don't like it, I always skip ingredients that I don't have... and for the equipment if the recipe is not made with a simple stove/oven I don't even bother trying.
But you actually raised the real issue for a beginner: the sources. I needed a few months before I was able to find youtubers and websites that I actually trust and I was not 100% a beginner (my mom teached me how to cook pasta, eggs, and some other basic things). I wasted a lot in the beginning because the recipes were not good from the start (I can see it now, I did not when I started).
Good sources will teach you how to cook for real, they will teach you why you need to do what you are doing and what are the alternatives and if you can skip a step/ingredient/tool.
Good teachers are actually hard to find since anyone can make a viral video with an horrible recipe and get good reviews.
author: @LiefLayer

text:
¬†@LiefLayer¬† Yeah the problem is though if you aren't already good at cooking, you don't know what things you can skip or not. If you're just cooking chicken with no spices or seasoning you may as well not even cook chicken since it won't taste good anyway and should make something that uses cheaper and pre-spiced ingredients. To get good at any skill requires a lot of messing up and a lot of trial and error and that becomes paradoxical when you're trying to save money because you have to spend a lot of money (and time) messing up before you get to the point where you can save money reliably. Like every new cook has spent 30$ buying ingredients for a recipe that they somehow screwed up royally to the point that it's unsalvageable and now you're in the red. Again, there are start up costs a lot of people just overlook and a lot of skills people don't recognize involved and the advice ends up being like "just cook a stir fry bro" as a result. 

Weird analogy but I notice the same thing with like high ELO League of Legends players trying to give advice to noobs, they take for granted so much assumed knowledge and subconscious things they're doing that they're actually incapable of understanding or giving useful advice to a new player and just say platitudes like "get more gold and die less" not understanding the enormous gulf of practical knowledge and experience that goes into that. The best people to give advice to low ELO players are mediocre players who are just a little bit better than them and can still relate to what it was like being a noob. In the same way, the actual cooking advice that's helped me is never from food influencers but instead from normal people who are still only one step removed from being a terrible cook themselves and can give practical tips for my level. But there are very few cooking channels that are like "I am a terrible cook but here's an easy method I found for cooking serviceable dal curry on the stovetop seasoned with walmart brand spice mix and ramen packets."
author: @soasertsus

text:
¬†@soasertsus¬† Still, you need to eat... and if you eat outside everyday you will spend a lot of money. Trial and error for cooking will cost you about the same amount in the beginning or even more, but it will save you money in the long run. And if you cannot afford even that I don't think you can actually afford to eat outside.
You don't need to play LoL, so you can just play something else and call it a day.

Also for chicken, I got multiple ways to cook it with just salt/no spices and make it great:
1. Make a brooth. Even just the chicken (or even better and cheaper an hen) + water + salt is amazing (if you got an onion, a carrot and honey that's even better... if you got sage even better... but they are not needed). It just need time to cook (I think most people in US underestimate how good boiled meat is when done properly).
2. Cook it in a salt crust (salt here is cheap like 0,30‚Ç¨/kg, I know it's not that cheap in some places). I cooked it multiple time like that with just 1 lemon or 1 orange in the cavity and it's more than amazing.
author: @LiefLayer

text:
Alot of negative thinking here. You don't need everything to get started and alot of kitchen gadgets are just slight time savers. Dint have a whisk? Use a fork. No stand mixer? Use a hand mixer... that's all my grandma had!

You pick a recipe and get what you need to do it. If it needs a spice, buy bulk and get lots of the spice. Of it needs potatoes, onions, rice, beans, etc, again, buy bulk. A bit expensive at first, but you begin to add up a store of food and at cheap bulk prices. Stuff you now have on hand for another recipe.
Each dish with a new spice is more spices in your spice drawer.
I am at the point where I have almost everything on hand to make any recipe. I just need to restock when a bulk item gets used up.

Most appliances and utensils can be had from thrift shops.
90 percent of my pans, appliances, utensils are bought this way. Again, one recipe at a time. Things as I need them.
I have a big freezer and learned to can stuff.

I buy only discounted protiens. There is a yummy recipe for anything you can find.
So tonight I am making a huge stock pot of jambalaya. A 4 dollar packet of shrimp, a few cups out of a six dollar bag of pre cooked sausage. Two chicken breasts discounted to 6 dollars. My canned tomatoes. A bell pepper. Spices from my spice drawer. Pasta from the dollar store.
This will be frozen in single portions and family size portions.
Equipment needed... canning pot, stock pot, wooden spoon, chefs knife, cutting board, frypan or wok.
12 to 15 single portions. Multiple meals.
Last week turned a discounted 2 dollar huge bag of onions into caramelized onions for French onion soup.
Week before, clams from the dollar store, some of my bulk potatoes, carrots, frozen corn and a jug of cream. Spices, bacon.... multiple servings of clam chowder. Set the breadmaker before I leave, come home to fresh bread and a quickly heated up meal in the microwave.

So just go slow and add to your supplies, tools and repertoire.

More of that cheap shrimp found tonight. Lemons in the discount bin.... shrimp scampi tonight!

text:
@soasertsus¬† nope. Read it.
I got my hand mixer for 5 bucks... as I said... thrift store.
I can go to no frills right now and buy two individual potatoes for two bucks or a 5lb bag for..... two bucks. As I said, my five pound bag of discounted onions I got for 2 bucks as well. About the price of two individual onions.
Buying bulk SAVES money. By buying that bag of potatoes instead of just two potatoes, I have many, many meals I can make.
And as I said.... one recipe at a time. This recipe needs a certain kind of pan.... 4 bucks at the thrift store and you are set.
Never need to buy that pan again for any other recipe.

Just like I grew my own business. Crappy tools and only what I needed for the job. Let that one help pay for the tool I need o  the next job. Slowly growing until I had bigger, better jobs and now a shop full of professional tools.

Do not talk to me about not understanding poor.
Very ill for more than four years now. Not able to work. Tiny pension. Latest kitchen gadget for a recipe... air fryer. Thrift store again. 10 bucks.
Built up my kitchen and my experience just like that, one recipe, one step at a time.
I eat like a king.
author: @cecilbrisley5185

text:
@ You're still willfully ignoring the fact that some people CANT buy in bulk practically. Everyone knows buying in bulk saves money. What I'm telling you is that at that time it wasn't practical for me to do, I didn't have a car to carry big sacks of bulk food around or storage for them or a freezer to put the leftovers into or even the ability to consume bulk food before it's no good. Whenever I'd try I'd end up making a lot of waste because I couldn't efficiently use everything. 

Not everyone is American, people in the rest of the world have different lifestyles designed around walking and small living spaces and smaller shops instead of enormous supermarkets like walmart.

You're just assuming the alternative to cooking is exclusively delivery app fast food at a 3x mark up but it is very common and normal in some parts of the world for single people to purchase mass produced meals from the grocery store instead of ingredients to make them themselves, so that there are the benefits of economy of scale when they make 300 at once, and they even get marked down 50% off towards the end of the day. I couldn't realistically make something as quality and healthy as those meals for the same price as a single person.
author: @soasertsus

text:
@soasertsus¬† nope. Again. One. Recipe. At. A. Time.
We are not talking about going out and stocking your pantry with every staple in bulk in one go.

So your recipe needs a couple potatoes... 2 bucks. Or I can currently get a 5lb bag of them for 2 bucks.
The first 2 dollars gets me one meal. The 2 dollars bulk means hashbrowns, home fries, jacket potatoes, roasted potatoes, chowder, scalloped potatoes, shepherds pie, perogies... same price, multiple meals and side dishes. 
Even at full price of 6 dollars for that bag, it is easy to afford the extra four bucks and that four bucks buys all those potential meals.
Next recipe, you might still have potatoes left and this recipe calls for rice. Same thing. Off to the Asian market and buy a big bag of rice for 6 to 8 bucks more than your small package would cost.

That 6 or 8 bucks gives you rice for months. Now you can do tons of recipes with that rice and still have some of those potatoes kicking around.
Next time might be flour. The few extra dollars for the big bag giving you months of flour. Bread, pastry, breaded meats, roux to make sauces, dumplings.... Soooo much food.
And this over the course of weeks. Slowly building up your staples.

Almost painless and with a store of items building up, less and less shopping to do. More things you can make.
My daughter's - university students. Single. Small appartment. Student loans. They do this. Bulk pack of hamburger on special, home it comes. Cooked. Portioned. Frozen. Takes no time. Now throughout the week she can make spaghetti, stroganoff, nachos, Korean beef power bowls.
Before going to class they take 5 minutes to put ingredients into their breadmaker and push the start button. Load up the slow cooker and come home to a hot dinner. Actually, the loaf and a full cooker means hot dinners for several nights. Portion and freeze. Build up a choice of ready made meals by cooking once or twice a week. The breadmaker we got from the thrift store for 10 bucks. So many loaves and pizza dough made in that thing.

None of us have very much money. We all eat like kings.

text:
Ahh, I LOVE black beans! In Turkish cuisine, black beans are almost nonexistent. Here, we have a popular combo called "kuru fasulye + pilav" (stewed white beans with rice), just like the one you mentioned in a previous video. Finding black beans here is quite difficult, and they are much more expensive than regular beans.

I think during one of my depressed periods, I once cooked black beans with purple onions, purple carrots, and purple peppers. It didn‚Äôt look very appetizing, but it tasted amazing!

One of the biggest struggles of living alone is cooking. If I try to make a different meal every day, it takes too much time. If I cook in large batches, I lose variety. But if I prepare multiple big meals, I can at least maintain a 3-4 day rotation.
author: @bugra3sby

text:
Hi Adam, I appreciate you speaking to the point that equity could definitely be improved in our current system. However, I would also like to add that while ideally, yes, I would also agree that incentivizing people to work hard for better outcome like eating better, more variety of meals is a great thing, I know many many people who work very hard (2-3 jobs) and are still struggling to make ends meet. 

I know there will be comments about working smarter, but in my experience it usually boils down to the opportunities that were/are presented. Generally, poorer families start with less opportunities, be it educational, financial, geographical or otherwise and unfortunately working harder or smarter does not necessarily mean that you will ever get to a comfortable, secured place in the current system where it overwhelming favors the rich.

As someone who is very much privileged, I also have the luxury of being able to get a head start and have my affairs in order to not be so affected by external pressures. Though, I just want to voice out the above concerns in order to try to dispel any misconceptions that less fortunate people are lazy or are just dumb. Thank you for your time if you end up reading this.

text: I would really suggest getting your protein from milk, not beans. Bean protein is incomplete and the gastrointestinal issues that were mentioned can really fuck you up, this happens because the starches in the beans are resistant starches so you won't fully digest them before they move from the small intestine to the big intestine, the big intestine is full of bacteria who will gleefully eat all those leftover beans, causing gas, inflammation, shedding endotoxin and reproducing, adding more and more bacteria to your big intestine over time. Then even later all these newly reproduced bacteria will die, the endotoxin shells they leave behind causing even more inflammation, making you genuinely sick. If your health is important to you you really shouldn't eat foods that are difficult to digest, no matter how rich or poor you are.

But wow, $2 for a single pepper?? Just checked the Aldi website and you can get 2 for ‚Ç¨1.50 here (in the fancy supermarkets I'm seeing ‚Ç¨1.79 for 2). text: As a Brazilian who lived almost 2 years in the US, I still struggle to accept that in most so-called developed countries eating out is cheaper than cooking at home. In Brazil - and in most of Southern nations I assume - cooking your own meals is just so much more cheaper than eating out... So much so that eating out (even in fast food chains) is considered a rich people thing not a poor people thing. Most low-income families can easily make their groceries for a month of home cooked meals by the price of maybe 2 or 3 times eating out. I can't help but assume that most of this divergence between Northern and Southern nations come from restaurants exploting their labor force. Anyways, it's probably one of my favorite things about my country that I can go to my local grocery store and buy a whole lot of fresh fruits and vegetables for a very small fraction of what people in America pay while eating so much healthier.

To add to this: assuming you aren't meal prepping and have the time, it's not too hard to create variance out of the same base ingredients.

Buy chicken thighs in bulk for the week and one day can be chicken adobo, one day pan fried chicken, day after chicken soup...etc.

Potatoes can be mashed, baked or fried with different seasonings.

Rice could be risotto, Mexican style or an Asian fried rice.

Let the spices and method of prep be your guide but buy the main ingredients in bulk. Still relatively cheap and convenient.

text:
I'm watching this video while eating a bowl of stew that I made ~10lbs of the other night for under $10. Thank you Adam for teaching me how to cook, teaching me how to cook cheap and healthy, and for being so self-aware.

(If you're curious here is my "recipe")
In the morning, soak a bag of black beans.
Buy one pork shoulder. Chop off the fat cap and all the white inedible sinew bits. Reserve the rest of the meat, then cut the fat & sinew into chunks. Put a little water in a dutch oven and throw the chunks in there; stir it occasionally on medium-high heat to get the fat to render out. It will look like garbage at first but hold faith. If the fond at the bottom is at risk of burning you can deglaze it with water to reset your burning timer (I did this like 4 or 5 times?), but be careful cause you can get a lot of fat in that pan and it can bubble quite vigorously when adding water. After you get a lot of oil in the pan you can add some spices to steep in the hot oil, I used curry powder and paprika and Pizza Hut pepper flakes but any hot strongly-colored spice will do.
While that's rendering, chop up 2 white onions into whatever shape and about 1/3 of the pork roast into cubes. Freeze the rest of the roast. I think I rolled the cubed pork around in some salt and pepper to """marinate""" but it probably doesn't matter.
Deglaze the pot with some flavorful liquid (i don't have any WHITE WINE so I used rice vinegar), then use tongs or whatever to take the horrid bits of pork out. You could probably leave them in the pot if you were really strapped for cash but I just chucked them, they have an awful texture.
Fry the onions in the pot, then fry the pork. Pour the beans in (I drained the soaking water but whatever) and some water to cover. Then yeet whatever spices in, I think I used an italian spice mix, MSG, and garlic powder. I also put some whole spices (peppercorns, rosemary, and bay leaves) in a metal tea strainer to hang it in the pot, this way you can take it out at the end to avoid peppercorn jumpscares when eating it, but whatever.
While that's all cooking chop a small mountain of waxy potatoes. Potatoes don't really shrink as they cook so cut them to the size you want to eat them. Dump them in, stir, add more water to cover. At this point the stew was a weird greenish-brown color so I put a bunch of gochujang (spicy Korean fermented pepper paste) in which made it redder. You can get it pretty cheap at an asian grocery store, it comes in a red flip-top container. I cannot say enough good about gochujang in stews, it makes it taste like you developed the flavors for days. (Because someone did develop the flavors for days! If I could beam one piece of information into Adam's mind to share with his audience it would be **USE GOCHUJANG IN STEWS**)
When the beans are like 3/4 done pour some canned corn in. I like whole kernel corn with peppers in it because that way I don't also have to chop and buy peppers.
And when the beans are finished cooking and the potato chunks are getting battered around the edges, add salt or better than boullion or whatever, and serve.

The pork shoulder was $17 at Target and everything else I had lying around. (My roommate had bought the potatoes and onions like 6 months ago and forgot about them. Most of the onions had gone bad but there were 2 good ones, and all the potatoes were good). Given I only used half the pork shoulder I'm saying it was "about $10".

The pork is only like 1/10th of the volume of the stew at the end, so you're getting a good money's worth and I like the fun flavor contrast of finding a pork lump, like a marshmallow in Lucky Charms or whatever. I only used the lard I rendered out of the pork in the recipe, no extra oil. So it all tastes like meat while not being very much meat.

text: I cook 90 percent of my meals at home, my average dinner for a family of 4 costs about 13 dollars. I buy a lot of my common ingredients like beans, pasta, ground beef, onions, in bulk. I make liberal use of my freezer for proteins and keeping left overs for later in the week. I have a solid backbone of five or so meals that I know like the back of my hand and can cook in like 20 minutes with little planning and they all have a protein, a vegetable, and a carb source. I watch cooking videos like Adam's in my free time to try and come up with things that break up the monotony of the same meals all the time. If I can penny pinch or catch a deal in one area then I might be able to stretch and make something new and exciting. Watching the creators that have a 15000 dollar fridge might not seem like it would help me at all but certain creators, like Adam, that know there are poor people who watch and make videos not necessarily catering to them but keeping them in mind, make the repetition and tedium a lot more bearable by introducing new ideas that use the same common ingredients. The "bringing sexy beans" and the improvised vegetable soup videos are responsible for some of my most liked dinners that I've served.

text:
Appeciate the video and the honesty.  There are some tough biases though. "Appreciate that the current economic system incentivies people to work". There is a heavy implication that the "poor" people aren't working hard. Just sitting around and being lazy.  "If you want to eat more interesting food, get off the couch and work" is a common take. But history has shown that not to be the case. Much of the "poor" are the working poor, who generally have to work a lot harder, in worse conditions, for a lot less reward.

Adam in particular is a good example of this. Worked hard and hustled the youtuber lifestyle to get success, and it hasn't been exactly as rewarding as the brochure suggests.  Got that 15K fridge, but the incentive to "work hard for satisfying life" isn't quite there anymore.  

(Obviously it's a much more nuanced subject, but I do think the contrast can be illuminating).

Still appreciate the video, it's really hard to talk about socio economic differences and not come off as preachy.  The very definition of priviledge. No matter how hard we try, it's really hard to completely check all our priviledge at the door.

text: Concerning meat: Yes, if you feed your livestock with corn, oats or whatever, you can "cut out the middle man" and just eat the plant. The reason why we raise livestock in the first place is though, that they turn things we CAN't eat into cheeseburgers. Grass, shrubbery etc. is stuff humans can't eat and that our furry ... friends turn into yummy meat, milk and eggs (also stuff like wool and skin -> leather), so for pre-factory farm societies, producing meat is efficient if all you have is grass and shrublands, but no (or less) arable land.

text: Lemon Chicken or Chicken Piccata is my go to "cheap" meal that is efficent and cheap. Not "poor" cheap but being conscious about spending. It can be made differently so it doesn't feel like you are eating the same thing over and over. The chicken is straightforward. Not always cheap per say but you don't need the best or biggest cuts. One breast can easily feed two people (or two meals for one). Thighs can vary. Can be paird with any carb like pasta or rice. Any green or vegetable tends to go well with it. Lemons are only like $0.50 and have great flavor. 1/4 box of chicken stock (or bouillon) and 1/4 stick of butter means multiple meals from one item. Not as cheap as rice and beans of course, but for the protein and flavor you get along with the versatility, it's a great option, even for people who kinda suck at cooking. Mastering Piccata isn't hard but it will take a few tries.

text:
Thanks for this one - kind of a good 'step back and think' approach to this with your comment. Frankly, back when Adam's channel was growing through here and shares on Reddit, I really enjoyed the approach, but I think he is hitting a sort of tough and stagnant spot. Some bits, like the very beginning of the video, give an impression of bitterness towards other types/styles of channels (I would assume it was an intended point towards Weissman), but these kinds of things really make me less interesting in viewing the rest of the video. Around the same time as Adam's channel surge, Weissman was having some success too, and expanding in all sorts of different directions.

Maybe it is the divide between the comfortable home cooking family element compared to Weissman's more "restaurant experienced" and spread of content, but to me these both represent fairly separate cooking and food priorities. Many of my friends in the restaurant industry have a bit of an edge to them personality wise, and I think people who approach all cooking content with that more wholesome and 'economic' standpoint get turned off easily by those fairly typical mannerisms. There may be an element of going in with the wrong expectations, but I find people get really egotistical themselves when seeing people taking pride in their work/ opinions (often from experience).

Regardless, I still enjoy Adam's insight and unique topics they cover, I just hope they sort of step back from the bitter vibes I've been noticing more and more of. I don't think the main audience particularly cares of course, they are quite content with ripping into other channels over series that ended years ago now, but alas.

text:
I asked these questions from a sales rep before:
A domestic fridge is designed to be opened and closed 20-30 times a day for 3-7 years depending on the brand. A commercial fridge is designed to be opened and closed 300 times a day for 15 years. The hinges could use rubber, plastic, nylon or self-lubricating UHMW polymers. Those 300 closings are expected to be slammed with your feet or butt, so instead of using self-tapping screws and adhesives for the shell, they have to use self locking nuts and bolts with threadlock. The compressor is designed to bring a room temp interior to refrigerated in less than 30 minutes, typically 12-15 minutes, while a domestic fridge has 2 hours. That compressor and refrigeration lines are assembled  with fittings so that components can be replaced as needed and soldered joints will not survive the shock of being slammed all day everyday. That compressor by itself is 3 grand plus because it is oversized compared to a domestic and it has that quick cycle time that wears any compressor out more. I‚Äôm sure the brand adds a few grand too.

text:
Love this video!
Growing up poor I was so used to eating the same meal 5 days in a row. Blew my mind when I found out friends eat different meals everyday. My single mum had to take care of me and work, there was no time to cook fancy dishes everyday - at least as Asians half the meal was already set (rice) and then you just need one side dish. I'm still fine with eating the same thing for multiple days as long as it's yummy.

text:
I really appreciate this video, even if the recipe isn't applicable to me. 

Having digestive disorders and autoimmune reactions to multiple foods, cooking videos always make me yank my hair out. I have to continually remind myself that they aren't blanket for me, even if many of the are presented as being universally applicable and miracle cures. If I ate scratch cooking for every meal, I would be malnourished, in absurd pain, and deeply in debt. Of course, I also can't eat out, but most of my food is at least partially prepackaged.

Beans and bell pepers are two of my worst enemies. (Before I get flamed, fiber and enzymes are not the problem. I go to great lengths to get more than enough fiber, from a variety of sources. Most fibrous foods do not bother me, but beans do, regardless of how they're prepared. And I'm allergic to bell peppers.)
author: @yeetghostrat

text: I've never put sugar or vinegar in a pot of beans in my life... And I am decidedly poor and I do frequently have a pot of food I cooked in the fridge for weeks at a time. First, you get the sale price pork shoulder (bone in, it's cheaper and it makes good stock) then you make tacos for a few days. Freeze some of it, ideally, to stretch future meals. Then, take the liquid from the slow cooker or instant pot and make a pot of beans. Add some vegetables, I use a pablano and jalipenio, but whatever you can do, some garlic.  And hey, that $20 pork roast provided flavor and added protein for more than a weeks worth of meals.

text:
Something that really helps with varying up your meals is to cook some multi-purpose ingredients in bulk-- for example, some pureed tomatoes might go with a grilled cheese one day and into a shakshuka the next (current birdflu eggonomics nonwithstanding.)


Also, something I (surprisingly) don't see talked about a lot in regards to economic inequality (especially within developed countries) is just how much of it stems from the fact that our entire monetary system is based on debt -- The federal reserve (a collection of private, for-profit institutions by the way) creates and issues new currency (devaluing existing currency), loans it at low rates to smaller banks who loan it at high rates to you, loans it to corporations etc-- So that wealth is issued*, institutionally, from the top-- but *value is of course created by actual people doing actual work. This is also a big part of why corporations are always looking to make MORE money than before-- if they kept making the same amount of money, they would over time be making less in terms of actual value.

And this isn't a necessary function of capitalism, either-- This only really started in 1913 with the creation of the federal reserve.

text:
@ I'm not sure. But in the same way, people say "I cut the mold off bread and eat it anyway and don't get sick. What's with that?" And I'd also say I'm not sure but it's still not something I could recommend doing. 

I've done additional research as this thread has gone on, and it does seem that a half hour at boiling point denatures the PHA. There are temperature fluctuations even in a boiling pot though, especially if it's just a simmer. 

Which is to say, if it works for you, I see no reason why you should have to change. But I wouldn't test the lower limit of how fast you can cook kidney beans that haven't been soaked unless you're prepared to suffer for science.

text: I'm trying to retire by 50, which means investing over 50% of my take home pay. One of the main ways I manage to do this is by cooking instead of ordering out, and cooking cheaply. For me that mostly means cooking Indian. No meat, because meat is expensive (I'll get a couple pounds of ground beef once in a while, maybe once a month or less), and no fancy ingredients. I buy everything in bulk or family size packages. Dry chickpeas, split peas, lentils, rice, canned tomatoes and tomato paste, garlic paste, ginger garlic paste, and frozen spinach, peas, carrots, and onions. That's like 85% of my diet. I make soups, masalas, and saags in large batches and just freeze them in individual serving containers and have them over rice. I spend probably 30 dollars a week on groceries and I'm getting restaurant quality Indian food. You do need a couple expensive appliances though. I use an instant pot and vitamix stick blender all the time.

text: It's okay to not be poor, too. You don't have to feel guilty about buying something expensive just because others can't afford it. Just make some minimal effort to ensure that the collection and expenditure of your wealth isn't holding others back and you're golden. You can even use it to help people by buying those slightly more expensive items that are packaged in recyclable materials instead of plastic or by buying the farmers' market produce that grew locally and probably tastes better. You can even use it to eat out at someone's startup pizza/bakery business to help it get going. Having money isn't bad or good; the morality is in how you get it and use it, and you get to decide how much you think it should benefit you and how much you think it should benefit others. If you aren't hurting others with it, you're neutral at worst, and neutral is, by definition, not bad.

text:
alaskan here. i don't think i've seen anyone under ~50 with rickets, but unfortunately lots of alaska natives out in the village (the village being a collective term for all the villages off the road system, and a village almost always being a native settlement. they're generally small -- i wouldn't consider bethel a village, for instance: they have a subway. and the most taxis per capita of any city in the US!) were malnourished and you still see them walking around anchorage, where i live, to this day.

re: energy, if you lose sleep over people using their ovens, do yourself a favor and do not look into energy in alaska. especially out in the village. only a small handful of them are connected to our grid. and our grid isn't connect to any other grid. so it's all diesel generators. and even on the road system, people leave their vehicles running for days straight during cold snaps (i'm talking -40C/F)

all that energy, and moose's tooth pizzeria -- the highest grossing pizzeria in the entire country -- still sucks. it sucks. i have to make pizza at home. judge me or judge yourself but i can't sleep giving them $20.
