text:
I also used to be very poor (grocery shopping at Dollar Tree is not super fun) and now I am reasonably wealthy, and yeah, I am convinced that it's basically just luck. I didn't work harder than my friends who are still bouncers or delivery drivers in WV. I worked hard, and I worked hard in an area that they didn't (computers, rather than manual labor), but it's not like I thought I was going to get rich, it's just the thing I was better at was lucky for me to be more lucrative than what they were good at. I'm not better than them, and I don't deserve it more than them. I was just lucky. People who start thinking that being rich happens because they're better than other people are really good examples of survivorship bias, and nobody should listen to their advice. 

Thanks for keeping it real, Adam.

text:
Don't season the entire pot of beans, just use a minimal amount of salt and maybe some black pepper, and then season each bowl of beans. You can have many very different dishes out of a single pot of beans. Also, you can skip the beans every other day as long as you bring the pot to a boil the next day. Freezing individual servings is also an option.
Also, don't buy one red pepper for $2. Buy a bag of frozen pepper strips for like $3. You'll get much more edible poundage per dollar, and you'll get 3 or 4 colors of peppers.

text: I live in Canada, as do all of my friends and family, and none of us find it cheaper to home cook meals of any level of "fanciness" anymore. Cooking meals that dont make you want to kill yourself after 3 days of eating it stopped being cheaper than eating out around 2019. Now, eating out and home cooking are both disastrously expensive and instead of going strictly for whatever is cheapest, we try to determine the highest possible quality we can get for the relative least amount of money. Whether that be eating out, making unseasoned rice and beans or lavish crab bisque we are essentially fucked in terms of prices no matter what so we try to maximize quality + bang-for-your-buck instead.

text: It is just luck. There's been a bunch of studies on what predicts whether someone will be wealthy, and the single most important factor, beating every other one by a landslide, was - how rich your parents are. Aka just pure dumb luck on your part. And even when they controlled for that, the biggest factor was being in the right place at the right time. Luck once again. Hard work has nothing to do with it.
author: @LenaMel

text: So much of it is determined by who your parents are that there's actually very little room for non-luck in the equation.  Usually when you talk to a bouncer or delivery driver about their career, it's not like "yeah I'm just really good at this shit, it's a shame that it doesn't pay better."  It's almost always that they weren't given enough guidance and/or resources as kids.  Or they were dealt some substantial handicap like ADHD or Aspergers.  Either way it's mostly out of their control.  People love to point to those who overcome such things, but it's typically a case of the exception proving the rule.
author: @senormoll

text:
‚Äã¬†@LenaMel¬† This just isn't true.  Your SAT score predicts your future income better than your parents' income does.

Many studies fail to disentangle the effects of inherited wealth versus inherited ability, but the ones that make the effort generally find that inherited ability is more important than inherited wealth.

Doesn't mean everyone who's rich earned it, or that everyone who's poor is lazy, but it is simply true that the average rich person is smarter and harder working than the average poor person.
author: @elusivegeoff

text: ¬†@elusivegeoff¬†I mean, SAT scores are not an inherent indicator of how smart someone is. People have to study for them and be educated to take the test, and that education often is linked to the economic conditions they grew up in. I.e, kids in poorer areas going to schools with fewer resources, and getting a comparatively worse education then their well off peers
author: @adriansuggs8092

text: Right? I played with computers because they were adjacent to my childhood interest of video games and I had long accepted that my hobby wasn't going to make me money. I dropped out of college and had just kind of accepted that life goes on even when your dreams have dried up. I was out at a bar with my friends when one of them ran into an old college buddy who was looking to hire people for entry-level IT work. I took that opportunity and made a career of it, but I will always acknowledge that without that chance encounter I'd still be poor. I got where I did because I was lucky and that's it.
author: @s_SoNick

text: ¬†@LenaMel¬† said another way. Your zip code has more say on your success than anything else
author: @JasonJonesoriginal

text: ‚Äã¬†@elusivegeoff¬† Having rich parents makes it far more likely you'll do well on the SAT. Being able to afford tutoring, practice tests, and growing up in a stable environment where you could focus on learning instead of focusing on being hungry will absolutely make your SAT score go up. The correlation is there, but the causation is debatable.
author: @14nickel

text: ¬†@elusivegeoff¬† Because income famously has no impact on your ability to study and the resources available to you to do so with. Yeah I'm sure people who can afford to hire a private tutor do better on standardized testing and then get better jobs, but that doesn't in any way disprove that family wealth predicts how successful you will be, because test scores aren't actually an independent measure of your intelligence.
author: @LenaMel

text: @LenaMel¬† Tutors obviously have an effect, but they can only take you so far.  A poor kid with a 1600 SAT is more likely to die rich than a rich kid with a 1200.
author: @elusivegeoff

text:
¬†@adriansuggs8092¬† the effect of your SAT score on your future income, after controlling for parental wealth, is bigger then the effect of your parental wealth on your future income after controlling for your SAT score. 

They control for exactly the advantages you're talking about, and it still turns out your SAT score (which certainly isn't a perfect measure of intelligence, but is a pretty good one) matters more.

author: @zacharyenderman

text:
@MeecroSkills¬† You don't seem to know what controls are.

The studies I am talking about do essentially the following (multiplied by hundreds of cases):

They compare two children of the same parents who have different SAT scores, and see how strongly differences in the children's SAT scores correlate with differences in their incomes as adults.

Then they compare two children with the same SAT scores who had different parents, and they see how strongly differences in their parental incomes correlate with differences in their incomes as adults.

Almost universally, studies show that a difference in SAT scores has a bigger effect than a difference in parental income.  And we know it's not just because richer parents afford tutors because the relationship still exists (and is still extremely strong) even for children born to the same parents.
author: @elusivegeoff

text:
¬†@emma70707¬† If you will accept a study that use a generic IQ-style test, and that therefore doesn't have the tutoring issue you're worried about, you can check out Furnham & Cheng (2016) in the Journal of Intelligence.  

Their study analyzes a data set of 4,000 people who were followed from birth through age 54, and it finds that childhood cognitive ability has nearly twice the predictive power as parental social class (a composite value including parental income and education) with respect to the children's income as adults.

That study is a long way from an outlier.  Basically every study that attempts to control for the effect you are talking about comes to the same conclusion.

text:
¬†@elusivegeoff¬† It's not just about tutors, tho. It's easier to study for the test if you can afford study guides. And it's way easier if you have a computer at home (you'd be surprised how many poor households do not, in some cases because they also do not have reliable or any internet, and in some other cases because such items just end up getting stolen or sold by unscrupulous "friends" or family members). It's easier to study and do well on the test if you are able to sleep and eat well enough to stay cognitively sharp. And if you're not being abused or dealing with toxic levels of physical and mental stress from your living conditions. It's easier to do well if you don't have work to help out your family, so you actually have time to study (and actually go to class, instead of taking extra day shifts to cover unexpected expenses like new glasses or a car repair). And way easier if your family isn't bouncing between shelters, relatives' houses and a car for housing. And so on.

Being rich = you deal with NONE of that (except maybe abuse). Being poor means you almost certainly are dealing with at least some of that (and in far too many cases, all of it).

¬†@zaxtonhong3958¬† 
Distributing wealth and resources is not the same as incentivizing hard work. I agree that capitalism does not distribute resources well. But it also does not incentivize hard/smart work. It incentivizes, as I said, greed and exploitation. 

The discussion I raised had nothing to do with distribution of resources and everything to do with incentives and there's a deep-seeded assumption pervasive to American philosophy and neoliberalism in general that while we currently don't distribute resources equitably - we could do so under capitalism. And we can't. It's not possible. Capitalism, by design, cannot incentivize work and cannot distribute resources equitably. Can't argue it both ways.

text:
THat's a sadly very common western viewpoint (see this comment section for countless examples). There is this individualistic idea that in order to validate yourself you have to be compared to others. And if someone could do just as well if not better than you, without working as hard, then that imply you are worth less.  Which just pits everyone against each other in this dog eat dog nonsense.  We are terribly act recognizing how much good fortune and timing plays a role in our success and over attribute how much of our own personal self and work contributed.  So then if people are poor, they obviously didn't work as hard as you.   Yeah wealth inequality sucks, but like, they can't have as good a life and eat nice food as me, otherwise what did I work so hard for? How are we supposed to measure the success and worth of our life an achievements?

Adam's a very smart guy, but even he can fail to realize these viewpoints ingrained in our culture. He's scratching at the surface of these feelings in this video, you can see the awkwardness. But not enough to make any meaningful self reflection. He can afford the fridge, he worked hard, so I guess he kinda deserves it?  Our conscience tells us otherwise, but a few awkward comments in a video and we forget all about it.

Throwing my favorite ‚Äòpoor‚Äô recipe from childhood here for anyone who wants it: Tuna Casserole:

Mix 2 cups uncooked macaroni, 2 cups water, 1 can cream of mushroom soup, 1 can milk (fill cream of mushroom soup can), 1 can chunk light tuna, 1 can diced mushrooms (or dice fresh), salt and pepper to taste.
Pour into casserole dish, top with shredded cheese
Bake @375-400 for about 45 minutes or until pasta is fully cooked.

Total cost in my area (Midwest): ~$5, if you have to buy all the ingredients the first time, <$10

Being Poor or cooking "Economically" always means foodprep. I did build up a stash of preped meals over february. Burritos, soups, sauces and more. All the good stuff you can easily store frozen and are easy to reheat. You can add alot of variety and you have food for many days (just remember the frozen Shelflife of your food ^^). Today i eat some Buffalo Chicken Burritos, tomorrow a Tomato Soup and the day after tomorrow i use my Bolognese i preped to make Spaghetti. 

Doing the Foodprep did put a big dent into my Budget early in the Month but i dont need to spend that money on grocerys the next couple of weeks. So its ok to Frontload the spending process. Doing dedicated mealprep even helped me save some Money in the end because buying things in Bulk is always cheaper. I also started to use more of my Pantry items. author: @remysavary689

text:
Thank you!
If you're cooking food, it's a vegetable. If you're leading a botany class, it's a fruit.

In botany "vegetable" has no meaning, in culinary, vegetables are plants that are typically eaten in savory dishes.

It's like the term "accelerate" - if you're driving and then start braking, you're technically accelerating (accelerate means change in velocity - ANY CHANGE, not just speeding up), but go ahead and tell a student driver "accelerate" when you mean "brake" and see what happens. If you're dealing with physics, then use the physics term for accelerate, but in everyday speech there's no need to get technical about the term accelerate, we all know it as a term that means "speed up" in just about any scenario except science. We're all adults, we already adjust our speech depending on the context, so learn to do that with botanical fruits and culinary fruits.

text: Meat should not be a secondary product if done properly. Like in the rough mountainous areas of south america like chile, argentina, and the patagonias in general, the cattle consume grasses and birds like chickens consume insects and other seeds from the grasses and other things that they find roaming around. You would not eat any of the things that they eat, thus the meats from these animals are primary products, and this is what was originally done to economically get the most bang for your buck. Why in the world would you feed your animals food you would eat when food is scarce to begin with? So you wouldn't do that, in the old days anyway.

text: If beans make you bloat up like the Goodyear blimp, soak them in water overnight before cooking then drain the beans and toss out the water. I actually do this two or three times during the soaking. The water absorbs a lot of the things that cause gas and by draining it you get rid of the issue. Additionally, add 1/4 teaspoon of baking soda per pound of beans to the cooking water when you‚Äôre actually cooking them. The cooking water gets rid of some complex carbohydrates that you can‚Äôt digest, but bacteria in your gut absolutely love it and their metabolic processes create gas, which gives you gas by extension. Beans are actually seeds and you can grow plants from dried beans in most cases. They‚Äôre extremely nutrient dense. Please don‚Äôt miss out on them just because of the avoidable gas issue.

text: What do you do to avoid it?
author: @samdajellybeenie14

text: ¬†@samdajellybeenie14¬† Eat wholemeal wheat bread (no white bread), cut out all mass-produced cereals except for oat-based granola, avoid baked goods that could contain fortified flour (same with breaded products and some frozen goods which have it in sauces and others uses), don't eat iron-rich meat such as beef, venison, duck, lamb and pork (chicken and Turkey have less iron compared and are okay) as well as not having raw shellfish at all. Avoiding alcohol (I don't drink so it's fine) and not having vitamin C through fruit juices with meals as it can increase the amount of iron absorbed with other foods (also recommended to have fruit in between meals but not with them too). There's more exhaustive lists out there, but that's what I've been doing whilst waiting for hospital appointments to deal with high iron levels in my blood.

text:
yes being rewarded for "working hard" is good, but 2 peoples levels of "working hard" are completely different. i have very strong autism along with anxiety and depression and a million other things. me working the absolute hardest i possibly can and putting the most effort i can into something often equates to the same results that somebody "normal" would achieve with minimal effort. even something like working in a fast food place is far outside the realm of possibility for me. 

I know this is quite literally an impossible thing to ever properly achieve, but ideally (for me, and others like me) there'd be a system where the effort you put in is the reward you get out, regardless of what is actually achieved by that effort. but trying to quantify how much "effort" somebody is putting into something or how much a disabled person is truly struggling is impossible, and also incredibly dehumanising, as I very much know :)

text: 17:11 The issue with meat is not that it's a secondary product, it's that we've turned it into a secondary product. The purpose of all agriculture is to acquire food from things that are not themselves edible. Plant based agriculture is favoring the growth of edible plants over inedible ones, or growing edible plants where they wouldn't grow naturally. The purpose of livestock is to convert inedible plants into edible meat. We should not be feeding livestock the plants we eat, or at least not the parts of the plants that we eat, livestock should be raised in areas where we can't grow our favored crops or where it's economically inefficient to do so. And this would generally be healthier for both them and us, cattle are grazing animals that are built mostly for eating grass, starchy seeds are like sugar for their much more robust digestive systems.

text:
This is a meal my mom taught me. It's good, hearty food for real cheap. It feeds 3 adults well for about $2.46 per person, and you barely have to do any work.

Budget Chicken & Rice Bake ($7.37 total)

üõí What you need:
1 can cream of chicken ‚Äì $0.68
1 can cream of celery ‚Äì $0.68
1 can cream of mushroom ‚Äì $0.68
6 chicken legs (from a frozen 12-pack) ‚Äì $2.50
2 cups Minute Rice ‚Äì $0.75
2 cups water ‚Äì (free!)
A few shakes of Tony‚Äôs seasoning ‚Äì $0.10
1 bag frozen broccoli ‚Äì $1.68
A few dollops of Country Crock ‚Äì $0.20
Onion powder & garlic powder ‚Äì $0.10

How to make it:

Prices reflect great value brand stuff at my local walmart your milage may vary

1‚É£ Dump everything except the chicken and Country Crock into a baking dish and stir it up.
2‚É£ Add a few dollops of Country Crock on top.
3‚É£ Lay the chicken legs on top and season them or my mom's ghost will haunt you (they don‚Äôt even need to be fully thawed!).
4‚É£ Bake uncovered at 400¬∞F for 60-75 minutes until the chicken is golden and cooked through.
5‚É£ Let it cool for a few minutes, then dig in!

This is one of those "dump-and-bake" meals that takes almost no effort but fills you up. Cheap, easy, and delicious. Hope this helps someone out!  üòä

text: With the population and demand for meat it's not feasible to raise livestock like that.  Companies do what they can to save money and therefore resources because they're costly.  There isn't enough grass growing to feed all the cows, and the grass we do feed them is usually heavily irrigated which is draining the water of the entire American west.  The human population is insanely high, especially for how large we are.  Because of the large amount of prey needed to sustain them, terrestrial large predators exist in populations of thousands, not billions.  To support even a fraction of our diet with meat requires a lot of intensive agriculture.  If we raised livestock "sustainably" just on unirrigated pasture, then beef and dairy consumption would have to go down to become basically negligible, which kind of means meat is the problem.  We also do feed livestock the parts of the plants that we don't eat because it saves money that way since they can't sell it to people.  But again, that isn't nearly enough to sustain the amount of meat we eat so that has to be supplemented with grain and mass produced silage.

text: This is a good point, but is still missing the nuances involved in raising livestock. If I have a field where I could farm 10x as many calories to feed my cows than if I let it grow wild plants, it's probably a better use of that land to grow crops to feed the cattle. However, if the land is suitable for farming in the first place, why not just grow food for humans? Therefore if we are trying to maximize calories, it only makes sense to graze animals in areas that can grow inedible plants but is also completely unsuitable for farming, which is a supply of land that has only gotten more scarce due to the green revolution, gene editing, etc. Therefore, while you make a good point, if we followed this logic and only grazed livestock on this special type of land, not only would our existing supply of meat be significantly reduced, but it would shrink over time, assuming we don't cut down any more rainforests.
author: @justindie7543

text: ‚Äã¬†@kiryowtk2869¬†exactly. I live in western Alberta, a hub for Canadian beef. We are surrounded with steep hills that would be unsuitable for plant-based agriculture, but are perfect for grazing livestock. I'm surprised at how athletic cows can be, they'll climb a hill with >10% incline with no problem. It's land that would otherwise go unused for food production.

text:
This was only true when non-edible plants effectively had no value. If was very easy to just trim up a bunch of grass and dump it in front of a pig. Tilling and managing wheat crops was not so easy. Processing that wheat was labor intensive. A pig can just be smoked and cured with comparatively less effort. The only reason animal agriculture wasn't more common in settled agrarian cultures is because the animals were actually needed for labor. Nomadic pastoralists did rely most on animals, unlike their settled counterpart. 

These days, with mechanization, stuff like corn, wheat, and soybeans have close to no value as well. So transforming them into a secondary product is more profitable than selling them on the open market. Why sell a bushel of wheat (60 pounds) for a few dollars when you could transform it into beef worth at least six dollars? For the record, a lot of animal feed is inedible plants, which grow at a greater density than edible ones. Another component is byproducts like hay and chaff which has very little use for humans. Insects are commonly used as high-quality chicken feed, which is undesirable for humans.

text:
¬†@gagenater¬† Frozen meats can last for an extremely long time, packaging helps a lot too. I'm still plowing through some frozen salmon I bought a year ago when I found it on sale ! One brand, a little more loosely packed, was freezer burned too much and sadly I had to toss it as the damage was too great but the other brand was well packed and only shows hints of burn on the corners and still cooks up perfectly fine. 
A freezer is indeed a lifesaver in a budget home. That being said, avoid upright freezers, they're less efficient and frost up WAY more than chest freezers.
author: @Neuralatrophy

text: ¬†@Neuralatrophy¬† We use an upright freezer, because it takes up less floor space, and the items in it are easier to find.  That said we don't let anything stay in there more than 12 months.  My experience with people who have chest freezers is that they invariably forget about what is in them near the bottom, and wind up throwing away 1/2 the stuff in them because it is 5 years old and in bad quality.

text:
In some cities of the world it's common for people to prepare a dough at home, put it in a pan and take it to the local baker who will throw it in the hot oven they already have going. There are many aspects of our lives that could be made much more efficient through a communal approach. Communal cooking is leagues more efficient in terms of both nutritional distribution and energy use. The modern daily hot shower is an extremely unsustainable practice that is less energy efficient than an ancient roman bathhouse. 

It's unfortunate that we have so few social mechanisms to do things like cooking and growing food communally outside of private business.

text:
Not just that, but also child raising is SO different outside of the "western" world. I remember talking with some of my friends who grew up in other countries (mostly western africa and south asia) and the sheer amount of people who would talk about their neighbors or family friends in the same way they would talk about direct family is wild. In many parts of the world, it's just expected that neighbors and extended family would be happy to take care of each others' kids in times when their direct parents were stuck at work or were struggling financially and there was zero shame attached to it. That pales in comparison to how many kids grow up here where parents are super competitive, neighbors don't really know each other that well, and being viewed as "poor" was something to be ashamed of rather than showing you needed help. I mean, we even used to have that in the US where my own parents would tell stories about how linked their neighborhood was or how they would constantly come together when things got bad. Nowadays you just have parents who NEED to constantly be working just to survive combined with the lack of communal childcare so kids suffer the brunt of it while parents don't catch a break.

Edit: and to clarify: yes they came here due to suffering at home, but that's one thing they talk about missing greatly back home. They would talk about how yes, the greater economic prosperity and possible safety benefits are genuinely good things about coming here, but they didn't expect how HARD it would be to raise a kid given that you're just expected to kinda do it on your own. I wish so badly we could live in a world with both, and I know very well it's possible, but it's a horrific shame that it's not.

text: ¬†@jong2359¬† although i wish this was true, the fact is that societies organize governments, and it's quite illogical to try and separate the two. varied governmental systems across socialist countries (for simplicity's sake im not diving into revisionism or theory here but) in say Yugoslavia vs USSR vs China etc etc were organized because of their different societal and material conditions. saying that we should do socialism, for example, in a non regulatory way would be amazing, but unfortunately, the reality is there are countries that will work their hardest to destabilize socialist countries, and what happens? surprise! censorship. im not saying this is the best way to go about doing things, nor am i saying its the worst, just explaining why things unfolded the way they did! if you're more interested in the systems the USSR and China held, i'd suggest reading into Marxism (Marxism-Leninism more specifically, it's what im more interested in), and if you're interested in the more "deregulatory" styles of socialism, i'd suggest reading into Anarchism or Syndicalism (anarchism isnt literally living like cave men, the name may be a bit misleading but whatever). lmk if you have any questions though!

text:
The main thing I see food youtubers fail to consider when suggesting low-budget food is time and energy.
Yes, you probably can save $2 baking your own bread. Sure you can probably save money by boiling down bones to stock. There are plenty of ways to cut costs.
But a large portion of those methods are being proposed by content creators that do it as their full time job, that's their only responsibility. It's a very different situation when someone is doing that after getting home from their full time job at 6pm with a family to take care of, and those recipes often make an assumption of unlimited time and energy.
I was doing the math last year on a lot of homemade things I was cooking, and I realized that they cost more for me to make than in a restaurant. The ingredients were cheaper, but if I had calculated in the value of taking the couple of hours I spent making a dish like a lasagna, I'd be looking at $100+ worth of time if I was at work.
That's not to say it's a waste, I enjoy cooking, that's why I do it. But there's an argument to be made that if someone strongly dislikes cooking and views it as being as unpleasant as work, it might not make sense for them to cook much, and just spend that time putting in an extra hour at work then getting take out. As much as I love it, complex dishes are not for everyone.

text: Your point is good but I can make it better. Don't spend 2 hrs making lasagna that will last you for 1 or 2 meals max, but simplify it. Lasagna = noodles boiled, red and white sauce made, then layering, then freezing and reheating. A dish like that best bought from costco for the time reasons. BUT, here is what you can do: Have white and red sauce made in bulk once a month and freeze it in smaller containers/cubes. Have stews and veggies made in bulk once a week and keep in 1 pot. So, dinner during busy week is this: get a 4-5 pot = portion meat, veggies, and sauces into it, and as it warms up, cook pasta or rice or anything on the side, which take about 20 min. The mix together = deconstructed lasagna if it's pasta, or stir fry or whatever else u want to call it if it's anything else.

text: I think part of the problem is access to convenience has utterly eroded the craft and skill of cooking for so many people. The fact that you get to view it as a "hobby", and not a regular routine of life is a privilege that I think has poisoned the well. If it costed say $75 a week for your laundry to be done magically in the same way you can order doordash for dinner, I think a substantial amount of people who economically shouldnt would pay that premium. I think it becomes problematic when people seem to ignore the agency they have in their own lives at the cost of their own ecenomic situation. It might make sense for some people to eat out every meal, or have a personal chef. But eating is a reality of life, there's no way around it. You either learn to cook or suffer the consequences of having that option unavailable to you. But cooking can be effectively learned by anyone, so lots of excuses ring hollow to me. The reason it sucks that cooking takes time is because it's a chore. Like many chores, people should be willing and ready to take logical and economical shortcuts, like bulk cooking and meal planning. It doesn't taste as good as eating out until you eventually frontload the labor enough to learn what you actually like to eat.

text:
Bread isn't difficult or time consuming to make though. Throw a poolish together and set aside for loaf number two, spend 15 minutes (at most) throwing together a rough dough and kneading it. Let it rest while you're at work (either on the counter or in an oven that is off but has the light on), when you get off work throw it in a pan (or a dutch oven if you have one), score it, bake it for 30-45 minutes and you're done. Tomorrow, use the poolish you made to create your dough and repeat all those same steps and your next loaf will be even better. Just make sure you always have a poolish ready 6-24 hours before you will need it. 

Bread is one of those things where the more you put into it, the better your end result becomes (with diminishing returns after a certain point). A super simple recipe will still create good edible bread. If you don't have 15 minutes to throw a dough together, you're purposefully mismanaging your own time. If you can't think 24 hours in advanced, how are you even surviving on your own as an adult?

text:
Valuing your time cooking at the same as what you're paid in your job is a very bad way to look at it. Unless you happen to be working in a restaurant, that is. What you're said for at your day job is VALUE for your SKILL SET, not VALUE for your TIME. Your lasagna isn't worth what a professional makes, that's just a simple reality. Also, no one is going to pay, say a programmer their programmer hourly rate to make a lasagna, that would be nonsense. And lastly, it's not like you're given a choice of making a lasagna or working an extra 2-3 hours. Not every time, at least.

There are also cases where takeout food is simply overpriced. I took up making pizza at home after I looked at the cost of ingredients and compared it to takeout. The cost of ingredients was about 3-4‚Ç¨, whereas a takeout pizza from a place across the street with the same toppings would be 14‚Ç¨. At that level, you're paying a massive margin for convenience, because pizza at home takes a longer time to make. In a similar manner, I make pasta at home, and I can make a carbonara for less than 2‚Ç¨. Carbonara from a nearby restaurant would be 13.70‚Ç¨.

text: When I was a poor college student I would cook at home. Full load of classes where I tried (and managed to) to maintain a very high GPA, off campus work, one campus work + extra-curricular activities for my CV. I just couldn't afford to eat out. And even though I couldn't afford the time to cook that's what I didn't: grocery shopping at 11pm, fast, no queue. Lots and lots of batch cooking. There was no YouTube then, we didn't overthink things. It was chicken tighs, rice, some vegetable and fruits. Pizza was the very occasional treat. $15 for one pizza/two meals was too much for me. But yeah maybe because we didn't have YouTube I just cooked from my I remembered eating growing up and knew that I only needed salt, pepper, onions and garlic, some season all to season my food.
author: @FutureCommentary1

text:
Realistically though, a portion of lasagna where I live will generally be ~$25, and if I cook one at home, it's gonna be somewhere in the ballpark of 6 restaurant portions. That's around $150 if I was buying from a restaurant. The recipe I do isn't exactly fancy, but I could take it from start to finish in two hours, and close to half of that time is just waiting around; I could be doing other chores in that time. With an easier recipe like a soup, I could easily make that many meals in under an hour.
Unless you have a job where you CAN choose your hours completely on a whim, which very few people do, I think this is actually a pretty harmful way of valuing time.
Giving people money to do a chore for you, like cooking, is a luxury. Some people can afford it, and that's fine, but for someone who has to worry about budgets, this really isn't an option. Suppose a single parent is raising two kids- takeout for a day is somewhere around $20 per person. For three people, that's $400 a week. At minimum wage, 22 hours of work- more than half a full time job. On the other hand, cooking a cheap meal every other day costs probably $10 + an hour of work every second day. That's $35 a week. One 8 hour day of work could pay for a whole month of food at that price.
Personally, I value my time outside of work very cheap, in the low single digits. $2 for a loaf of bread to save me a few hours is worth it (not to mention preservation). But unless it's a special occasion, like a birthday, or friends from out of town visiting, I can never justify going to a restaurant. I can afford it, I just can't convince myself it's worth the price

Down that path lay thinking like "Going to this gathering with my friends for the evening will cost me around $200 in time alone, I better just stay home and continue the grind". You cannot live like that.

But beside that, a lot of the time consuming cooking tasks involve a lot of :down time" anyway. Making a good pasta sauce might take a couple hours, but it's like 15 minutes of browning meat and chopping veggies and then 1 hr and 45 minutes of just leaving it on the stove on a low heat and stirring occasionally. You can watch tv or play video games or doing other chores or pretty much whatever you would normally be doing while doing it.

Just to seize on to the bread example you gave: It's pretty easy to make a bunch of dough (like mixing it in the most gigantic tupperware dish you have), store it in the fridge, and tearing off chunks to bake as needed. You can use a no-knead method so you really just have to dump in the ingredients, mix unti barely combined, then knead it for about 10 seconds every day (just to knock the excess gas out so it doesn't burst out of the container). I have a job, a family, and am also studying for career move, and I haven't bought a loaf of bread at the store for years. 

Making large batches of dough and baking ends up being like 95% passive effort.

text: I think the even more salient point is that a lot of these things are skills that people don't just... HAVE.  Especially things like baking bread.  You have to do it a bunch of times before you can reliably get good results without stressing out about it.  And while someone like me can do bulk buying of dried and cheap canned goods once every couple of months because I have space to store all that stuff, then make huge batches of things and store portioned meals in my giant chest freezer... these things are definitely not true for everyone.  I've also seen people suggest, with a straight face, that people take up gardening because of all the money that you can save.  It's easy to forget when you're good at something because you're passionate about a thing and enjoy it that not everyone is that way.

It really doesn't take hardly any Hands-On work. You just dump a bunch of bones and some onions in a pot and let it bubble away. Then strain and package and freeze.

Same concept can be applied to baking bread. Make a bunch, slice and freeze. You only have to do it when you run out.

I was skeptical as well, but found a couple studies from separate university labs that confirm it can fairly accurately measure your carb:fat catabolic ratio based on the CO2 you exhale relative to the O2 you inhale. The whole design of the product is based on the stoichiometry of fatty acid oxidation vs. glycolysis. So at the very least, the science is plausible and the research that has evaluated it supports its claim with pretty good P values.

text:
Biggest problem with groceries is myself, as a single man, has to spend upwards of $300-$400 a month on groceries. I maintain a calorie deficit of 1500. I am not making horribly fancy meals or buying insanely priced cuts of meat. 

This is milk, eggs, bacon, bread, pasta, and a variety of dairy products such as cheeses and butters. Veggies too, like broccoli, romain, arugula, tomatoes, potatoes, onions, carrots, etc. My protein is primarily seafood (whitefish and shrimp), chicken, beans, ground beef, ground turkey, and sardines because steaks are just too damn expensive. 

I am not buying unbelievably expensive brands of any of these products. I am not purchasing processed, pre-frozen foods. 99% of the time, the things I buy are generic store brands. The two exceptions would be the particular breads, cheeses, and milk I purchase, but these are only a few dollars more than your generic store brands. I would still be spending approximately the same amount regardless of these choices. 

I purchase these brands for a few reasons. I only buy Fairlife because I am not going to use a whole gallon jug of milk before it goes bad. I purchase Lewis brand breads because, surprise surprise, I will not use a full loaf of bread before it goes stale. As for cheeses, I don't buy incredibly fancy ones, but I do go a step above generic. I grate/shred cheeses when I use them. Generic brands in blocks don't melt right, they are coated in the same starches as the pre-shredded bags of cheese. These small deviations from cheapest of cheap do not change the overall monthly cost very much at all, at most by maybe $10-$20.  

This is approximately 1 months worth of groceries. My fridge is not large enough to fit one months worth of groceries, so I restock every two weeks. Every two weeks, I spend anywhere from $150 to $200, hence the valuation I've arrived at for my "monthly grocery budget" of $300-$400. 

When I see people posting "proof" that they're able to make luxurious meals on $150 a month just for themselves, I find this unbelievable. Even if you shopped at a Dollar Tree you are going to spend way more than $150 a month on groceries.

I grew up in the 90's. I distinctly remember a FULL CART loaded to the top, practically spilling over, was at most $200. The same amount of money now barely fills a cart whatsoever. It fills a carrying bin.

author: @JesseLG1213

text:
Speaking as someone who worked his way off the streets of Seattle in 2013, most of those structural inequalities are rooted in the social services poverty-perpetuation loop.

I don't disagree with your core premise‚Äîthat we've got a serious problem with people unable to break the cycle. But I suspect I strongly disagree with what you may consider to be the solution. I had a serious dent put in my compassion for the "less fortunate" when I had to live among them for several months because my own life had fallen into disaster during the Great Recession. The "culture of poverty" is absolutely real, and that's something we have to address before we start talking about structural inequality.

author: @ericthompson3982

text: ¬†@SimuLord¬† I don't suggest that there is a simple solution. It's a complex problem.
author: @ericthompson3982

text:
‚Äã¬†@everettvitols5690¬† Simplest is that it's just more expensive to be poor. Sometimes referred to as the Vimes Economic Theory of Boots (after a fictional character from Sir Terry Pratchett's Discworld series) it is often just more expensive to be poor because when you are poor, you cannot afford to buy anything that lasts. Cars are a good example here, because they are often a virtual necessity in much of North America, you need to have one in order to work. But if you are poor, you can't afford a new one that has a warranty, you can't afford to bring it in to a shop to fix it up, and so you often just buy the POS that you can afford now, despite the fact that you will need to replace it sooner, and that it's likely going to cost you more on gas than an equivalent new car would.
Cars themselves being a virtual necessity to work in most of North America is another example in an of itself. The cost that goes in to owning a car is massive, from maintenance, to insurance to gas. This is all a cost that eliminates a person's ability to have money to spare on other things.
Fines. Breaking the law often results in fines, and there is a famous saying "If the punishment for a crime is a fine, then that crime only exists for the poor". A $100 fine for jaywalking certainly impacts the working poor much more than the well off, and while some countries do have more equitable systems that will adjust fines based on income or worth, most do not.
Being poor often means not having access to routine medical care (check-ups and what not), especially in the USA, and it is often way less costly to treat many serious ailments if you catch them early than if you only catch them after they start having a negative impact on your day-to-day
 
 There are many more examples and many papers on this topic, but I'll leave that as an exercise for you to discover. scholar.google.com is better than regular google for this type of research
author: @Jaaxfo

text: ¬†@ericthompson3982¬†  they really don‚Äôt. The poorest quarter of Americans have a negative tax rate. They get more than they pay in
author: @everettvitols5690
@JesseLG1213

text: @JesseLG1213¬† Very well stated. Thank you for articulating what I didn't have the time to (and also, I suspect, not neearly the same level of expertise as you) so eloquently.
author: @ericthompson3982

text: @everettvitols5690¬† I'd disagree. For example, a 6% sales tax rate affects people in poverty much more disproportionately than those who have some level of wealth. That's why I mention proportion. Additionally, not having access to financial resources denies access to, for example, accounting and legal resources that may allow you to maintain wealth by paying a lower proportion of your assets overall. Property tax rates, for example, disproportionately benefit the wealthy, not to mention the ways in which educational funding based on property values affects access to educational resources.
author: @ericthompson3982

text: I would like to thank everyone in this conversation for really engaging with it in a genuinely thoughtful and respectful way. Well done, folks, genuinely. Please keep at it.
author: @ericthompson3982

text:
¬†@JesseLG1213¬† The real sad part of all this is that I wish there were more liberals in Congress like you and more conservatives in Congress like me.

Because that's the ultimate reason why none of this will get solved any time soon‚Äîthere are more productive and respectful disagreements in the comments section of a cooking YouTuber than there are in the places where public policy is made for hundreds of millions of people.
author: @SimuLord

text:
¬†@everettvitols5690¬† Nothing is as expensive as being poor is something I have often found to be true. Just looking at the fact that they pay less taxes than middle class people is disingenuous. 
To give you an example, in the country I live I have to pay for health insurance. By paying it all in one big sum at the start of the year I get to save about 75 euro. But that does mean having 3000 euro on hand. 75 euro might no be much but it is enough for me to eat for about a week.
Or the obvious once where well of people don't have to go into debt to buy a new fridge/car/heating/etc. breaks.

text:
Very odd he decided to educate on economies of scale and budget without thoroughly discussing freezing. Saving by freezing could be its own video. I have two deep freezers. They are critical to eating on a budget. Buying 40lbs of chicken breasts at a time, from the restaurant supply store saves more money than the annual cost of electricity to run a 14cu.ft. deep freezer.  You also don't have to "eat the same thing for days on end." I feel like he wasn't really prepared or possibly not experienced enough to cover the topic of home economics.
Also +1 on the bulk shelf stable foods.

text: If you're poor, you might not have that much freezer space. I'm not even poor, but my freezer has a capacity of maybe 40-50 l, that's used up quickly with a few soup containers, some frozen vegetables, maybe some meat you bought in bulk...
author: @barvdw

text:
Yes. I do this all the time. I live on my own, work for minimum wage, but I have a large freezer that you would usually only expect a small family to have. But I use it all the time. Currently, I'm making a batch of curries to portion out and freeze. I estimate it to be about 25 portions. Including buying all the spices which I've got loads left over, and are now pantry staples, it probably cost about ¬£150; probably a lot less; I wasn't keeping track. So approximately ¬£5-¬£6 per meal.

¬£50 of that was the meat. I could buy 2kg of chicken thighs for about ¬£5 in Tesco, compared to I think 600g for ¬£3. So if I'm just making a small amount, the price would skyrocket. Buy the larger amount, cook it up, and then freeze it, it's far more economical.

For the record, the other ¬£40 was for just over 2kg of lamb. I decided to treat myself.
author: @JRCSalter

text:
Would also add to the recipes - go to thrift stores for older cookbooks, or better yet 'procure' on the internet some pdfs. Most of them were published with the idea that the reader is a housewife on a tight budget and you need to stretch it for the family. As such they can be very valuable for finding cheap, filling recipes. Even ones published by chefs 30 years ago assumed you were also not a chef. Nothing wrong (generally) with modern ones, just they cost more money.

If kitchen counter space is scare or you dont want to keep the book open on the counter every time - scribble it out onto a notebook, your note-taking app or take a picture.

text: ¬†@LightningbrotherG¬† Mise en place is actually going to make cooking easier for a newbie. All it means is '(everything) put in its place', the idea being that you have prepared everything before you begin cooking meaning you can focus on better cooking and not think about chopping while you're cooking (as is often seen on TV cooking shows). Mise en place is especially important if you're cooking in a wok as you have no spare time to do other stuff. I agree with some comments that Joshua can be cringe and can be obnoxious on occasions, but mise en place is a genuinely good tip for a beginner, even if it means more washing up.

text:
Corn and grain is what I suppose hes saying is being fed to cattle. 

Now, i am not a meat eating evangelist but it shluld be said that In the Canadain prairies (and presumably many other arid places) there is SO MUCH LAND that cannot sustain crops. But it CAN sustain grass. Local grass grows without human intervention and in many cases against human intervention. 

Grasslands cannot grow sustainable crops, but it CAN grow sheep, or cows. Leaner hearty breeds may not be the most profitable per lb but it is edible and grass is not. (Speckle park and Saleir are what my community raises) 

Sheep are even better imho, but I'm a textile freak so of course I would say that. If the north American palette gets more accustomed to sheep/goat milk and meat i think it would be a fantastic thing. 

Then land which cannot grow human edible crops can grow sheep. And if it's growing sheep then it's growing meat, milk, fertilizer(scat and bone meal) leather, and wool. And wool is amazing stuff dont even get me started on wool. Textiles sure but also great mulch, compostable, textiles of all manner, beds, wound dressing, kindle, dryer balls, on and on.
author: @Ninjozata

text:
"I try to emphasize meat ought to be a special treat, not a staple food" but "in our modern diet we generally eat too many carbs and not enough protein"..? You can't have it both ways bro.

Meat (an animal products in general - eggs, dairy, liver etc) IS a staple food, and should be, based on the sheer nutrient abundance within vs plants. Use meat to hit your protein needs, and then add plants n fruit to supplement for micronutrients that you are missing out on. But meat should be the biggest part of your plate. We know better by now.

text:
¬†@jesperdahl1486¬† And for thousands of years before the west came along, they managed just fine without us. Ever wonder what happened to make them dependent? It was, and is, an intentional power ploy by the west. 

Send your poor neighbor food, and he will be grateful. And, if they want to keep receiving the food, they will agree to the unfavorable trade terms you just proposed. And, wouldn't you know it, the crazy border disputes and economic turmoil caused by Western imperialism have made traditional agricultural practices untenable. Too bad that nobody is sending them agricultural machinery to industrialize their food economy. Ah well, guess they'll just have to keep accepting food aid and selling off their natural resources to foreigners. 

Teach a man to fish, you feed him for a lifetime. Give a man a fish and ruin the local waters, and he'll buy from you at any price for the rest of his life.

text:
"Cooking more economically" is simply a fool's errand because I live alone. Sure, groceries are cheaper than fast/takeout food, but there are so many other things that I have to factor in as costs. Whether it's eating the same thing four days in a row because that's the only way to avoid food waste on, say, a pack of burger buns, or the cost of me being a less-than-restaurant-quality cook and occasionally screwing up a meal, or other actual issues relating to the quality and variety of home-cooked compared to takeout food, that's almost enough by itself.

The other factor? My time has value. Even if it's not directly measured in dollars and cents the way an hour of my time is valued by my employer, it's measured in things like psychological value‚Äîthere are a finite number of hours between when I get home and when I go to bed that I want to spend doing something other than preparing and cooking food. Heck, I lit $50 on fire for an Uber yesterday to save an hour when I had a dental appointment two towns over and wanted to get home without taking two buses and a 20-minute walk between the dentist and my apartment. If I'm willing to value my time that highly, swinging by Bucks Teriyaki&Wok (not an ad, just a fan) on East Hill in Kent outside of Seattle for a delicious dinner for under $20 is a no-brainer.

Once in awhile, usually on a weekend or during a staycation week, I'll cook, and it's usually when I want something very specific that I can't get from a restaurant in the area at any kind of decent quality. Like a perfect slab o' meat (you can get a steak or a pork chop anywhere but I think I've earned the right to be proud of my meat cookery specifically) or one of my comfort recipes.

text:
‚Äã¬†@MrJahka¬† Vague notions of "certain people" or "you know who i'm talking about" or "i don't even have to say who i'm talking about" etc
get annoying really quickly.
The moment you dig into exactly what they mean by "certain people" the argument starts to fall apart.
Clarity is the essence of rhetoric. Without clarity, you're most likely an idiot rambling to clouds about things that may or may not be true but would be convenient to you if they were true so you believe it without question.
Save this "certain people" talk for yourself.
Keep it inside. Take it out only if you've decided to truly give it a varied and nuanced look.
Only then will you realize that there is no place for phrases like "certain people" because 99% of the time life is a whole lot more complex than what can be described using phrases like "certain people".

text:
@SangoProductions213¬† Youre wrong, thats smth that is drastically diff from state to state; ive seen the diff... And thats before considerin that the vast majority of food banks are run by religious orgs which oft proselytise to us as a prereq to givin food

When i was without a job for over a yr in Oregon i was able to survive bcuz yeah, food banks there are extremely generous compared to food banks id find durin my time bein without a job in the midwest; whilst food prices soared ‚Äî and i didnt even mention the lack of variety from many of those food banks or how we routinely got alrdy rotten meat and rotten fruits/veggies from the food banks run by those religious orgs; and wudve to throw out prty much everythin fresh that they gave us bcuz they cudnt even give us food that wasnt literally moldy

Now im in CO, still without a job what with the whole disability thing and all, the food banks provide better options and weve more choices for places to go where we wont be lectured about how we are livin in sin by bein trans, as a prereq to even get food

Its like, state/city/county fundin of these things hvily impacts whether its plentiful or not; far moreso  than you cud ever believe if yavent lived somewhere that the state restricts all of that

Oh btw, and in some of those states they refuse to provide me food stamps bcuz i cannot work; so idve to go out and try to work bcuz i dont qualify for disability as they wudnt pay for me to get a diagnosis of anythin when i was on state healthcare in said red state ‚Äî it doesnt matter that im actually disabled and this is clear as day, they demand proof and they wont let me get the proof bcuz they dont want to give out any of their meager funds to anyone when it comes to their food stamps

Back in Oregon, and again now in Colorado, theyre willin to waive those requirements for me even without proof of disability, bcuz they care more about providin for their poorest ppl than they do about some alleged welfare queens defraudin the system. 

Heck, Oregon nvr required me to go out and seek employment when i lived there bcuz they saw that my job history was a line of 6 month or less jobs and were able to figure out that i wasnt a good fit for working. Even long before i realised i was disabled and it started impactin my physical health a lot more as things caught up to me, Oregon was just like "Yeah, feed this person even if they cant find steady employment ever; why shudnt we do this?". A lot of the red states wudnt dare allow such things bcuz theyre so convinced that the few ppl takin the meager funds theyve got wud all just pull themselves up by their bootstraps if they didnt have this

Bootstraps mentality nearly saw me dead and resulted in me bein homeless for not bein able to do it all myself; feck that

text:
"Major in something that's got a good return on the investment of a degree. Save money aggressively " - apologies if I missed the sarcasm. But that is the very point the OP is calling out about the video.  Even this statement that I quoted assumes a ton of privilege. That "everyone" has the access and opportunity to get an education to "Major in something". And that they have disposable income to save.

It's very much ingrained in our western culture. Individualism and "everyone can make it".  Don't get me wrong, I'm not discounting the hard work part, there are plenty of people who are success that work very hard. But it almost always discounts the good fortune required to enable the fact for that hard work to pay off. For many many people that same level of hard work, due to circumstances outside of their own power, will never lead to anything more than mere survival. And in our current socio-economic climate, even that mere survival is in question/jeopardy.
author: @aggies11

text:
¬†@jimbob4004¬† It's not weird. Adam is a smart guy, but he was brought up in this society and our western beliefs are incredibly pervasive. Insidious even. Despite him recognizing that this video itself is cognitively dissonant.  despite showing his distaste for wealth inequality and the unfairness of being poor. He also still "agrees" with the idea that humans need incentives to work, that the whipmaster has to be always at your back so that you can aspire to something "more".  At it's worse we call it hustle culture.  But it's this false idea that only through hard work and sacrifice can you obtain "worth". And truly enjoy life to it's fullest.   It CANT be that all humans deserve joy, pleasure and happiness, because that wouldn't be "fair" and it would invalidate all the hard work you did to get where you are.

And so this video is him wrestling with that idea, but ultimately not quite getting to the full realization.  He didn't have to buy the $15K. He can buy it, he can afford it (and he can make a video about it that potentially increases his wealth to offset the cost if not entirely pay for it).  But if he truly thought that the $15k fridge was an opulent waste, then he wasn't forced to do it there were other options.  And sadly once you end up with that much priviledge, you unfortunately can't reasonably commentate on "the poor". 

Rich people taking private jets aren't the main reason we are facing a climate crisis. But if you are a rich person and you are going to talk about publicly your support in the fight against climate change, you can't also be taking private jets everywhere just because "well I can afford it,  and it's already there, so it's not going to make that much of a difference...".   Principles. You can't just talk principled, you have to act principled too.
author: @aggies11

text:
¬†@Sleeper_6875¬† It's been psychological proven that we have a really hard time of properly attributing how much good fortune/luck is responsible for our own outcomes. We usually dramatically over estimate how much of it was due to our own uniqueness and hard work and effort.  That on it's own doesn't seem too bad, until you realize that viewpoint inherently means that you then must believe that people who are less successful than yourself must also be equally responsible for their own fate.

One of the major follies of modern society is that it's set up to, often directly, but more commonly subtley, pit all of us against one another. It's a rat race, and for you to get ahead means you have to step on the hand of the person next to you. Resources are limited and so, you gotta make sure you got yours.

text: @ maybe not, but if you look at the back of the package, do you think an ingredient list that just says ‚Äúsemolina flour‚Äù vs ‚Äúsemolina flour, reduced iron, niacin, thiamine, etc.‚Äù is equal in health value?

text:
‚ÄúSociety will take all forces of production and means of commerce, as well as the exchange and distribution of products, out of the hands of private capitalists and will manage them in accordance with a plan based on the availability of resources and the needs of the whole society. In this way, most important of all, the evil consequences which are now associated with the conduct of big industry will be abolished.
There will be no more crises; the expanded production, which for the present order of society is overproduction and hence a prevailing cause of misery, will then be insufficient and in need of being expanded much further. Instead of generating misery, overproduction will reach beyond the elementary requirements of society to assure the satisfaction of the needs of all; it will create new needs and, at the same time, the means of satisfying them. It will become the condition of, and the stimulus to, new progress, which will no longer throw the whole social order into confusion, as progress has always done in the past. Big industry, freed from the pressure of private property, will undergo such an expansion that what we now see will seem as petty in comparison as manufacture seems when put beside the big industry of our own day. This development of industry will make available to society a sufficient mass of products to satisfy the needs of everyone.‚Äù

- Engels, the principles of communism

The problem with eating cheap is that learning to cook and learning to cook the way you like food costs money.

I grew up broke with a mom who couldn‚Äôt cook. I went to college and was also broke and ate terribly. I also probably spent more money on food as I hated the crap I was eating.

I PROBABLY eat cheaper today and my family makes really good money. We meal prep beans for beans and rice and our recipe is so good that we eat it a lot. And I eat a lot of chicken breast. I messed up chicken breast all the time when I was young and stopped buying it. But now? I sous vide it and then sear it on a cast iron with some garlic and broccoli. I eat that almost daily. text: This is a fundamental refusal to understand how much a manger can help. If people aren‚Äôt organized properly, their labor can be way less valuable than if they are organized, so getting rid of managers and getting your ‚Äúfull labor value‚Äù can often leave you poorer
author: @Brent-jj6qi

text: ¬†@Eden_Laika¬†capitalism fundamentally doesn‚Äôt have any requirement for shareholders to profit, that‚Äôs a purely recent government incention
author: @Brent-jj6qi

text: ¬†@Brent-jj6qi¬† Why would people invest in a company that didn't generate a return on their investment? How would they be incentivised otherwise?
author: @Eden_Laika

text: @ they could still get a return on their investment without legally requiring the company to hard focus quarterly profits, in fact, they‚Äôd potentially get a bigger return long term
author: @Brent-jj6qi

text: ¬†@Brent-jj6qi¬† Worker co-operatives are provably more efficient, stable and resiliant to outside shocks than corperations. They also, on average, have better worker retention and customer satisfaction. There's plenty of research on this, from multiple countries.
author: @Eden_Laika

text: @Brent-jj6qi¬† "Potentially"? That's not very convincing.
author: @Eden_Laika

text: @ yeah, well, you also don‚Äôt see worker coops building high tech goods for a reason
author: @Brent-jj6qi

text: ¬†@Eden_Laika¬† I said they could potentially get more, the core of my argument stands, which is that most of the issue is the legal requirement to focus on quarterly profits, which is artificial and not part of capitalism
author: @Brent-jj6qi

text: @Brent-jj6qi¬† And what is that reason?
author: @Eden_Laika

text: @Brent-jj6qi¬† But these legal requirments haven't just popped into existence ex nihilo. Why do they exist?
author: @Eden_Laika

text: @ because they require the coordination of millions of people to produce
author: @Brent-jj6qi

text: @Brent-jj6qi¬† No they don't. They require resouces to be gathered and refined to certain specifications, and then put through certain industrial processes, but no step of the process requires the coordination of more than a few hundred people.
author: @Eden_Laika

text: ¬†@Brent-jj6qi¬† Just to elaborate my point: let's say you're making CPUs. You need silicon that has been purified and chrystalised to a certain standard, but you don't need to know how it was mined, how exactly it was processed and refined, and how it's been transported; all you need to know is that it's to spec. Similarly, the people refining the silicon don't need to know anything about the process of making CPUs, they just need to know the specs they need to reach. And the people transporting the silicon don't even need to know what it is, they just need to know where it's coming from, where it's going and how to store it in the meantime. Making a CPU is an extremely complicated process, but you don't need to have one organisation doing everything. In fact, that would be massively inefficient.
author: @Eden_Laika

text: ¬†@everettvitols5690¬† The labour theory of value has not been widely debunked, and it never will be, because it's a model: a way to analyse economic activity. it's useful in some contexts and limited in others. 'Value' itself does not objectively exist; it's a conceptual tool used by economists to describe how the economy fuctions.
author: @Eden_Laika

text: @mvmlego1212¬† All foods have benefits and drawbacks, but the question is which foods have more benefits than drawbacks.  The bottom line is health outcomes.  The study I cited found that those who eat no meat other than fish were significantly less likely to develop chronic diseases and live longer.  Pescatarians lived the longest, but if vegans were to take algae based omega 3 supplements, they would live longer than pescatarians.  Vegetarians (including vegans) do live longer than other types of meat eaters according to that study.

text:
¬†@someguy2135¬† -- All of that sounds plausible to me, and most of it sounds likely--but it still doesn't imply that beans (which is one of many meat substitutes) are a healthy substitute for chicken (or any other specific kind of meat).

I think that you're making a statistical syllogism like this:
P1) Vegetarian foods are healthier than non-vegetarian foods.
P2) Beans are a vegetarian food, and chicken is a non-vegetarian food.
C) Therefore, beans are healthier than chicken.

The flaw is in P1. Vegetarian foods are healthier than non-vegetarian foods _on average, but not categorically_. Consequently, we can't say with confidence that a particular vegetarian food is healthier than a particular non-vegetarian food. Consequently, "eat more beans" isn't helpful advice.

author: @barvdw

text: ¬†@roymarshall_¬† The first thing every college student in my country invest in is some kind of cooking source, either a small gas stove or if you invest a little bit more an induction stove, sometime even before a bed or a table. It saves you from being at the mercy of local vendor's pricing for your meals, but it's also such a massive quality of life improvement simply for the fact you can reheat your food, you don't have to chow down on your food before it gets cold or get depressed eating stale cold leftover. And if the dorm doesn't allow cooking, they don't have to know.

author: @illeatmyhat

text:
¬†@roymarshall_¬† I'm in college now and I don't have a kitchen beyond the shared one but I cook stuff in the shared kitchen. I make food once or twice a week to supplement the meals from the cafeteria in bulk and freeze it to eat about one meal a day from my own food. Cause the meal plan is required but absurdly over priced (the cheapest is 1,200 a semester. I can eat for WAAAY cheaper then that on my own and I would if I was allowed to. But next semester I can when I move out so I will be.)

Yeah, I'll make like 4 or 5 big dishes at the beginning of the semester and freeze it so I can rotate out meals and I cook another dish or two each week and freeze it, picking foods and skewing my choices towards older food to keep it so nothing is older than a month. Then for the last two weeks ish of the semester I just polish off whatever's left.

This week I made beans rice and sausage (just the addition of sausage makes it so much tastier and polish sausage isn't all too expensive in an entire large dish. It's like 5 bucks but all the food comes out to like 10 meals so it's not horrible.) and I also made rice and beef because there was some ultra-thin cut stew meat (I think they just cut it wrong or something?? The coloring was good and it smelled fine and wasn't due to expire for another 4 days when I bought it so I assumed it was just because it was cut into almost paper think strips) so I seared it then made a gravy then watered the gravy down to the appropriate proportions to cook the rice in and threw in the stew meat to stew with the rice. Really tasty. And only came out to like 50 cents a meal for that. Including the cost of rice. (Rice is cheap)
author: @Edragon_Ghostmage

text:
¬†@roymarshall_¬† Not everyone lives in the US ;). European University life is very different than in America. Usually people live in shared flats, not dorms. So they are used to having a kitchen, comparatively eating out is more expensive than in the US due to actually paying a proper wage and buying ingredients is cheaper than in the US, because of a lot of reasons including on how agricultural subsidies work and the efficiency of stores.
Add to that that in the EU studying is generally free and the students only have to support themselfes and not the university as well and you get the people who usually turn up when you search for these types of videos. Europeans who were broke during college (for European standards).
author: @thecashier930
